revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=March 2011}} {{Infobox convention | name = Clevention, the 13th World Science Fiction Convention | image = | caption = | status = | genre = [[Science fiction]] | venue = Manger Hotel | location = [[Cleveland, Ohio]] | country = United States | first = September 2–5, 1955 | last = | organizer = | filing = non-profit | attendance = 380 | website = }} The '''13th World Science Fiction Convention''', also known as '''Clevention''', was held on September 2–5, 1955, at the Manger Hotel in [[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]], United States. The chairmen were Nick and Noreen Falasca. The guests of honor were [[Isaac Asimov]] (pro) and [[Sam Moskowitz]] (mystery GoH). Total attendance was approximately 380. This was the first convention at which the [[Hugo Award]]s were established as an annual feature; the first awards had been given out two years before, at [[Philcon II]] in 1953. ==Awards== {{About-Hugos}} The 11th Worldcon was the first one in which Hugo Awards were awarded. The 12th convention did not continue the tradition, but since the 13th convention, Hugo Awards have been a permanent fixture of Worldcons. ===Hugo Awards=== * [[Hugo Award for Best Novel|Best Novel]]: ''[[They'd Rather Be Right]]'' by [[Mark Clifton]] and [[Frank Riley (author)|Frank Riley]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Novelette|Best Novelette]]: "[[The Darfsteller]]" by [[Walter M. Miller, Jr.]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Short Story|Best Short Story]]: "[[Allamagoosa]]" by [[Eric Frank Russell]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Professional Artist|Best Professional Artist]]: [[Frank Kelly Freas]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Professional Magazine|Best Professional Magazine]]: ''[[Astounding]]'' edited by John W. Campbell, Jr. * [[Hugo Award for Best Fanzine|Best Fanzine]]: ''Fantasy Times'' edited by James V. Taurasi, Sr. and Ray Van Houten ==References== {{reflist|refs= {{cite web|work=The Hugo Awards |title=1955 Hugo Awards |publisher=[[World Science Fiction Society]] |url=http://www.thehugoawards.org/hugo-history/1955-hugo-awards/ |accessdate=March 7, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yVV7zBct?url=http://www.thehugoawards.org/hugo-history/1955-hugo-awards/ |archivedate=May 7, 2011 |df= }} }} ==See also== {{portal|Novels}} *[[World Science Fiction Society]] {{S-start}} {{Succession box | before=[[12th World Science Fiction Convention]]
SFCon in [[San Francisco, California|San Francisco]], United States (1954) | title=[[List of Worldcons]] | years='''13th World Science Fiction Convention'''
Clevention in [[Cleveland, Ohio|Cleveland]], United States (1955) | after=[[14th World Science Fiction Convention]]
NYCon II in [[New York City|New York]], United States (1956) | }} {{S-end}} {{World Science Fiction Convention}} {{DEFAULTSORT:World Science Fiction Convention 013}} [[Category:World Science Fiction Convention]] [[Category:Science fiction conventions in the United States]] [[Category:Culture of Cleveland]] [[Category:1955 in Ohio]] [[Category:1955 conferences]] {{Sf-convention-stub}}

{{Coord|43|44|4.74|N|7|25|16.8|E|scale:1563_type:landmark_region:MC|display=title}} {{Refimprove|date=February 2007}} {{Infobox Grand Prix race report |Type = EC |Grand Prix = Monaco |Date = 13 April |Image = File:Circuit_de_Monaco_1950.png |Year = 1936 |Official name = VIII Grand Prix de Monaco |Country = Monaco |Race_No = 1 |Season_No = 4 |Location = [[Circuit de Monaco]]
[[Monte Carlo]] |Course = Street circuit |Course_mi = 1.976 |Course_km = 3.180 |Distance_laps = 100 |Distance_mi = 197.6 |Distance_km = 318.0 |Weather = Heavy rain |Pole_Driver = [[Louis Chiron]] |Pole_Team = [[Mercedes-Benz]] |Pole_Country = Monaco |Pole_Time = 1:53.2 |Fast_Driver = [[Hans Stuck]] |Fast_Team = [[Auto Union]] |Fast_Time = 2:07.4 |Fast_Country = Germany |Fast_flag_suffix = Nazi |First_Driver = [[Rudolf Caracciola]] |First_Team = [[Mercedes-Benz]] |First_Country = Germany |First_flag_suffix = Nazi |Second_Driver = [[Achille Varzi]] |Second_Team = [[Auto Union]] |Second_Country = Italy |Second_flag_suffix = 1861 |Third_Driver = [[Hans Stuck]] |Third_Team = [[Auto Union]] |Third_Country = Germany |Third_flag_suffix = Nazi }} The '''1936 Monaco Grand Prix''' was a [[Grand Prix motor racing|Grand Prix]] [[motor race]] held at [[Circuit de Monaco]] on 13 April 1936. Heavy rain contributed to a series of accidents, while a broken oil line on the [[Alfa Romeo]] of [[Mario Tadini]] led to so many wrecks in the [[chicane]] out of the tunnel it was almost impassable.Kettlewell, Mike. "Monaco: Road Racing on the Riviera", in Northey, Tom, editor. ''World of Automobiles'' (London: Orbis, 1974), Volume 12, pp.1382–1383. The [[Mercedes-Benz in motorsport|Mercedes-Benz]]es of [[Louis Chiron]], [[Luigi Fagioli]], and [[Manfred von Brauchitsch]], as well as [[Bernd Rosemeyer]]'s ''Typ C'' of newcomer [[Auto Union racing car|Auto Union]], were all eliminated.Kettlewell, p.1383. [[Tazio Nuvolari]] in the [[Alfa Romeo 8C]] benefitted from the chaos, only to suffer [[brake fade]], and [[Rudolf Caracciola]], proving the truth of his [[List of motorsports people by nickname#R|nickname]], ''Regenmeister'' (Rainmaster), went on to win for Mercedes. He was followed by [[Achille Varzi]] and [[Hans Stuck]], both for Auto Union.Kettlewell, p.1383. ==Classification== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 95%;" !Pos !No !Driver !Team !Car !Laps !Time/Retired !Grid !Points |- ! 1 | 8 | {{flagicon|DEU|Nazi}} '''[[Rudolf Caracciola]]''' | '''[[Daimler-Benz|Daimler-Benz AG]]''' | '''[[Mercedes-Benz W25|Mercedes-Benz W25K]]''' | 100 | 3:49:20.4 | 3 | '''1''' |- ! 2 | 4 | {{flagicon|ITA|1861}} '''[[Achille Varzi]]''' | '''[[Auto Union]]''' | '''[[Auto Union C]]''' | 100 | +1:48.9 | 7 | '''2''' |- ! 3 | 2 | {{flagicon|DEU|Nazi}} '''[[Hans Stuck]]''' | '''[[Auto Union]]''' | '''[[Auto Union C]]''' | 99 | +1 Lap | 4 | '''3''' |- ! 4 | 24 | {{flagicon|ITA|1861}} '''[[Tazio Nuvolari]]''' | '''[[Scuderia Ferrari]]''' | '''[[Alfa Romeo 8C#1935 Monoposto 8C 35 Type C|Alfa Romeo 8C 35 Type C]]''' | 99 | +1 Lap | 2 | '''4''' |- !rowspan=2|5 |rowspan=2|26 | {{flagicon|ITA|1861}} '''[[Antonio Brivio]]''' |rowspan=2|'''[[Scuderia Ferrari]]''' |rowspan=2|'''[[Alfa Romeo 8C#1935 Monoposto 8C 35 Type C|Alfa Romeo 8C 35 Type C]]''' |rowspan=2|97 |rowspan=2|+3 Laps |rowspan=2|11 | '''4''' |- | {{flagicon|ITA|1861}} [[Giuseppe Farina]] | n/a |- ! 6 | 16 | {{flagicon|FRA}} '''[[Jean-Pierre Wimille]]''' | '''[[Bugatti]]''' | '''[[Bugatti T59]]''' | 97 | +3 Laps | 8 | '''4''' |- ! 7 | 22 | {{flagicon|FRA}} '''[[Raymond Sommer]]''' | Private entry | '''[[Alfa Romeo Tipo B]]''' | 94 | +6 Laps | 14 | '''4''' |- ! 8 | 38 | {{flagicon|ITA|1861}} '''[[Pietro Ghersi]]''' | '''Scuderia Torino''' | '''[[Maserati]] 6C-34''' | 87 | +13 Laps | 17 | '''4''' |- ! 9 | 18 | {{flagicon|GBR}} '''[[William Grover-Williams]]''' | '''[[Bugatti]]''' | '''[[Bugatti T59]]''' | 84 | +16 Laps | 16 | '''4''' |- ! {{Infobox Election | election_name = Stafford by-election | type = presidential | country = United Kingdom | seats_for_election = [[Stafford (UK Parliament constituency)|Stafford]] parliamentary seat | ongoing = no | previous_election = United Kingdom general election, 1983 | previous_year = 1983 | next_election = United Kingdom general election, 1987 | next_year = 1987 | election_date = 3 May 1984
| candidate1 = [[Bill Cash]] | image1 =   | party1 = Conservative Party (UK) | popular_vote1 = '''18,713''' | percentage1 = '''40.4%'''
| candidate2 = David Dunn | image2 =   | party2 = Social Democratic Party (UK) | popular_vote2 = 14,733 | percentage2 = 31.8%
| candidate3 = Michael Poulter | image3 =   | party3 = Labour Party (UK) | popular_vote3 = 12,677 | percentage3 = 27.4%
| title = MP | posttitle = Subsequent MP | before_election = [[Hugh Fraser (British politician)|Hugh Fraser]] | before_party = Conservative Party (UK) | after_election = [[Bill Cash]] | after_party = Conservative Party (UK) }}
The '''Stafford by-election, 1984''' was a [[by-election|parliamentary by-election]] held on 3 May 1984 for the [[British House of Commons]] [[United Kingdom constituencies|constituency]] of [[Stafford (UK Parliament constituency)|Stafford]].
== Previous MP == The seat fell vacant when the constituency's [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] [[Member of Parliament]] (MP), [[Hugh Fraser (British politician)|Major Sir Hugh Charles Patrick Joseph Fraser]] [[Order of the British Empire|MBE]] (23 January 1918 – 6 March 1984) died.
Fraser was educated at [[Ampleforth College]], [[Balliol College, Oxford]], where he was President of the [[Oxford Union]], and at the [[University of Paris|Sorbonne]]. He was commissioned into the [[Lovat Scouts]] in 1936 and during [[World War II]] saw service in [[North Africa]] and [[Europe]]; he retired in the 1950s with the rank of [[Major]].
Fraser was elected Member of Parliament for [[Stone (UK Parliament constituency)|Stone]] in 1945, later [[Stafford and Stone (UK Parliament constituency)|Stafford and Stone]] following constituency boundary changes, from 1950 until 1983, and then [[Stafford (UK Parliament constituency)|Stafford]] until his death.
== Candidates == Four candidates were nominated. The list below is set out in descending order of the number of votes received at the by-election.
1. The Conservative candidate was [[William Cash|William Nigel Paul Cash]] (born on 10 May 1940), a solicitor.
He has served continuously in the House of Commons since winning the by-election (as of July 2017). Cash represented Stafford, until boundary changes took effect in 1997. Since then he has been returned as MP for [[Stone (UK Parliament constituency)|Stone]].
2. The Social Democratic Party (SDP) candidate, representing the [[SDP-Liberal Alliance]], was David Joseph Dunn. He was a senior lecturer in International Relations, at the time of the by-election. He was born in 1946 and had contested the seat in the 1983 general election.
3. Michael John David Poulter was the Labour candidate. He worked as a senior probation officer and was born in 1942. He contested Stafford and Stone in 1979 and this constituency in 1983.
4. Christopher David Teasdale was an Independent, using the ballot paper label "Soon to be unemployed".
== Votes == {{Election box begin |title=1984 by-election: Stafford<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.election.demon.co.uk/by1983.html|title=Results of Byelections in the 1983-87 Parliament|last=Boothroyd|first=David|access-date=2015-09-19|website=United Kingdom Election Results}}</ref>}} {{Election box candidate with party link| |party = Conservative Party (UK) |candidate = [[Bill Cash]] |votes = 18,713 |percentage = 40.4 |change = -10.8 }} {{Election box candidate with party link| |party = Social Democratic Party (UK) |candidate = David Dunn |votes = 14,733 |percentage = 31.8 |change = +7.1 }} {{Election box candidate with party link| |party = Labour Party (UK) |candidate = Michael Poulter |votes = 12,677 |percentage = 27.4 |change = +3.7 }} {{Election box candidate with party link| |party = Independent (politics) |candidate = Christopher Teasdale |votes = 210 |percentage = 0.4 |change = N/A }} {{Election box majority| |votes = 3,980 |percentage = 8.6 |change = -17.9 }} {{Election box turnout| |votes = 46,333 |percentage = 65.6 |change = -10.9 }} {{Election box hold with party link| |winner = Conservative Party (UK) |swing = }} {{Election box Registered electors| |reg. electors = 70,635 }} {{Election box end}}
==See also== * [[Stafford (UK Parliament constituency)|Stafford constituency]] * [[List of United Kingdom by-elections]] * [[United Kingdom by-election records]]
==External links== *[http://by-elections.co.uk/stafford84.html Campaign literature from the by-election]
==Sources== {{reflist}} * ''Britain Votes/Europe Votes By-Election Supplement 1983-'', compiled and edited by F.W.S. Craig (Parliamentary Research Services 1985)

Section "Other awards": added the winner of the John W. Campbell Award for Best New Writer (R. A. MacAvoy)
revision.text:
{{Infobox convention | name = L.A.con II, the 42nd World Science Fiction Convention | image = | caption = | status = | genre = [[Science fiction]] | venue = Anaheim Hilton and the Anaheim Convention Center | location = [[Anaheim, California]] | country = United States | first = August 30–September 3, 1984 | organizer = | filing = non-profit | attendance = 8,365 | website = }} The '''42nd World Science Fiction Convention''' ([[Worldcon]]), also known as '''L.A.con II''', was held August 30–September 3, 1984, at the Anaheim Hilton and the Anaheim Convention Center in [[Anaheim, California]], United States. The chairmen were Craig Miller and [[Milt Stevens]]. The Guests of Honor were [[Gordon R. Dickson]] (pro) and [[Dick Eney]] (fan). [[Robert Bloch]] was the Toastmaster for the Hugo Ceremony, and [[Jerry Pournelle]] was the Master of Ceremonies for the Other Awards Ceremony. Total attendance was 8,365, a record and the largest to date. == Awards == {{About-Hugos}} ===Hugo Awards=== * [[Hugo Award for Best Novel|Best Novel]]: ''[[Startide Rising]]'' by [[David Brin]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Novella|Best Novella]]: "[[Cascade Point]]" by [[Timothy Zahn]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Novelette|Best Novelette]]: "[[Blood Music (novel)|Blood Music]]" by [[Greg Bear]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Short Story|Best Short Story]]: "[[Speech Sounds]]" by [[Octavia Butler]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Non-Fiction Book|Best Non-Fiction Book]]: ''[[Encyclopedia of Science Fiction and Fantasy]]'', vol. III, by [[Donald Tuck]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Dramatic Presentation|Best Dramatic Presentation]]: ''[[Return of the Jedi]]'' * [[Hugo Award for Best Professional Editor|Best Professional Editor]]: [[Shawna McCarthy]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Professional Artist|Best Professional Artist]]: [[Michael Whelan]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Semiprozine|Best Semiprozine]]: ''[[Locus (magazine)|Locus]]'', by [[Charles N. Brown]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Fanzine|Best Fanzine]]: ''[[File 770]]'', edited by [[Mike Glyer]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Fan Writer|Best Fan Writer]]: Mike Glyer * [[Hugo Award for Best Fan Artist|Best Fan Artist]]: [[Alexis Gilliland]] ===Other awards=== * [[John W. Campbell Award for Best New Writer]]: [[R. A. MacAvoy]] * Special Award: ** [[Larry T. Shaw]] for lifetime achievement as a science fiction editor ** [[Robert Bloch]] for fifty years as a science fiction professional ==Notable events== At the convention [[Robert Heinlein]] appeared, continuing his campaign to encourage [[science fiction fandom|science fiction fans]] to make [[blood donation]]s. [[A.E. Van Vogt]] appeared at the convention. ==See also== *[[World Science Fiction Society]] ==References== {{reflist|refs= }} == External links == * [http://www.nesfa.org/data/LL/TheLongList.html NESFA.org: The Long List] * [http://www.nesfa.org/data/LL/LongListNotes.html#1984 NESFA.org: 1984 convention notes] {{s-start}} {{succession box | before = [[41st World Science Fiction Convention]]
ConStellation in [[Baltimore, Maryland|Baltimore]], United States (1983) | title = [[List of Worldcons]] | years = '''42nd World Science Fiction Convention'''
L.A.con II in [[Anaheim, California|Anaheim]], United States (1984) | after = [[43rd World Science Fiction Convention]]
Aussiecon Two in [[Melbourne]], Australia (1985) }} {{s-end}} {{World Science Fiction Convention}} {{DEFAULTSORT:World Science Fiction Convention 042}} [[Category:1984 in the United States]] [[Category:World Science Fiction Convention]] [[Category:1984 in California]] [[Category:Science fiction conventions in the United States]] [[Category:1984 conferences]]

revision.comment: Gave a tiny bit of clarification to the party's leadership, and fixed grammar.
revision.text:
{{hatnote|Not to be confused with the [[Action Party (Italy)|Action Party]] of 1942}} {{one source|date=March 2015}} {{Infobox political party | name = Action Party | native_name = Partito d'Azione | colorcode = {{Action Party (Italy, 1848)/meta/color}} | leader1_title = Leaders | leader1_name = [[Giuseppe Mazzini]]
[[Giuseppe Garibaldi]]
[[Carlo Cattaneo]]
[[Carlo Pisacane]]
[[Aurelio Saffi]] | foundation = {{start date and age|1848|5|5|df=yes}} | dissolution = {{end date and age|1867|11|4|df=yes}} | successor = [[Historical Far Left]] | headquarters = [[Genoa]], [[Kingdom of Italy|Italy]] | newspaper = ''L'Unità italiana'' | wing1_title = Paramilitary wing | wing1 = [[Redshirts (Italy)|Redshirts]] | ideology = [[Federalism]]
[[Italian nationalism]]
[[Pan-Europeanism]]
[[Republicanism]] | position = [[Left-wing politics|Left-wing]] | international = [[Young Europe]] | colours = {{color box|{{Action Party (Italy, 1848)/meta/color}}|border=darkgray}} [[Red]] | slogan = ''Unione, Forza e Libertà''
("Union, Strength and Liberty") | country = Italy }} The '''Action Party''' ({{lang-it|Partito d'Azione}}) was an Italian pre-unitary [[political party]] active during the [[Risorgimento]].{{cite web|url=http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/partito-d-azione/|title=Partito d'Azione|work=Encilopedia Treccani}} It was the first organized party in the [[history of Italy]]. == History == After the failure of the [[Revolutions of 1848 in the Italian states|Italian revolutions of 1848]], [[Giuseppe Mazzini]]'s [[Young Italy (historical)|Young Italy]] was dissolved as a political organization to form the Italian National Association ({{lang-it|Associazione Nazionale Italiana}}), which was still led by Mazzini. During the 1848–1849, the Italian National Association competed against the rival [[Moderate Party (Italy)|Moderate Party]] led by [[Vincenzo Gioberti]] and [[Massimo d'Azeglio]] that won the election in the [[Kingdom of Sardinia]] and established a new government. After some years of weak activities, the Italian National Association was renamed in 1853 by Mazzini to the Action Party, which published the booklet-manifesto "To the Italians" (''Agli Italiani''){{cite book|first=Giuseppe|last=Mazzini|title=Agli italiani|pages=748–759|date=1853}} and invited [[Italians]] to start various rebel and republican organizations. This tactic was changed after the failed invasion of [[Sapri]] of the same year, where [[Carlo Pisacane]] died. In 1860, the Action Party financed the creation of a paramilitary group led by [[Giuseppe Garibaldi]] named the [[Redshirts (Italy)|Redshirts]] (''Camicie rosse''). The Redshirts become particularly famous for the [[Expedition of the Thousand]], when Garibaldi conquered in a few months all of the [[Kingdom of the Two Sicilies]] and the [[Papal States]]. In this period, the Action Party was strongly opposed to the Moderate Party and its new leader [[Camillo Benso di Cavour]], who was close to the [[House of Savoy]]. Mazzini particularly hated the annexation war, the falsification of the referendums and the Piedmontization of Italy that ignored the various diversities of a unified [[Italy]]. The Action Party founded the first mutual aid societies, workers' associations, public schools and cooperatives. In the 1861, Mazzini founded the newspaper of the Action Party, ''L'Unità italiana''. In 1867, the Action Party attempted to conclude the [[Unification War]] and take over [[Rome]] with the [[Battle of Mentana]], which failed. Disappointed, Mazzini dissolved the Action Party and retired from the politics. In 1870, Garibaldi [[Capture of Rome|captured Rome]], which became the capital of the [[Kingdom of Italy]]. In 1877, [[Agostino Bertani]], a former member of the Action Party, left the [[Historical Left]] to form the [[Historical Far-Left]], reputed to be the real heir of the Action Party. == Proposals and goals == * [[Unification of Italy]], including the "[[Italian irredentism|Irrident Lands]]". * Abolition of the [[monarchy]] and creation of a [[republic]]. * Elections with [[universal suffrage]]. * Support of the [[freedom of religion]], [[Freedom of the press|press]], [[Freedom of speech|speech]] and [[Freedom of thought|thought]]. * Creation of the [[United States of Europe]]. == Electoral results == {|class=wikitable |- |colspan=7|[[Chamber of Deputies (Italy)|Chamber of Deputies]] |- !Election year !No. of
overall votes !% of
overall vote !No. of
overall seats won !+/– !Leader |- ![[Italian general election, 1861|1861]] |Unknown (3rd) |2.3 |{{composition bar|14|443|hex={{Action Party (Italy, 1848)/meta/color}}}} |
–
|
[[Giuseppe Mazzini]]
|- ![[Italian general election, 1865|1865]] |Unknown (3rd) |3.5 |{{composition bar|15|443|hex={{Action Party (Italy, 1848)/meta/color}}}} |
{{increase}} 1
|
[[Giuseppe Mazzini]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox film |name = Aurore |image = Aurore.jpg |caption = Aurore movie poster |director = Luc Dionne |producer = Denise Robert
Daniel Louis |writer = Luc Dionne |starring = Marianne Fortier
[[Serge Postigo]]
[[Remy Girard]]
[[Stéphanie Lapointe]]
Yves Jacques
Helene Bourgeois-Leclerc
[[Michel Forget]]
[[Sarah-Jeanne Labrosse]] | | cinematography = Louis de Ernsted | music = Michel Cusson | editing = Isabelle Dedieu | distributor = Alliance Atlantis Vivafilm | released = July 8, 2005
(Quebec)
 | runtime = 115 minutes | country = Canada | language = [[French language|French]] | budget = $7 million CDN [http://lcn.canoe.com/artsetspectacles/cinema/archives/2004/09/20040930-110747.html]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} }} '''''Aurore''''' is a [[2005 in film|2005]] [[Quebec]] [[biographical]] [[drama]] movie that was directed by [[Luc Dionne]] and produced by [[Denise Robert]] and Daniel Louis. The movie is a remake of [[Jean-Yves Bigras]]'s 1952 movie ''[[Little Aurore's Tragedy|La petite Aurore: l'enfant martyre]] (Little Aurore: The Child Martyr)''. ==Synopsis== Aurore Gagnon, born in 1909 to Marie-Anne Caron and Telesphore Gagnon, is the second child of the couple. During the first nine years of her life, Aurore enjoys a happy life. Then, during the fall of 1917, Aurore's mother develops [[tuberculosis]]. She is brought to hospital for several months and doctors conclude she will never recover. Plans are made to give custody of Aurore and her sister Marie-Jeanne to Telesphore and his late wife's cousin, Marie-Anne Houde (often simply referred to as Telesphore's cousin in the movie), with whom he had fallen in love. During a visit to Marie-Anne Houde before she goes into hospital, Aurore's mother finds one of Marie-Anne's children locked inside a wooden structure. This alerts her that Marie-Anne might not treat her children well. At the same time, Aurore sees her father kissing Marie-Anne; the girl criticizes her father for not caring enough about his ill wife. Aurore's mother dies in 1918, and Telesphore and Marie-Anne marry immediately after the funeral. This is the start of an unhappier, more difficult life for Aurore, as her [[stepmother]] and father begin at once to mistreat her. When two of Marie-Anne's children die, some villagers blame Houde for their deaths. The situation soon becomes worse for Aurore. During Father Leduc's visit to her school, he asks her a question about religion and she tells him to lower his voice. Immediately, Telesphore and Marie-Anne are notified and the [[mistreatment]] becomes more and more brutal. Marie-Anne carries out most of the abuse by slapping Aurore, striking her feet with a [[Lumber#Dimensional lumber|2x4]] with nails, and burning her with a burning steel hook. Her father also abuses her by slapping her and striking her with an axe handle. She is also locked in an isolated room with little food. After the attack with the nails, Oreus, the peace judge of the town, forces her parents to send Aurore to hospital and suspects that she has been beaten. When Exilda Lemay (played by Francine Ruel), discovers Aurore with severe wounds all over her body, she immediately alerts Oreus about the situation. Oreus goes to Quebec to discuss the issue with a crown attorney. When the peace judge and several others, including doctors, arrive at Aurore's home, it is too late: she collapsed on the stairs and was attacked again by Marie-Anne with a 2x4. Doctors are unable to save Aurore, who passes away from [[blood poisoning]]. After Aurore's funeral, the couple is arrested for Aurore's death. Telesphore is sentenced to [[life sentence|life in prison]] for [[manslaughter]]. His cousin and wife Marie-Anne is initially sentenced to [[death penalty|death]] by [[hanging]] for [[second degree murder]]. She is then given a life sentence, but health issues force her to leave the jail, and she later dies from breast and brain cancer. Father Leduc, whom Oreus blames for his lack of action on the case, kills himself with [[explosives]]. ==Cast== ===Main cast=== * ''[[Aurore Gagnon]]'' (10 years old) by [[Marianne Fortier]] * ''Télesphore Gagnon'' by [[Serge Postigo]] * ''Marie-Anne Houde'' by [[Hélène Bourgeois-Leclerc]] * ''Marie-Anne Caron'' by [[Stéphanie Lapointe]] * ''Oreus Mailhot'' by [[Rémy Girard]] * ''Bishop Leduc'' by [[Yves Jacques]] * ''Marie-Jeanne Gagnon'' by [[Sarah-Jeanne Labrosse]] ===Secondary Cast=== * ''Aurore Gagnon'' (6 years old) by [[Alice Morel-Michaud]] * ''Arzélie Caron'' by [[Monique Spaziani]] * ''Nérée Caron'' by [[Michel Forget]] * ''Exilda Lemay'' by [[Francine Ruel]] * ''Adjutor Gagnon'' by [[Michel Barrette]] * ''Alphonse Chandonnet'' by [[Gaston Lepage]] * ''Arcadius Lemay'' by [[Luc Senay]] ==Awards== The movie was nominated for seven awards, including five [[Genie Awards]] and two [[Jutra Awards]], including Best Adapted Screenplay and Best Actress for Hélène Bourgeois-Leclerc.[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0430895/ Aurore (2005) - IMDb] ==See also== *[[Aurore Gagnon]] ==Footnotes== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|430895|Aurore}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Aurore (film)}} [[Category:2000s drama films]] [[Category:2005 films]] [[Category:Canadian biographical films]] [[Category:Canadian drama films]] [[Category:Canadian films]] [[Category:Films about child abuse]] [[Category:Films based on actual events]] [[Category:Films set in Quebec]] [[Category:French-language films]] [[Category:Canadian film remakes]] [[Category:Quebec films]]

{{short description|Toxic effects of carbon monoxide }} {{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Carbon monoxide poisoning | synonyms = Carbon monoxide intoxication, carbon monoxide toxicity, carbon monoxide overdose | image = Carbon-monoxide-3D-balls.png | alt = A carbon atom (shown as a grey ball) tripled bonded to an oxygen atom (shown as a red ball). | caption = [[Carbon monoxide]] | field = [[Toxicology]], [[emergency medicine]] | symptoms = [[Headache]], [[dizziness]], weakness, vomiting, [[chest pain]], [[confusion]] | complications = [[Loss of consciousness]], [[arrhythmias]], [[seizures]] | onset = | duration = | types = | causes = [[inhalation|Breathing]] in [[carbon monoxide]] | risks = | diagnosis = [[Carboxyl-hemoglobin]] level:
3% (nonsmokers),
10% (smokers) | differential = [[Cyanide toxicity]], [[alcoholic ketoacidosis]], [[aspirin poisoning]], [[upper respiratory tract infection]]{{cite book|last1=Caterino|first1=Jeffrey M.|last2=Kahan|first2=Scott|title=In a Page: Emergency medicine|date=2003|publisher=Lippincott Williams & Wilkins|isbn=978-1405103572|page=309|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O0LwFPZDKbsC&pg=PA309|accessdate=2 July 2017|language=en}} | prevention = [[Carbon monoxide detector]]s, venting of [[gas appliances]], maintenance of [[exhaust system]]s | treatment = [[Supportive care]], [[Oxygen therapy|100% oxygen]], [[hyperbaric oxygen therapy]] | medication = | prognosis = Risk of death 1 to 30%. | frequency = >20,000 emergency visits for non-fire related cases per year (US) | deaths = >400 non-fire related a year (US) }} '''Carbon monoxide poisoning''' typically occurs from [[inhalation|breathing]] in [[carbon monoxide]] (CO) at excessive levels.{{cite book|last1=Schottke|first1=David|title=Emergency Medical Responder: Your First Response in Emergency Care|date=2016|publisher=Jones & Bartlett Learning|isbn=978-1284107272|page=224|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gGCHDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA224|accessdate=2 July 2017|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170910171934/https://books.google.com/books?id=gGCHDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA224|archivedate=10 September 2017|df=}} Symptoms are often described as "[[flu]]-like" and commonly include [[headache]], [[dizziness]], weakness, vomiting, [[chest pain]], and [[confusion]]. Large exposures can result in [[loss of consciousness]], [[arrhythmias]], [[seizures]], or death. The classically described "cherry red skin" rarely occurs. Long term complications may include feeling tired, trouble with memory, and movement problems. In those [[smoke inhalation|exposed to smoke]], [[cyanide toxicity]] should also be considered.{{cite journal|last1=Guzman|first1=JA|title=Carbon monoxide poisoning.|journal=Critical care clinics|date=October 2012|volume=28|issue=4|pages=537–48|pmid=22998990|doi=10.1016/j.ccc.2012.07.007}} Carbon monoxide poisoning can occur accidentally or as an [[suicide|attempt to end one's life]]. CO is a colorless and odorless gas which is initially non-irritating.{{cite journal|last1=Bleecker|first1=ML|title=Carbon monoxide intoxication|journal=Handbook of clinical neurology|date=2015|volume=131|pages=191–203|pmid=26563790|doi=10.1016/B978-0-444-62627-1.00024-X|series=Handbook of Clinical Neurology|isbn=978-0444626271}} It is produced during [[incomplete combustion|incomplete burning]] of [[organic matter]]. This can occur from [[motor vehicles]], heaters, or cooking equipment that run on [[carbon-based fuel]]s. It can also occur from exposure to [[methylene chloride]]. Carbon monoxide primarily causes adverse effects by combining with [[hemoglobin]] to form [[carboxyhemoglobin]] (HbCO) preventing the [[blood]] from carrying [[oxygen]]. Additionally, [[myoglobin]] and [[mitochondria]]l [[cytochrome oxidase]] are affected. Diagnosis is based on a HbCO level of more than 3% among nonsmokers and more than 10% among smokers. Efforts to prevent poisoning include [[carbon monoxide detector]]s, proper venting of [[gas appliances]], keeping chimneys clean, and keeping [[exhaust system]]s of vehicles in good repair.{{cite web|last1=Health|first1=National Center for Environmental|title=Carbon Monoxide Poisoning – Frequently Asked Questions|url=https://www.cdc.gov/co/faqs.htm|website=www.cdc.gov|accessdate=2 July 2017|language=en-us|date=30 December 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170705012403/https://www.cdc.gov/co/faqs.htm|archivedate=5 July 2017|df=}} Treatment of poisoning generally consists of giving [[oxygen therapy|100% oxygen]] along with [[supportive care]]. This should generally be carried out until symptoms are no longer present and the HbCO level is less than 10%. While [[hyperbaric oxygen therapy]] is used for severe poisonings, the benefit over standard oxygen delivery is unclear.{{cite journal|last1=Buckley|first1=NA|last2=Juurlink|first2=DN|last3=Isbister|first3=G|last4=Bennett|first4=MH|last5=Lavonas|first5=EJ|title=Hyperbaric oxygen for carbon monoxide poisoning.|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|date=13 April 2011|issue=4|pages=CD002041|pmid=21491385|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD002041.pub3}} The risk of death among those affected is between 1 and 30%. Carbon monoxide poisoning is relatively common, resulting in more than 20,000 [[emergency department]] visits a year in the United States.{{cite book|last1=Penney|first1=David G.|title=Carbon Monoxide Poisoning|date=2007|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=978-0849384189|page=569|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=793KBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA569|accessdate=2 July 2017|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170910171934/https://books.google.com/books?id=793KBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA569|archivedate=10 September 2017|df=}} It is the most common type of fatal poisoning in many countries.{{cite journal | author=Omaye ST | title=Metabolic modulation of carbon monoxide toxicity | journal=Toxicology |date=Nov 2002 | pages=139–50 | volume=180 | issue=2 | pmid=12324190 | doi=10.1016/S0300-483X(02)00387-6 }} In the United States non-fire related cases results in more than 400 deaths a year. Poisonings occur more often in the winter, particularly from the use of [[portable generators]] during [[power outage]]s.{{cite book|last1=Ferri|first1=Fred F.|title=Ferri's Clinical Advisor 2017 E-Book: 5 Books in 1|date=2016|publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences|isbn=978-0323448383|pages=227–28|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rRhCDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA227|accessdate=2 July 2017|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170910171934/https://books.google.com/books?id=rRhCDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA227|archivedate=10 September 2017|df=}} The toxic effects of CO have been known since [[ancient history]].{{cite journal|last1=Blumenthal|first1=I|title=Carbon monoxide poisoning.|journal=Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine|date=June 2001|volume=94|issue=6|pages=270–72|pmid=11387414|doi=10.1177/014107680109400604|pmc=1281520}} The realization that hemoglobin was affected by CO was determined in 1857. == Signs and symptoms == Carbon monoxide is not toxic to all forms of life. Its harmful effects are due to binding with hemoglobin so its danger to organisms that do not use this compound is doubtful. It thus has no effect on photosynthesising plants.{{cite web|url=http://ces.iisc.ernet.in/energy/HC270799/HDL/ENV/enven/vol321.htm|title=Carbon monoxide|work=ernet.in|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140414051805/http://ces.iisc.ernet.in/energy/HC270799/HDL/ENV/enven/vol321.htm|archivedate=2014-04-14|df=}} It is easily absorbed through the lungs. Inhaling the gas can lead to [[Cerebral hypoxia|hypoxic injury]], [[Brain damage|nervous system damage]], and even [[death]]. Different people and populations may have different carbon monoxide tolerance levels.{{cite journal|vauthors=Raub JA, Mathieu-Nolf M, Hampson NB, Thom SR |title=Carbon monoxide poisoning-a public health perspective|journal=Toxicology|date=April 2000|pages=1–14|volume=145|issue=1|pmid=10771127|doi=10.1016/S0300-483X(99)00217-6|subscription=yes}} On average, exposures at 100 [[parts per million|ppm]] or greater is dangerous to human health. In the [[United States]], the [[Occupational Safety and Health Administration|OSHA]] limits long-term workplace exposure levels to less than 50 ppm averaged over an 8-hour period;{{cite web|url=https://www.osha.gov/OshDoc/data_General_Facts/carbonmonoxide-factsheet.pdf|title=OSHA Fact Sheet: Carbon Monoxide|accessdate=2009-09-14|publisher=United States National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090826181843/http://osha.gov/OshDoc/data_General_Facts/carbonmonoxide-factsheet.pdf|archivedate=2009-08-26|df=}} in addition, employees are to be removed from any [[confined space]] if an upper limit ("ceiling") of 100 ppm is reached.{{cite web |url=https://www.osha.gov/pls/oshaweb/owadisp.show_document?p_table=STANDARDS&p_id=10366 |title=Carbon monoxide – 29 CFR Part 1917 Section 1917.24 |accessdate=2013-05-27 |publisher=United States Department of Labor: Occupational Safety and Health Administration |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130523211713/http://www.osha.gov/pls/oshaweb/owadisp.show_document?p_table=STANDARDS&p_id=10366 |archivedate=2013-05-23 |df= }} Carbon monoxide exposure may lead to a significantly shorter [[life expectancy|life span]] due to [[heart]] damage.{{cite journal|vauthors=Henry CR, Satran D, Lindgren B, Adkinson C, Nicholson CI, Henry TD |title= Myocardial Injury and Long-term Mortality Following Moderate to Severe Carbon Monoxide Poisoning|journal=JAMA|date=January 2006|volume=295|pages=398–402|doi= 10.1001/jama.295.4.398|pmid=16434630|issue= 4|url= http://jama.ama-assn.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=16434630|format= Free full text}} The carbon monoxide tolerance level for any person is altered by several factors, including activity level, [[Ventilation (physiology)|rate of ventilation]], a pre-existing [[Cerebrum|cerebral]] or [[cardiovascular disease]], [[cardiac output]], [[anemia]], [[sickle cell disease]] and other hematological disorders, [[barometric pressure]], and [[metabolic rate]].{{cite web|url=http://www.lungusa.org/site/pp.asp?c=dvLUK9O0E&b=35375|title=Carbon Monoxide|accessdate=2009-09-14|publisher=American Lung Association|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080528195959/http://www.lungusa.org/site/pp.asp?c=dvLUK9O0E&b=35375 |archivedate =2008-05-28|deadurl=yes}}{{cite journal|author=Lipman GS|title=Carbon monoxide toxicity at high altitude|journal=Wilderness & Environmental Medicine|year=2006|pages=144–45|volume=17|issue=2|pmid=16805152|doi=10.1580/1080-6032(2006)17[144:CMTAHA]2.0.CO;2}}{{cite book|author=first draft prepared by Mr J. Raub.|title=Environmental Health Criteria 213 (Carbon Monoxide)|publisher=International Programme on Chemical Safety, World Health Organization|location=Geneva|year=1999|pages=|isbn=9241572132}} {| class="wikitable" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; border: none;" |+Effects of carbon monoxide in relation to the concentration in parts per million in the air:{{cite journal|author=Goldstein M|title=Carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=Journal of Emergency Nursing|volume=34|issue=6|pages=538–42|date=December 2008|pmid=19022078|doi=10.1016/j.jen.2007.11.014}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Struttmann T, Scheerer A, Prince TS, Goldstein LA |title=Unintentional carbon monoxide poisoning from an unlikely source|journal=The Journal of the American Board of Family Practice|volume=11|issue=6|pages=481–84|date=Nov 1998|pmid=9876005|doi=10.3122/jabfm.11.6.481}} !Concentration !Symptoms |- |35 ppm (0.0035%) |Headache and dizziness within six to eight hours of constant exposure |- |100 ppm (0.01%) |Slight headache in two to three hours |- |200 ppm (0.02%) |Slight headache within two to three hours; loss of judgment |- |400 ppm (0.04%) |Frontal headache within one to two hours |- |800 ppm (0.08%) | Dizziness, nausea, and convulsions within 45 min; insensible within 2 hours |- |1,600 ppm (0.16%) |Headache, [[tachycardia|increased heart rate]], dizziness, and nausea within 20 min; death in less than 2 hours |- |3,200 ppm (0.32%) |Headache, dizziness and nausea in five to ten minutes. Death within 30 minutes. |- |6,400 ppm (0.64%) |Headache and dizziness in one to two minutes. Convulsions, respiratory arrest, and death in less than 20 minutes. |- |12,800 ppm (1.28%) |Unconsciousness after 2–3 breaths. Death in less than three minutes. |- |} === Acute poisoning === [[File:CO toxicity symptoms (en).jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|CO toxicity symptoms]] The main manifestations of carbon monoxide poisoning develop in the organ systems most dependent on oxygen use, the [[central nervous system]] and the [[heart]]. The initial symptoms of acute carbon monoxide poisoning include [[headache]], [[nausea]], [[malaise]], and [[fatigue (medical)|fatigue]].{{cite journal|vauthors=Hardy KR, Thom SR |title=Pathophysiology and treatment of carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=Journal of Toxicology. Clinical Toxicology|year=1994|pages=613–29|volume=32|issue=6|pmid=7966524|doi=10.3109/15563659409017973}} These symptoms are often mistaken for a virus such as [[influenza]] or other illnesses such as [[food poisoning]] or [[gastroenteritis]].{{cite book |title=Goldfrank's toxicologic emergencies |publisher=McGraw-Hill |location=New York |year=2002 |edition=7th |pages=1689–1704 |chapter=Carbon Monoxide |isbn=0071360018 |author1=Lewis Goldfrank |author2=Neal Flomenbaum |author3=Neal Lewin |author4=Mary Ann Howland |author5=Robert Hoffman |author6=Lewis Nelson}} Headache is the most common symptom of acute carbon monoxide poisoning; it is often described as dull, frontal, and continuous.{{cite journal|vauthors=Hampson NB, Hampson LA |title=Characteristics of headache associated with acute carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=Headache|volume=42|issue=3|pages=220–23|date=March 2002|pmid=11903546|doi=10.1046/j.1526-4610.2002.02055.x}} Increasing exposure produces cardiac abnormalities including [[tachycardia|fast heart rate]], [[hypotension|low blood pressure]], and [[cardiac arrhythmia]];{{cite journal |vauthors=Tritapepe L, Macchiarelli G, Rocco M, Scopinaro F, Schillaci O, Martuscelli E, Motta PM |title=Functional and ultrastructural evidence of myocardial stunning after acute carbon monoxide poisoning |journal=Critical Care Medicine |volume=26 |issue=4 |pages=797–801 |date=April 1998 |pmid=9559621 |doi=10.1097/00003246-199804000-00034}} [[central nervous system]] symptoms include [[delirium]], [[hallucination]]s, [[dizziness]], [[ataxia|unsteady gait]], [[confusion]], [[seizures]], [[central nervous system depression]], [[unconsciousness]], [[respiratory arrest]], and [[death]].{{cite journal|author=Weaver LK|title=Clinical practice. Carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=The New England Journal of Medicine|volume=360|issue=12|pages=1217–25|date=March 2009|pmid=19297574|doi=10.1056/NEJMcp0808891|url=http://content.nejm.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=short&pmid=19297574&promo=ONFLNS19}} Less common symptoms of acute carbon monoxide poisoning include [[myocardial ischemia]], [[atrial fibrillation]], [[pneumonia]], [[pulmonary edema]], [[hyperglycemia|high blood sugar]], [[lactic acidosis]], [[rhabdomyolysis|muscle necrosis]], [[acute kidney failure]], [[skin lesion]]s, and visual and auditory problems.{{cite journal|author=Choi IS|title=Carbon monoxide poisoning: systemic manifestations and complications|journal=Journal of Korean Medical Science|date=June 2001|pages=253–61|volume=16|issue=3|pmid=11410684|url=http://jkms.org/DOIx.php?id=10.3346/jkms.2001.16.3.253|doi-access=free |doi=10.3346/jkms.2001.16.3.253|pmc=3054741}}{{cite journal |author=Marius-Nunez AL |title=Myocardial infarction with normal coronary arteries after acute exposure to carbon monoxide |journal=Chest |volume=97 |issue=2 |pages=491–94 |date=February 1990 |pmid=2298080 |doi=10.1378/chest.97.2.491}}{{cite journal |vauthors=Gandini C, Castoldi AF, Candura SM, Locatelli C, Butera R, Priori S, Manzo L |title=Carbon monoxide cardiotoxicity |journal=Journal of Toxicology. Clinical Toxicology |volume=39 |issue=1 |pages=35–44 |year=2001 |pmid=11327225 |doi=10.1081/CLT-100102878}}{{cite journal |author=Sokal JA |title=The effect of exposure duration on the blood level of glucose, pyruvate and lactate in acute carbon monoxide intoxication in man |journal=Journal of Applied Toxicology: JAT |volume=5 |issue=6 |pages=395–97 |date=December 1985 |pmid=4078220 |doi=10.1002/jat.2550050611}} One of the major concerns following acute carbon monoxide poisoning is the severe delayed neurological manifestations that may occur. Problems may include difficulty with higher intellectual functions, [[memory loss|short-term memory loss]], [[dementia]], [[amnesia]], [[psychosis]], irritability, a strange [[gait]], speech disturbances, [[Parkinson's disease]]-like syndromes, [[cortical blindness]], and a [[Depression (mood)|depressed mood]].{{cite journal|author=Choi IS|title=Delayed neurologic sequelae in carbon monoxide intoxication|journal=Archives of Neurology|volume=40|issue=7|pages=433–35|date=July 1983|pmid=6860181|doi=10.1001/archneur.1983.04050070063016|url=http://archneur.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=582033|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120819232412/http://archneur.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=582033|archivedate=2012-08-19|df=}} Depression may occur in those who did not have pre-existing depression.{{cite journal|vauthors=Roohi F, Kula RW, Mehta N |title=Twenty-nine years after carbon monoxide intoxication|journal=Clinical Neurology and Neurosurgery|date=July 2001|pages=92–95|volume=103|issue=2|pmid=11516551|doi=10.1016/S0303-8467(01)00119-6}} These delayed neurological [[sequelae]] may occur in up to 50% of poisoned people after 2 to 40 days. It is difficult to predict who will develop delayed sequelae; however, advanced age, loss of consciousness while poisoned, and initial neurological abnormalities may increase the chance of developing delayed symptoms.{{cite journal|vauthors=Myers RA, Snyder SK, Emhoff TA |title=Subacute sequelae of carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=Annals of Emergency Medicine|volume=14|issue=12|pages=1163–67|date=December 1985|pmid=4061987|doi=10.1016/S0196-0644(85)81022-2}} One classic sign of carbon monoxide poisoning is more often seen in the dead rather than the living – people have been described as looking red-cheeked and healthy (see below). However, since this "cherry-red" appearance is common only in the deceased, and is unusual in living people, it is not considered a useful diagnostic sign in clinical medicine. In pathological (autopsy) examination the ruddy appearance of carbon monoxide poisoning is notable because unembalmed dead persons are normally bluish and pale, whereas dead carbon-monoxide poisoned persons may simply appear unusually lifelike in coloration.{{cite journal|author=Simini B|title=Cherry-red discolouration in carbon monoxide poisoning |journal=Lancet| volume=352|issue=9134| page=1154|date=October 1998|pmid=9798630|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(05)79807-X}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Brooks DE, Lin E, Ahktar J |title=What is cherry red, and who cares?|journal= [[The Journal of Emergency Medicine]] |date=February 2002|pages=213–14|volume=22|issue=2|pmid=11858933|doi=10.1016/S0736-4679(01)00469-3}} The colorant effect of carbon monoxide in such postmortem circumstances is thus analogous to its use as a red colorant in the commercial meat-packing industry. === Chronic poisoning === Chronic exposure to relatively low levels of carbon monoxide may cause persistent headaches, lightheadedness, depression, confusion, memory loss, nausea, hearing disorders and vomiting.{{cite journal|vauthors=Fawcett TA, Moon RE, Fracica PJ, Mebane GY, Theil DR, Piantadosi CA |title=Warehouse workers' headache. Carbon monoxide poisoning from propane-fueled forklifts|journal=Journal of Occupational Medicine|date=January 1992|pages=12–15|volume=34|issue=1|pmid=1552375}}{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/939229378|title=The Nordic Expert Group for criteria documentation of health risks from chemicals. 142, Occupational exposure to chemicals and hearing impairment|last=Johnson|first= Ann-Christin|date=2009|publisher=University of Gothenburg|others=Morata, Thais C.|isbn=978-9185971213|location=Göteborg|oclc=939229378}} It is unknown whether low-level chronic exposure may cause permanent neurological damage. Typically, upon removal from exposure to carbon monoxide, symptoms usually resolve themselves, unless there has been an episode of severe acute poisoning. However, one case noted permanent memory loss and learning problems after a 3-year exposure to relatively low levels of carbon monoxide from a faulty furnace.{{cite journal|author=Ryan CM|title=Memory disturbances following chronic, low-level carbon monoxide exposure|journal=Archives of Clinical Neuropsychology|year=1990|pages=59–67|volume=5|issue=1|pmid=14589544|doi=10.1016/0887-6177(90)90007-C}} Chronic exposure may worsen cardiovascular symptoms in some people. Chronic carbon monoxide exposure might increase the risk of developing atherosclerosis.{{cite journal|last=Davutoglu|first=V|title=Chronic carbon monoxide exposure is associated with the increases in carotid intima-media thickness and C-reactive protein level|journal=Tohoku J Exp Med|date=November 2009|volume=219|issue=3|pages=201–06|doi=10.1620/tjem.219.201|pmid=19851048}}{{cite book|last=Shephard|first=Roy|title=Carbon Monoxide The Silent Killer|year=1983|publisher=Charles C Thomas|location=Springfield Illinois|pages=93–96}} Long-term exposures to carbon monoxide present the greatest risk to persons with [[coronary heart disease]] and in females who are pregnant.{{cite journal|doi=10.1056/NEJM198911233212102|vauthors=Allred EN, Bleecker ER, Chaitman BR, Dahms TE, Gottlieb SO, Hackney JD, Pagano M, Selvester RH, Walden SM, Warren J |title=Short-term effects of carbon monoxide exposure on the exercise performance of subjects with coronary artery disease|journal=The New England Journal of Medicine|date=Nov 1989|pages=1426–32|volume=321|issue=21|pmid=2682242|url=}} In experimental animals, carbon monoxide appears to worsen noise-induced hearing loss at noise exposure conditions that would have limited effects on hearing otherwise.{{cite journal|last1=Fechter|first1=LD|title=Promotion of noise-induced hearing loss by chemical contaminants|journal=Journal of toxicology and environmental health. Part A|date=2004|volume=67|issue=8–10|pages=727–40|doi=10.1080/15287390490428206|pmid=15192865}} In humans, hearing loss has been reported following carbon monoxide poisoning. Unlike the findings in animal studies, noise exposure was not a necessary factor for the auditory problems to occur. == Causes == {| class="wikitable" style = "float: right; margin-left:15px; text-align:center" !Concentration !Source |- |0.1 ppm |Natural atmosphere level ([[MOPITT]]){{cite book | author =Committee on Medical and Biological Effects of Environmental Pollutants | title = Carbon Monoxide | publisher = National Academy of Sciences| location = Washington, DC| year =1977 | page = 29| doi = | isbn =0309026318 }} |- |0.5 to 5 ppm |Average level in homes{{cite web| title =An Introduction to Indoor Air Quality: Carbon Monoxide (CO)| author =Green W| publisher =United States Environmental Protection Agency| url =http://www.epa.gov/iaq/co.html| doi =| accessdate =2008-12-16| deadurl =no| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20081218112704/http://www.epa.gov/iaq/co.html| archivedate =2008-12-18| df =}} |- |5 to 15 ppm |Near properly adjusted gas stoves in homes |- |100 to 200 ppm |Exhaust from automobiles in the [[Mexico City]] central area{{cite book | last = Singer | first = Siegfried Fred | title = The Changing Global Environment | publisher = [[D. Reidel]] Publishing Company| location = Dordrecht| page = 90| doi = | isbn = }} |- |5,000 ppm |Exhaust from a home wood fire{{cite web | title =What Do Carbon Monoxide Levels Mean? | author =Gosink T | work =Alaska Science Forum | publisher =Geophysical Institute, University of Alaska Fairbanks | date =1983-01-28 | url =http://www.gi.alaska.edu/ScienceForum/ASF5/588.html | accessdate =2008-12-16 | deadurl =no | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20081225113654/http://www.gi.alaska.edu/ScienceForum/ASF5/588.html | archivedate =2008-12-25 | df = }} |- |7,000 ppm |Undiluted warm car exhaust without a [[catalytic converter]] |- |30,000 ppm |[[Afterdamp]] following an explosion in a coal mine{{citation | last = Roberts | first = H C W | title = Report on the causes of, and circumstances attending, the explosion which occurred at Easington Colliery, County Durham, on the 29th May, 1951. | date = September 1952 | publisher = Her Majesty's Stationery Office | publication-place = London | series = Cmd 8646 | format = PDF | url = http://hdl.handle.net/1842/5365 | page = 39 }} |} Carbon monoxide is a product of combustion of organic matter under conditions of restricted oxygen supply, which prevents complete [[oxidation]] to [[carbon dioxide]] (CO2). Sources of carbon monoxide include cigarette smoke, house fires, faulty [[furnace]]s, heaters, [[wood-burning stove]]s,{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/man-died-from-carbon-monoxide-poisoning-after-using-heat-beads-in-greystanes-home-20150718-gif8d8.html|title=Man died from carbon monoxide poisoning after using 'heat beads' in Greystanes home|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150719131747/http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/man-died-from-carbon-monoxide-poisoning-after-using-heat-beads-in-greystanes-home-20150718-gif8d8.html|archivedate=2015-07-19|df=}} [[internal combustion]] [[vehicle exhaust]], [[electrical generator]]s, [[propane]]-fueled equipment such as portable stoves, and gasoline-powered tools such as [[leaf blower]]s, lawn mowers, high-pressure washers, concrete cutting saws, power trowels, and welders.{{cite journal|vauthors=Marc B, Bouchez-Buvry A, Wepierre JL, Boniol L, Vaquero P, Garnier M |title=Carbon-monoxide poisoning in young drug addicts due to indoor use of a gasoline-powered generator|journal=Journal of Clinical Forensic Medicine|volume=8|issue=2|pages=54–56|date=June 2001|pmid=16083675|doi=10.1054/jcfm.2001.0474}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Johnson C, Moran J, Paine S, Anderson H, Breysse P |title=Abatement of toxic levels of carbon monoxide in Seattle ice-skating rinks|journal=American Journal of Public Health|volume=65|issue=10|pages=1087–90|date=October 1975|pmid=1163706|doi=10.2105/AJPH.65.10.1087|pmc=1776025}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/co/|title=NIOSH Carbon Monoxide Hazards from Small Gasoline Powered Engines|accessdate=2007-10-15|publisher=United States National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071029032750/http://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/co/|archivedate=2007-10-29|df=}}{{cite journal |vauthors=Fife CE, Smith LA, Maus EA, McCarthy JJ, Koehler MZ, Hawkins T, Hampson NB |title=Dying to play video games: carbon monoxide poisoning from electrical generators used after hurricane Ike |journal=Pediatrics |volume=123 |issue=6 |pages=e1035–38 |date=June 2009 |pmid=19482736 |doi=10.1542/peds.2008-3273}}{{cite report|author=Emmerich, SJ|date=July 2011|title=Measured CO Concentrations at NIST IAQ Test House from Operation of Portable Electric Generators in Attached Garage – Interim Report|url=https://www.nist.gov/manuscript-publication-search.cfm?pub_id=907771|publisher=United States National Institute of Standards and Technology|accessdate=2012-04-18|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130224044200/http://nist.gov/manuscript-publication-search.cfm?pub_id=907771|archivedate=2013-02-24|df=}} Exposure typically occurs when equipment is used in buildings or semi-enclosed spaces. Riding in the back of [[pickup trucks]] has led to poisoning in children.{{cite journal|vauthors=Hampson NB, Norkool DM |title=Carbon monoxide poisoning in children riding in the back of pickup trucks|journal=JAMA|volume=267|issue=4|pages=538–40|date=January 1992|pmid=1370334|doi=10.1001/jama.267.4.538|url=}} Idling automobiles with the exhaust pipe blocked by snow has led to the poisoning of car occupants.{{cite journal|author=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)|title=Carbon monoxide poisonings associated with snow-obstructed vehicle exhaust systems—Philadelphia and New York City, January 1996|journal=MMWR. Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report|volume=45|issue=1|pages=1–3|date=January 1996|pmid=8531914|url=https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00039929.htm|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170624015949/https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00039929.htm|archivedate=2017-06-24|df=}} Any perforation between the exhaust manifold and shroud can result in exhaust gases reaching the cabin. Generators and propulsion engines on boats, especially houseboats, has resulted in fatal carbon monoxide exposures.{{cite journal |author=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)|title=Houseboat-associated carbon monoxide poisonings on Lake Powell—Arizona and Utah, 2000|journal=MMWR. Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report|volume=49|issue=49|pages=1105–1108|date=December 2000|pmid=11917924|url=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/coboating/|title=NIOSH Carbon Monoxide Dangers in Boating|accessdate=2007-10-15|publisher=United States National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071013113132/http://cdc.gov/niosh/topics/coboating/|archivedate=2007-10-13|df=}} Poisoning may also occur following the use of a self-contained underwater breathing apparatus (SCUBA) due to faulty [[diving air compressor]]s.{{cite journal|vauthors=Austin CC, Ecobichon DJ, Dussault G, Tirado C |title=Carbon monoxide and water vapor contamination of compressed breathing air for firefighters and divers|journal=Journal of Toxicology and Environmental Health|volume=52|issue=5|pages=403–23|date=December 1997|pmid=9388533|doi=10.1080/00984109708984073}} In caves carbon monoxide can build up in enclosed chambers due to the presence of decomposing organic matter.{{cite book |last=Dart| first= RC |chapter= |title=Medical toxicology |publisher=Williams & Wilkins| location=Philadelphia |year=2004|page=1169| isbn=0781728452}} In coal mines incomplete combustion may occur during explosions resulting in the production of [[afterdamp]]. The gas is up to 3% CO and may be fatal after just a single breath. Following an explosion in a colliery, adjacent interconnected mines may become dangerous due to the afterdamp leaking from mine to mine. Such an incident followed the [[Trimdon Grange]] explosion which killed men in the [[Kelloe]] mine.{{citation | url = http://www.healeyhero.co.uk/rescue/pits/Trimdon_Grange/Trimdon3.htm#top | title = Trimdon Grange, Durham. 16th February 1882 | accessdate = 22 May 2012 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170330072644/http://www.healeyhero.co.uk/rescue/pits/Trimdon_Grange/Trimdon3.htm#top | archivedate = 30 March 2017 | df = }} Another source of poisoning is exposure to the organic solvent [[dichloromethane]], found in some [[paint stripper]]s,{{cite journal|last=van Veen|first=MP|author2=Fortezza F |author3=Spaans E |author4=Mensinga TT |title=Non-professional paint stripping, model prediction and experimental validation of indoor dichloromethane levels|journal=Indoor Air|year=2002|volume=12|issue=2|pages=92–97|doi=10.1034/j.1600-0668.2002.01109.x|pmid=12216472}} as the metabolism of dichloromethane produces carbon monoxide.{{cite journal|vauthors=Kubic VL, Anders MW |title=Metabolism of dihalomethanes to carbon monoxide. II. In vitro studies|journal=Drug Metabolism and Disposition|date=March 1975|pages=104–12|volume=3|issue=2|pmid=236156}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Dueñas A, Felipe S, Ruiz-Mambrilla M, Martín-Escudero JC, García-Calvo C |title=CO poisoning caused by inhalation of CH3Cl contained in personal defense spray|journal=The American Journal of Emergency Medicine|volume=18|issue=1|pages=120–21|date=January 2000|pmid=10674554|doi=10.1016/S0735-6757(00)90070-6}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Varon J, Marik PE, Fromm RE, Gueler A |title=Carbon monoxide poisoning: A review for clinicians|journal= [[The Journal of Emergency Medicine]] |year=1999|pages=87–93|volume=17|issue=1|pmid=9950394|doi=10.1016/S0736-4679(98)00128-0}} == Pathophysiology == The precise mechanisms by which the effects of carbon monoxide are induced upon bodily systems, are complex and not yet fully understood. Known mechanisms include carbon monoxide binding to [[hemoglobin]], [[myoglobin]] and [[mitochondrial]] [[cytochrome oxidase]] and restricting oxygen supply, and carbon monoxide causing [[brain]] [[lipid peroxidation]].{{cite journal|author=Bateman DN|title=Carbon Monoxide|journal=Medicine|volume=31|issue=10|page=233|date=October 2003|doi=10.1383/medc.31.10.41.27810}} === Hemoglobin === [[File:Hemoglobin saturation curve.svg|thumb|Carbon monoxide shifts the oxygen-dissociation curve to the left.]] Carbon monoxide has a higher diffusion coefficient compared to oxygen, and the only enzyme in the human body that produces carbon monoxide is [[heme oxygenase]], which is located in all cells and breaks down [[heme]]. Under normal conditions, carbon monoxide levels in the [[Blood plasma|plasma]] are approximately 0 [[Millimeter of mercury|mmHg]] because it has a higher diffusion coefficient and the body easily gets rid of any CO made.{{cite book|title=USMLE Step 1 Lecture Notes: Physiology|year=2011|author=Dunn, Robert B.|author2=Kudrath, W. |author3=Passo, SS |author4=Wilson, LB|pages=167–68|chapter=7-3}} When CO is not ventilated it binds to hemoglobin, which is the principal oxygen-carrying compound in blood; this produces a compound known as [[carboxyhemoglobin]]. The traditional belief is that carbon monoxide toxicity arises from the formation of carboxyhemoglobin, which decreases the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood and inhibits the transport, delivery, and utilization of oxygen by the body. The affinity between hemoglobin and carbon monoxide is approximately 230 times stronger than the affinity between hemoglobin and oxygen so hemoglobin binds to carbon monoxide in preference to oxygen.{{cite journal|vauthors=Townsend CL, Maynard RL |title=Effects on health of prolonged exposure to low concentrations of carbon monoxide|journal=Occupational and Environmental Medicine|volume=59|issue=10|pages=708–11|date=October 2002|pmid=12356933|pmc=1740215|doi=10.1136/oem.59.10.708|url=}}{{cite journal|author=Haldane J|title=The action of carbonic oxide on man|journal=The Journal of Physiology|year=1895|pages=430–62|volume=18|url=http://jp.physoc.org/content/18/5-6/430.full.pdf|pmid=16992272|issue=5–6|pmc=1514663|doi=10.1113/jphysiol.1895.sp000578|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708152937/http://jp.physoc.org/content/18/5-6/430.full.pdf|archivedate=2011-07-08|df=}} Hemoglobin is a [[Tetrameric protein|tetramer]] with four oxygen binding sites. The binding of carbon monoxide at one of these sites increases the oxygen affinity of the remaining three sites, which causes the hemoglobin molecule to retain oxygen that would otherwise be delivered to the tissue.{{cite journal|vauthors=Gorman D, Drewry A, Huang YL, Sames C |title=The clinical toxicology of carbon monoxide|journal=Toxicology|date=May 2003|pages=25–38|volume=187|issue=1|pmid=12679050|doi=10.1016/S0300-483X(03)00005-2}} This situation is described as carbon monoxide shifting the [[oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve|oxygen dissociation curve]] to the left. Because of the increased affinity between hemoglobin and oxygen during carbon monoxide poisoning, little oxygen will actually be released in the tissues. This causes hypoxic tissue injury. Hemoglobin acquires a bright red color when converted into carboxyhemoglobin, so poisoned cadavers and even commercial meats treated with carbon monoxide acquire an unnatural reddish hue. === Myoglobin === Carbon monoxide also binds to the [[hemeprotein]] [[myoglobin]]. It has a high affinity for myoglobin, about 60 times greater than that of oxygen. Carbon monoxide bound to myoglobin may impair its ability to utilize oxygen. This causes reduced [[cardiac output]] and [[hypotension]], which may result in [[brain ischemia]]. A delayed return of symptoms have been reported. This results following a recurrence of increased carboxyhemoglobin levels; this effect may be due to a late release of carbon monoxide from myoglobin, which subsequently binds to hemoglobin. === Cytochrome oxidase === Another mechanism involves effects on the mitochondrial respiratory enzyme chain that is responsible for effective tissue utilization of oxygen. Carbon monoxide binds to [[cytochrome oxidase]] with less affinity than oxygen, so it is possible that it requires significant intracellular hypoxia before binding.{{cite journal |vauthors=Gorman DF, Runciman WB |title=Carbon monoxide poisoning |journal=Anaesthesia and Intensive Care |volume=19 |issue=4 |pages=506–11 |date=November 1991 |pmid=1750629 |doi= |url=}} This binding interferes with aerobic metabolism and efficient [[adenosine triphosphate]] synthesis. Cells respond by switching to [[anaerobic metabolism]], causing [[Hypoxia (medical)|anoxia]], [[lactic acidosis]], and eventual cell death.{{cite journal|vauthors=Alonso JR, Cardellach F, Lopez S, Casademont J, Miro O |title=Carbon monoxide specifically inhibits cytochrome c oxidase of human mitochondrial respiratory chain|journal=Pharmacology & Toxicology|date=September 2003|pages=142–46|volume=93|issue=3|pmid=12969439|doi=10.1034/j.1600-0773.2003.930306.x}} The rate of [[Dissociation (chemistry)|dissociation]] between carbon monoxide and cytochrome oxidase is slow, causing a relatively prolonged impairment of [[oxidative metabolism]]. === Central nervous system effects === The mechanism that is thought to have a significant influence on delayed effects involves formed blood cells and chemical mediators, which cause brain [[lipid peroxidation]] (degradation of unsaturated fatty acids). Carbon monoxide causes [[endothelial]] cell and platelet release of [[nitric oxide]], and the formation of [[oxygen free radicals]] including [[peroxynitrite]]. In the brain this causes further mitochondrial dysfunction, [[capillary]] leakage, [[leukocyte]] sequestration, and [[apoptosis]].{{cite journal|author=Blumenthal I|title=Carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine|date=June 2001|pages=270–72|volume=94|issue=6|pmid=11387414|url=http://www.jrsm.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=11387414|format=Free full text|pmc=1281520|doi=10.1177/014107680109400604}} The result of these effects is [[lipid peroxidation]], which causes delayed reversible [[Demyelinating disease|demyelinization]] of [[white matter]] in the central nervous system known as [[Grinker myelinopathy]], which can lead to [[edema]] and [[necrosis]] within the brain. This brain damage occurs mainly during the recovery period. This may result in cognitive defects, especially affecting memory and learning, and movement disorders. These disorders are typically related to damage to the cerebral [[white matter]] and [[basal ganglia]].{{cite journal|vauthors=Fan HC, Wang AC, Lo CP, Chang KP, Chen SJ |title=Damage of cerebellar white matter due to carbon monoxide poisoning: a case report|journal=[[The American Journal of Emergency Medicine]]|volume=27|issue=6|pages=757.e5–e7|date=July 2009|pmid=19751650|doi=10.1016/j.ajem.2008.10.021}} Hallmark pathological changes following poisoning are bilateral necrosis of the white matter, [[globus pallidus]], [[cerebellum]], [[hippocampus]] and the [[cerebral cortex]].{{cite journal|vauthors=Prockop LD, Chichkova RI |title=Carbon monoxide intoxication: an updated review|journal=Journal of the Neurological Sciences|date=Nov 2007|pages=122–30|volume=262|issue=1–2|pmid=17720201|doi=10.1016/j.jns.2007.06.037}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Fukuhara M, Abe I, Matsumura K, Kaseda S, Yamashita Y, Shida K, Kawashima H, Fujishima M |title=Circadian variations of blood pressure in patients with sequelae of carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=American Journal of Hypertension |volume=9|issue=4 Part 1|pages=300–05|date=April 1996|pmid=8722431|doi=10.1016/0895-7061(95)00342-8}} === Pregnancy === Carbon monoxide poisoning in pregnant women may cause severe adverse [[fetus|fetal]] effects. Poisoning causes fetal tissue [[Hypoxia (medical)|hypoxia]] by decreasing the release of maternal oxygen to the fetus. Carbon monoxide also crosses the [[placenta]] and combines with [[fetal hemoglobin]], causing more direct fetal tissue hypoxia. Additionally, fetal hemoglobin has a 10 to 15% higher affinity for carbon monoxide than adult hemoglobin, causing more severe poisoning in the fetus than in the adult. Elimination of carbon monoxide is slower in the fetus, leading to an accumulation of the toxic chemical.{{cite journal|vauthors=Greingor JL, Tosi JM, Ruhlmann S, Aussedat M |title=Acute carbon monoxide intoxication during pregnancy. One case report and review of the literature|journal=Emergency Medicine Journal|volume=18|issue=5|pages=399–401|date=September 2001|pmid=11559621|pmc=1725677|doi=10.1136/emj.18.5.399|url=http://emj.bmj.com/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=11559621}} The level of fetal morbidity and mortality in acute carbon monoxide poisoning is significant, so despite mild maternal poisoning or following maternal recovery, severe fetal poisoning or death may still occur.{{cite journal|vauthors=Farrow JR, Davis GJ, Roy TM, McCloud LC, Nichols GR |title=Fetal death due to nonlethal maternal carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=Journal of Forensic Sciences|volume=35|issue=6|pages=1448–52|date=November 1990|pmid=2262778}} == Diagnosis == [[File:Co monitor.JPG|thumb|Finger tip [[carboxyhemoglobin]] saturation monitor (SpCO%). Note: This is not the same as a pulse oximeter (SpO2%), although some models (such as this one) do measure both the oxygen and carbon monoxide saturation.]] [[File:Breath CO Monitor.jpg|thumb|Breath CO monitor displaying carbon monoxide concentration of an exhaled breath sample (in ppm) with its corresponding percent concentration of carboxyhemoglobin.]] As many symptoms of carbon monoxide poisoning also occur with many other types of poisonings and infections (such as the flu), the diagnosis is often difficult.{{cite journal|vauthors=Bennetto L, Powter L, Scolding NJ |title=Accidental carbon monoxide poisoning presenting without a history of exposure: A case report|journal=Journal of Medical Case Reports|volume=2|issue=1|page=118|date=April 2008|pmid=18430228|doi=10.1186/1752-1947-2-118|pmc=2390579}} A history of potential carbon monoxide exposure, such as being exposed to a residential fire, may suggest poisoning, but the diagnosis is confirmed by measuring the levels of carbon monoxide in the blood. This can be determined by measuring the amount of [[carboxyhemoglobin]] compared to the amount of [[hemoglobin]] in the blood. The ratio of carboxyhemoglobin to hemoglobin molecules in an average person may be up to 5%, although cigarette smokers who smoke two packs per day may have levels up to 9%.{{cite book|veditors=Ford MD, Delaney KA, Ling LJ, Erickson T |title=Clinical Toxicology|year=2001|page=1046|publisher=WB Saunders Company|isbn=0721654851}} In symptomatic poisoned people they are often in the 10–30% range, while persons who die may have postmortem blood levels of 30–90%.Sato K, Tamaki K, Hattori H, et al. Determination of total hemoglobin in forensic blood samples with special reference to carboxyhemoglobin analysis. For. Sci. Int. 48: 89–96, 1990.R. Baselt, ''Disposition of Toxic Drugs and Chemicals in Man'', 8th edition, Biomedical Publications, Foster City, CA, 2008, pp. 237–41. As people may continue to experience significant symptoms of CO poisoning long after their blood carboxyhemoglobin concentration has returned to normal, presenting to examination with a normal carboxyhemoglobin level (which may happen in late states of poisoning) does not rule out poisoning.{{cite journal|vauthors=Keleş A, Demircan A, Kurtoğlu G |title=Carbon monoxide poisoning: how many patients do we miss?|journal=European Journal of Emergency Medicine |volume=15|issue=3|pages=154–57|date=June 2008|pmid=18460956|doi=10.1097/MEJ.0b013e3282efd519}} ===Measuring=== Carbon monoxide may be quantitated in blood using [[spectrophotometry|spectrophotometric]] methods or [[chromatography|chromatographic techniques]] in order to confirm a diagnosis of poisoning in a person or to assist in the forensic investigation of a case of fatal exposure. A [[CO-oximeter]] can be used to determine carboxyhemoglobin levels.{{cite journal|vauthors=Rodkey FL, Hill TA, Pitts LL, Robertson RF |title=Spectrophotometric measurement of carboxyhemoglobin and methemoglobin in blood|journal=Clinical Chemistry|volume=25|issue=8|pages=1388–93|date=August 1979|pmid=455674|doi=|url=http://www.clinchem.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=455674|accessdate=2009-07-17}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Rees PJ, Chilvers C, Clark TJ |title=Evaluation of methods used to estimate inhaled dose of carbon monoxide|journal=Thorax|volume=35|issue=1|pages=47–51|date=January 1980|pmid=7361284|pmc=471219|doi= 10.1136/thx.35.1.47|url=http://thorax.bmj.com/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=7361284}} Pulse [[CO-oximeter]]s estimate carboxyhemoglobin with a non-invasive finger clip similar to a [[pulse oximeter]].{{cite journal|vauthors=Coulange M, Barthelemy A, Hug F, Thierry AL, De Haro L|title=Reliability of new pulse CO-oximeter in victims of carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=Undersea & Hyperbaric Medicine|volume=35|issue=2|pages=107–11|date=March 2008|pmid=18500075|doi=|url=http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/8084|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110625021038/http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/8084|archivedate=2011-06-25|df=}} These devices function by passing various wavelengths of light through the fingertip and measuring the light absorption of the different types of hemoglobin in the capillaries.{{Cite journal|last = Maisel | first = William | authorlink = |author2=Roger J. Lewis | title = Noninvasive Measurement of Carboxyhemoglobin: How Accurate is Accurate Enough? | journal = Annals of Emergency Medicine | volume = 56 | issue = 4 | pages = 389–91 | publisher = | location = Boston, MA | year = 2010 | doi=10.1016/j.annemergmed.2010.05.025}} The use of a regular [[pulse oximeter]] is not effective in the diagnosis of carbon monoxide poisoning as people with carbon monoxide poisoning may have a normal [[oxygen saturation]] level on a pulse oximeter.{{cite journal|vauthors=Vegfors M, Lennmarken C |title=Carboxyhaemoglobinaemia and pulse oximetry|journal=British Journal of Anaesthesia|volume=66|issue=5|pages=625–626|date=May 1991|pmid=2031826|doi=10.1093/bja/66.5.625}} This is due to the carboxyhemoglobin being misrepresented as oxyhemoglobin.{{cite journal|vauthors=Barker SJ, Tremper KK |title=The effect of carbon monoxide inhalation on pulse oximetry and transcutaneous PO2|journal=Anesthesiology|volume=66|issue=5|pages=677–79|date=May 1987|pmid=3578881|doi=10.1097/00000542-198705000-00014}} [[Carbon monoxide breath monitor|Breath CO monitoring]] offers an alternative to pulse CO-oximetry. Carboxyhemoglobin levels have been shown to have a strong correlation with breath CO concentration.{{cite journal|first=M.|last=Jarvis|year=1986|title=Low cost carbon monoxide monitors in smoking assessment|journal=Thorax|pages=886–87|doi=10.1136/thx.41.11.886|volume=41|issue=11|pmc=460516}}{{cite journal|first=Nicholas|last=Wald|year=1981|title=Carbon monoxide in breath in relation to smoking and carboxyhaemoglobin levels|journal=Thorax|pages=366–69|doi=10.1136/thx.36.5.366|pmid=7314006|pmc=471511|volume=36|issue=5}} However, many of these devices require the user to inhale deeply and hold their breath to allow the CO in the blood to escape into the lung before the measurement can be made. As this is not possible in people who are unresponsive, these devices may not appropriate for use in on-scene emergency care detection of CO poisoning. === Differential diagnosis === There are many conditions to be considered in the differential diagnosis of carbon monoxide poisoning.{{cite journal |vauthors=Kao LW, Nañagas KA |title=Toxicity associated with carbon monoxide |journal=Clinics in Laboratory Medicine |volume=26 |issue=1 |pages=99–125 |date=March 2006 |pmid=16567227 |doi=10.1016/j.cll.2006.01.005}}{{cite web | last =Shochat | first =Guy N | title =Toxicity, Carbon Monoxide | publisher =[[emedicine]] | date =17 February 2009 | url =http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/819987-overview | accessdate =2009-04-27 | deadurl =no | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20090309072832/http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/819987-overview | archivedate =9 March 2009 | df = }} The earliest symptoms, especially from low level exposures, are often non-specific and readily confused with other illnesses, typically [[influenza|flu-like viral syndromes]], [[clinical depression|depression]], [[chronic fatigue syndrome]], [[chest pain]], and [[migraine]] or other headaches.{{cite journal | vauthors=Ilano AL, Raffin TA | title=Management of carbon monoxide poisoning | journal=Chest | date=Jan 1990 | pages=165–69 | volume=97 | issue=1 | pmid=2403894 | doi=10.1378/chest.97.1.165 }} Carbon monoxide has been called a "great mimicker" due to the presentation of poisoning being diverse and nonspecific. Other conditions included in the differential diagnosis include [[acute respiratory distress syndrome]], [[altitude sickness]], [[lactic acidosis]], [[diabetic ketoacidosis]], [[meningitis]], [[methemoglobinemia]], or [[Opioid overdose|opioid]] or toxic alcohol poisoning. == Prevention == [[File:CO DETECTOR (cropped).JPG|thumb|Carbon monoxide detector connected to a North American power outlet]] === Detectors === [[File:COMonitor.jpg|thumb|A carbon monoxide monitor clipped to the uniform of a paramedic]] Prevention remains a vital [[public health]] issue, requiring public education on the safe operation of appliances, heaters, fireplaces, and internal-combustion engines, as well as increased emphasis on the installation of [[carbon monoxide detector]]s.{{cite journal|vauthors=Ernst A, Zibrak JD |title=Carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=The New England Journal of Medicine|volume=339|issue=22|pages=1603–08|date=November 1998|pmid=9828249|doi=10.1056/NEJM199811263392206|url=http://content.nejm.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=short&pmid=9828249&promo=ONFLNS19}} Carbon monoxide is tasteless and odourless, and therefore can not be detected by visual cues or smell.{{cite journal |title=Compressed breathing air – the potential for evil from within |vauthors=Millar IL, Mouldey PG |year=2008 |volume=38 |issue=2 |pages=145–51 |journal=Diving and Hyperbaric Medicine |publisher=[[South Pacific Underwater Medicine Society]] |url=http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/7964 |accessdate=2013-04-14 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101225063245/http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/7964 |archivedate=2010-12-25 |df= |pmid=22692708 }} The United States [[Consumer Product Safety Commission]] has stated, "carbon monoxide detectors are as important to home safety as smoke detectors are," and recommends each home have at least one carbon monoxide detector, and preferably one on each level of the building. These devices, which are relatively inexpensive and widely available, are either battery- or AC-powered, with or without battery backup.{{cite web|last=Lipinski|first=Edward R|title=Keeping Watch on Carbon Monoxide|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=February 14, 1999|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/02/14/nyregion/home-clinic-keeping-watch-on-carbon-monoxide.html|accessdate=2009-09-09|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110623100533/http://www.nytimes.com/1999/02/14/nyregion/home-clinic-keeping-watch-on-carbon-monoxide.html|archivedate=June 23, 2011|df=}} In buildings, carbon monoxide detectors are usually installed around heaters and other equipment. If a relatively high level of carbon monoxide is detected, the device sounds an alarm, giving people the chance to evacuate and ventilate the building.{{cite journal |vauthors=Krenzelok EP, Roth R, Full R |title=Carbon monoxide ... the silent killer with an audible solution |journal=The American Journal of Emergency Medicine |date=September 1996 |pages=484–86 |volume=14 |issue=5 |pmid=8765117 |doi=10.1016/S0735-6757(96)90159-X }}{{cite journal |vauthors=Yoon SS, Macdonald SC, Parrish RG |title=Deaths from unintentional carbon monoxide poisoning and potential for prevention with carbon monoxide detectors |journal=JAMA |date=March 1998 |pages=685–87 |volume=279 |issue=9 |pmid=9496987 |doi=10.1001/jama.279.9.685 }} Unlike [[smoke detector]]s, carbon monoxide detectors do not need to be placed near ceiling level. The use of carbon monoxide detectors has been standardized in many areas. In the US, NFPA 720-2009,{{cite book|title=NFPA 720: Standard for the Installation of Carbon Monoxide (CO) Detection and Warning Equipment|publisher=National Fire Protection Agency|location=Quincy, MA|year=2009|pages=|isbn=}} the carbon monoxide detector guidelines published by the [[National Fire Protection Association]], mandates the placement of carbon monoxide detectors/alarms on every level of the residence, including the basement, in addition to outside sleeping areas. In new homes, AC-powered detectors must have battery backup and be interconnected to ensure early warning of occupants at all levels.
