NFPA 720-2009 is the first national carbon monoxide standard to address devices in non-residential buildings. These guidelines, which now pertain to schools, healthcare centers, nursing homes and other non-residential buildings, include three main points: :1. A secondary power supply (battery backup) must operate all carbon monoxide notification appliances for at least 12 hours, :2. Detectors must be on the ceiling in the same room as permanently installed fuel-burning appliances, and :3. Detectors must be located on every habitable level and in every [[HVAC]] zone of the building. Gas organizations will often recommend to get gas appliances serviced at least once a year.{{cite web|title=Gas Safety in the Home |publisher=UK Gas Safe Register |accessdate=2013-05-27 |url=http://www.gassaferegister.co.uk/advice/being_gas_safe.aspx |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130502012946/http://gassaferegister.co.uk/advice/being_gas_safe.aspx |archivedate=2013-05-02 |df= }} === Legal requirements === The NFPA standard is not necessarily enforced by law. As of April 2006, the US state of Massachusetts requires detectors to be present in all residences with potential CO sources, regardless of building age and whether they are owner-occupied or rented.{{cite web|url=http://www.malegislature.gov/Laws/GeneralLaws/PartI/TitleXX/Chapter148/Section26F1~2|title=MGL Ch. 148 §28F{{frac|1|2}} – Nicole's Law, effective March 31, 2006|work=malegislature.gov|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121230154311/http://www.malegislature.gov/Laws/GeneralLaws/PartI/TitleXX/Chapter148/Section26F1~2|archivedate=December 30, 2012|df=}} This is enforced by municipal inspectors, and was inspired by the death of 7-year-old Nicole Garofalo in 2005 due to snow blocking a home heating vent.{{cite web |url=http://www.lawlib.state.ma.us/subject/about/carbonmonoxide.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-02-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130305145343/http://www.lawlib.state.ma.us/subject/about/carbonmonoxide.html |archivedate=2013-03-05 |df= }} Other jurisdictions may have no requirement or only mandate detectors for new construction or at time of sale. Despite similar deaths in vehicles with clogged exhaust pipes (for example in the [[Northeastern United States blizzard of 1978]] and [[February 2013 nor'easter]]) and the commercial availability of the equipment, there is no legal requirement for automotive CO detectors.{{citation needed|date=May 2015}} ===World Health Organization recommendations=== The following guideline values (ppm values rounded) and periods of time-weighted average exposures have been determined in such a way that the carboxyhaemoglobin (COHb) level of 2.5% is not exceeded, even when a normal subject engages in light or moderate exercise: * 100 mg/m3 (87 ppm) for 15 min * 60 mg/m3 (52 ppm) for 30 min * 30 mg/m3 (26 ppm) for 1 h * 10 mg/m3 (9 ppm) for 8 h For indoor air quality 7 mg/m3 (6 ppm) for 24 h (so as not to exceed 2% COHb for chronic exposure) == Treatment == {| class="wikitable" style = "float: right; margin-left:15px; text-align:center;" |+ Time to remove 50% carboxy hemoglobin{{cite book|last1=Mathieu|first1=Daniel|title=Handbook on Hyperbaric Medicine|date=2006|publisher=Springer|location=[New York]|isbn=978-1402043765|edition=Online-Ausg.}} ! Oxygen pressure О2 ! Time |- |21% oxygen at normal atmospheric pressure (fresh air) | 5 hours 20 min |- |100% oxygen at normal atmospheric pressure (non-rebreather oxygen mask) | 1 hours 20 min |- |100% Hyperbaric oxygen (3 atmospheres absolute) | 23 min |} Initial treatment for carbon monoxide poisoning is to immediately remove the person from the exposure without endangering further people. Those who are unconscious may require [[Cardiopulmonary resuscitation|CPR]] on site. Administering [[oxygen]] via [[non-rebreather mask]] shortens the [[Biological half-life|half-life]] of carbon monoxide from 320 minutes, when breathing normal air, to only 80 minutes. Oxygen hastens the dissociation of carbon monoxide from [[carboxyhemoglobin]], thus turning it back into [[hemoglobin]].{{cite journal|author=Olson KR|title=Carbon monoxide poisoning: Mechanisms, presentation, and controversies in management|journal= [[The Journal of Emergency Medicine]] |volume=1|issue=3|pages=233–43|year=1984|pmid=6491241|doi=10.1016/0736-4679(84)90078-7}} Due to the possible severe effects in the fetus, pregnant women are treated with oxygen for longer periods of time than non-pregnant people.{{cite journal|author=Margulies JL|title=Acute carbon monoxide poisoning during pregnancy|journal=The American Journal of Emergency Medicine|volume=4|issue=6|pages=516–19|date=November 1986|pmid=3778597|doi=10.1016/S0735-6757(86)80008-0}} === Hyperbaric oxygen === [[File:HyperBaric Oxygen Therapy Chamber 2008.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|A person within a hyperbaric oxygen chamber]] [[Hyperbaric oxygen]] is also used in the treatment of carbon monoxide poisoning, as it may hasten dissociation of CO from carboxyhemoglobin and cytochrome oxidase{{cite journal|vauthors=Brown DB, Mueller GL, Golich FC |title=Hyperbaric oxygen treatment for carbon monoxide poisoning in pregnancy: a case report|journal=Aviation, Space, and Environmental Medicine|volume=63|issue=11|pages=1011–14|date=November 1992|pmid=1445151}} to a greater extent than normal oxygen. Hyperbaric oxygen at three times [[atmospheric pressure]] reduces the half life of carbon monoxide to 23 (~80/3 minutes) minutes, compared to 80 minutes for oxygen at regular atmospheric pressure. It may also enhance oxygen transport to the tissues by plasma, partially bypassing the normal transfer through hemoglobin. However, it is controversial whether hyperbaric oxygen actually offers any extra benefits over normal high flow oxygen, in terms of increased survival or improved long-term outcomes.{{Cite journal|last=Buckley|first=Nick A.|last2=Juurlink|first2=David N.|last3=Isbister|first3=Geoff|last4=Bennett|first4=Michael H.|last5=Lavonas|first5=Eric J.|date=2011-04-13|title=Hyperbaric oxygen for carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|issue=4|page=CD002041|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD002041.pub3|issn=1469-493X|pmid=21491385}}{{cite journal|author=Henry JA|title=Hyperbaric therapy for carbon monoxide poisoning: to treat or not to treat, that is the question|journal=Toxicological Reviews|volume=24|issue=3|pages=149–150|year=2005|pmid=16390211|doi=10.2165/00139709-200524030-00002}} {{cite journal|author=Olson KR|title=Hyperbaric oxygen or normobaric oxygen?|journal=Toxicological Reviews|volume=24|issue=3|page=151; discussion 159–60|year=2005|pmid=16390212|doi=10.2165/00139709-200524030-00003}}{{cite journal|author=Seger D|title=The myth|journal=Toxicological Reviews|volume=24|issue=3|pages=155–56|year=2005|pmid=16390214|doi=10.2165/00139709-200524030-00005}}{{cite journal|author=Thom SR|title=Hyperbaric oxygen therapy for carbon monoxide poisoning: Is it time to end the debates?|journal=Toxicological Reviews|volume=24|issue=3|pages=157–58|year=2005|pmid=16390215|doi=10.2165/00139709-200524030-00006}} There have been [[randomized controlled trial]]s in which the two treatment options have been compared;{{cite journal|vauthors=Scheinkestel CD, Bailey M, Myles PS, Jones K, Cooper DJ, Millar IL, Tuxen DV|title=Hyperbaric or normobaric oxygen for acute carbon monoxide poisoning: a randomized controlled clinical trial|journal=[[The Medical Journal of Australia]]|date=March 1999|pages=203–10|volume=170|issue=5|pmid=10092916|url=http://www.mja.com.au/public/issues/mar1/scheink/scheink.html|format=Free full text|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080905012917/https://www.mja.com.au/public/issues/mar1/scheink/scheink.html|archivedate=2008-09-05|df=}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Thom SR, Taber RL, Mendiguren II, Clark JM, Hardy KR, Fisher AB |title=Delayed neuropsychologic sequelae after carbon monoxide poisoning: prevention by treatment with hyperbaric oxygen|journal=Annals of Emergency Medicine|date=April 1995|pages=474–80|volume=25|issue=4|pmid=7710151|doi=10.1016/S0196-0644(95)70261-X}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Raphael JC, Elkharrat D, Jars-Guincestre MC, Chastang C, Chasles V, Vercken JB, Gajdos P |title=Trial of normobaric and hyperbaric oxygen for acute carbon monoxide intoxication|journal=Lancet|date=August 1989|pages=414–19|volume=2|issue=8660|pmid=2569600|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(89)90592-8}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Ducasse JL, Celsis P, Marc-Vergnes JP|title=Non-comatose patients with acute carbon monoxide poisoning: hyperbaric or normobaric oxygenation?|journal=Undersea & Hyperbaric Medicine|date=March 1995|pages=9–15|volume=22|issue=1|pmid=7742714|url=http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/2193|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110811174818/http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/2193|archivedate=2011-08-11|df=}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Mathieu D, Mathieu-Nolf M, Durak C, Wattel F, Tempe JP, Bouachour G, Sainty JM|title=Randomized prospective study comparing the effect of HBO vs 12 hours NBO in non-comatose CO-poisoned patients: results of the preliminary analysis|journal=Undersea & Hyperbaric Medicine|year=1996|page=7|volume=23|url=http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/447|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110702235523/http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/447|archivedate=2011-07-02|df=}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Weaver LK, Hopkins RO, Chan KJ, Churchill S, Elliott CG, Clemmer TP, Orme JF, Thomas FO, Morris AH |title=Hyperbaric oxygen for acute carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=The New England Journal of Medicine|date=October 2002|pages=1057–67|volume=347|issue=14|pmid=12362006|doi=10.1056/NEJMoa013121}} of the six performed, four found hyperbaric oxygen improved outcome and two found no benefit for hyperbaric oxygen.{{cite journal|vauthors=Buckley NA, Isbister GK, Stokes B, Juurlink DN |title=Hyperbaric oxygen for carbon monoxide poisoning: a systematic review and critical analysis of the evidence|journal=Toxicological Reviews|year=2005|pages=75–92|volume=24|issue=2|pmid=16180928|doi=10.2165/00139709-200524020-00002}} Some of these trials have been criticized for apparent flaws in their implementation.{{cite journal|author=Gorman DF.|title=Hyperbaric or normobaric oxygen for acute carbon monoxide poisoning: a randomised controlled clinical trial. Unfortunate methodological flaws|journal=The Medical Journal of Australia|date=June 1999|pages=563; author reply 564–65|volume=170|issue=11|pmid=10397050}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Scheinkestel CD, Jones K, Myles PS, Cooper DJ, Millar IL, Tuxen DV |title=Where to now with carbon monoxide poisoning?|journal=Emergency Medicine Australasia: EMA|date=April 2004|pages=151–54|volume=16|issue=2|pmid=15239731|doi=10.1111/j.1742-6723.2004.00567.x}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Isbister GK, McGettigan P, Harris I |title=Hyperbaric oxygen for acute carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=The New England Journal of Medicine|date=February 2003|pages=557–60|volume=348|issue=6|pmid=12572577|doi=10.1056/NEJM200302063480615}}{{cite journal |vauthors=Buckley NA, Juurlink DN |title=Carbon monoxide treatment guidelines must acknowledge the limitations of the existing evidence |journal=American Journal of Respiratory and Critical Care Medicine |volume=187 |issue=12 |page=1390 |date=June 2013 |pmid=23767905 |doi=10.1164/rccm.201212-2262LE}} A review of all the literature concluded that the role of hyperbaric oxygen is unclear and the available evidence neither confirms nor denies a medically meaningful benefit. The authors suggested a large, well designed, externally audited, multicentre trial to compare normal oxygen with hyperbaric oxygen. === Other === Further treatment for other complications such as [[seizure]], hypotension, cardiac abnormalities, [[pulmonary edema]], and [[acidosis]] may be required. Increased muscle activity and seizures should be treated with [[dantrolene]] or [[diazepam]]; diazepam should only be given with appropriate respiratory support. Hypotension requires treatment with intravenous fluids; [[vasopressor]]s may be required to treat myocardial depression.{{cite journal|author=Tomaszewski C|title=Carbon monoxide poisoning. Early awareness and intervention can save lives|journal=Postgraduate Medicine|volume=105|issue=1|pages=39–40, 43–48, 50|date=January 1999|pmid=9924492|doi=10.3810/pgm.1999.01.496}} [[Cardiac dysrhythmia]]s are treated with standard [[advanced cardiac life support]] protocols. If severe, metabolic acidosis is treated with [[sodium bicarbonate]]. Treatment with sodium bicarbonate is controversial as acidosis may increase tissue oxygen availability.{{cite journal|author=Peirce EC|title=Treating acidemia in carbon monoxide poisoning may be dangerous|journal=Journal of Hyperbaric Medicine|volume=1|issue=2|pages=87–97|year=1986|pmid=|url=http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/4304|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110703000244/http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/4304|archivedate=2011-07-03|df=}} Treatment of acidosis may only need to consist of oxygen therapy. The delayed development of neuropsychiatric impairment is one of the most serious complications of carbon monoxide poisoning. Brain damage is confirmed following [[magnetic resonance imaging|MRI]] or [[X-ray computed tomography|CAT]] scans.{{cite journal|vauthors=Devine SA, Kirkley SM, Palumbo CL, White RF |title=MRI and neuropsychological correlates of carbon monoxide exposure: a case report |journal=Environmental Health Perspectives |volume=110 |issue=10 |pages=1051–55 |date=October 2002 |pmid=12361932 |pmc=1241033 |doi=10.1289/ehp.021101051 |url=http://ehpnet1.niehs.nih.gov/members/2002/110p1051-1055devine/devine-full.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120707154535/http://ehpnet1.niehs.nih.gov/members/2002/110p1051-1055devine/devine-full.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-07-07 }}{{cite journal|vauthors=O'Donnell P, Buxton PJ, Pitkin A, Jarvis LJ |title=The magnetic resonance imaging appearances of the brain in acute carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=Clinical Radiology|volume=55|issue=4|pages=273–80|date=April 2000|pmid=10767186|doi=10.1053/crad.1999.0369}} Extensive follow up and supportive treatment is often required for delayed neurological damage. Outcomes are often difficult to predict following poisoning,{{cite journal|vauthors=Seger D, Welch L |title=Carbon monoxide controversies: neuropsychologic testing, mechanism of toxicity, and hyperbaric oxygen|journal=Annals of Emergency Medicine|volume=24|issue=2|pages=242–48|date=August 1994|pmid=8037390|doi=10.1016/S0196-0644(94)70136-9}} especially people who have symptoms of [[cardiac arrest]], [[coma]], [[metabolic acidosis]], or have high carboxyhemoglobin levels. One study reported that approximately 30% of people with severe carbon monoxide poisoning will have a fatal outcome. It has been reported that electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) may increase the likelihood of delayed neuropsychiatric sequelae (DNS) after carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning.{{cite journal|last=Chiang|first=CL|author2=Tseng, MC|title=Safe use of electroconvulsive therapy in a highly suicidal survivor of carbon monoxide poisoning.|journal=Gen Hosp Psychiatry|date=27 September 2011}} == Epidemiology == {{Category see also|Deaths from carbon monoxide poisoning}} The true number of cases of carbon monoxide poisoning is unknown, since many non-lethal exposures go undetected. From the available data, carbon monoxide poisoning is the most common cause of injury and death due to poisoning worldwide.{{cite journal|author=Thom SR|title=Hyperbaric-oxygen therapy for acute carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=The New England Journal of Medicine|volume=347|issue=14|pages=1105–06|date=October 2002|pmid=12362013|doi=10.1056/NEJMe020103}} Poisoning is typically more common during the winter months.{{cite journal |vauthors=Ernst A, Zibrak JD |title=Carbon monoxide poisoning |journal=The New England Journal of Medicine |volume=339 |issue=22 |pages=1603–08 |date=November 1998 |pmid=9828249 |doi=10.1056/NEJM199811263392206}}{{cite journal |author=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) |title=Deaths from motor-vehicle-related unintentional carbon monoxide poisoning—Colorado, 1996, New Mexico, 1980–1995, and United States, 1979–1992 |journal=MMWR. Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report |volume=45 |issue=47 |pages=1029–32 |date=November 1996 |pmid=8965803 |doi= |url=https://www.cdc.gov/mmwR/preview/mmwrhtml/00044617.htm |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170624012603/https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00044617.htm |archivedate=2017-06-24 |df= }}{{cite journal |vauthors=Partrick M, Fiesseler F, Shih R, Riggs R, Hung O |title=Monthly variations in the diagnosis of carbon monoxide exposures in the emergency department |journal=Undersea & Hyperbaric Medicine |volume=36 |issue=3 |pages=161–67 |year=2009 |pmid=19860138}} This is due to increased domestic use of gas furnaces, gas or kerosene [[space heater]]s, and kitchen stoves during the winter months, which if faulty and/or used without adequate ventilation, may produce excessive carbon monoxide.{{cite journal |author=Heckerling PS |title=Occult carbon monoxide poisoning: a cause of winter headache |journal=The American Journal of Emergency Medicine |volume=5 |issue=3 |pages=201–04 |date=May 1987 |pmid=3580051 |doi= 10.1016/0735-6757(87)90320-2|url=}} Carbon monoxide detection and poisoning also increases during power outages, when electric heating and cooking appliances become inoperative and residents may temporarily resort to fuel-burning space heaters, stoves, and grills (some of which are safe only for outdoor use but nonetheless are errantly burned indoors).{{cite web|title=Department of Public Health Warns of Dangers of Carbon Monoxide Poisoning During Power Outages|url=http://www.towergenerator.com/Resources/Power_Generator_Carbon_Monoxide_Dangers/|publisher=Tower Generator|accessdate=2011-11-23|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426001248/http://www.towergenerator.com/Resources/Power_Generator_Carbon_Monoxide_Dangers/|archivedate=2012-04-26|df=}}{{cite web|title=Avoiding Carbon Monoxide poisoning during a power outage |url=http://www.bt.cdc.gov/disasters/psa/co.asp |publisher=CDC |accessdate=2011-11-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111212171534/http://www.bt.cdc.gov/disasters/psa/co.asp |archivedate=2011-12-12 |df= }}{{cite journal|last=Klein|first=Kelly|author2=Herzog, Perri |author3=Smolinske, Susan |author4= White, Suzanne |title=Demand for poison control center services "surged" during the 2003 blackout.|journal=Clinical Toxicology|year=2007|volume=45|issue=3|pages=248–54|doi=10.1080/15563650601031676 |pmid=17453875}} It has been estimated that more than 40,000 people per year seek medical attention for carbon monoxide poisoning in the United States.{{cite journal|author=Hampson NB|title=Emergency department visits for carbon monoxide poisoning in the Pacific Northwest|journal= [[The Journal of Emergency Medicine]] |date=September 1998|pages=695–98|volume=16|issue=5|pmid=9752939|doi=10.1016/S0736-4679(98)00080-8}} 95% of carbon monoxide poisoning deaths in the United States are due to gas space heaters.{{cite web|url=http://www.esv.vic.gov.au/Portals/0/About%20ESV/Files/Gas%20use%20reports/2004AddendumtoOverseasandAustralianStatisticsandBenchmarksforCustomerGasSafetyIncidents.pdf|title=2004 Addendum to Overseas and Australian Statistics and Benchmarks for Customer Gas Safety Incidents|publisher=Office of Gas Safety, Victoria|year=2004|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924002528/http://www.esv.vic.gov.au/Portals/0/About%20ESV/Files/Gas%20use%20reports/2004AddendumtoOverseasandAustralianStatisticsandBenchmarksforCustomerGasSafetyIncidents.pdf|archivedate=2015-09-24|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.scer.gov.au/files/2012/03/EMR2-QRA-Final.pdf |title=The risk of carbon monoxide poisoning from domestic gas appliances |work=Report to the Department of Resources, Energy and Tourism |date=Feb 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150312065135/http://www.scer.gov.au/files/2012/03/EMR2-QRA-Final.pdf |archivedate=2015-03-12 |df= }} In many industrialized countries carbon monoxide is the cause of more than 50% of fatal poisonings. In the United States, approximately 200 people die each year from carbon monoxide poisoning associated with home fuel-burning heating equipment.{{cite web|title=Carbon Monoxide Detectors Can Save Lives: CPSC Document #5010|publisher=US Consumer Product Safety Commission|url=http://www.cpsc.gov/CPSCPUB/PUBS/5010.html|accessdate=2009-04-30|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090409030219/http://www.cpsc.gov/CPSCPUB/PUBS/5010.html |archivedate=2009-04-09}} Carbon monoxide poisoning contributes to the approximately 5613 smoke inhalation deaths each year in the United States.{{cite journal|vauthors=Cobb N, Etzel RA|title=Unintentional carbon monoxide-related deaths in the United States, 1979 through 1988|journal=JAMA|volume=266|issue=5|pages=659–63|date=August 7, 1991|pmid=1712865|url=http://jama.ama-assn.org/cgi/content/abstract/266/5/659|doi=10.1001/jama.266.5.659|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080921102448/http://jama.ama-assn.org/cgi/content/abstract/266/5/659|archivedate=September 21, 2008|df=}} The [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]] reports, "Each year, more than 500 Americans die from unintentional carbon monoxide poisoning, and more than 2,000 commit suicide by intentionally poisoning themselves."{{cite web|title=Carbon Monoxide poisoning fact sheet|publisher=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|date=July 2006|url=https://www.cdc.gov/co/pdfs/faqs.pdf|format=pdf|doi=|accessdate=2008-12-16|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081218085439/http://www.cdc.gov/co/pdfs/faqs.pdf|archivedate=2008-12-18|df=}} For the 10-year period from 1979 to 1988, 56,133 deaths from carbon monoxide poisoning occurred in the United States, with 25,889 of those being suicides, leaving 30,244 unintentional deaths. A report from [[New Zealand]] showed that 206 people died from carbon monoxide poisoning in the years of 2001 and 2002. In total carbon monoxide poisoning was responsible for 43.9% of deaths by poisoning in that country.{{cite journal|vauthors=McDowell R, Fowles J, Phillips D|title=Deaths from poisoning in New Zealand: 2001–2002|journal=[[The New Zealand Medical Journal]]|volume=118|issue=1225|page=U1725|date=November 2005|pmid=16286939|url=http://www.nzmj.com/journal/118-1225/1725/|format=Free full text|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20110714220921/http://www.nzmj.com/journal/118-1225/1725/|archivedate=2011-07-14|df=}} In [[South Korea]], 1,950 people had been poisoned by carbon monoxide with 254 deaths from 2001 through 2003.{{cite journal|vauthors=Song KJ, Shin SD, Cone DC |title=Socioeconomic status and severity-based incidence of poisoning: a nationwide cohort study|journal=[[Clinical Toxicology]]|volume=47|issue=8|pages=818–26|date=September 2009|pmid=19640232|doi=10.1080/15563650903158870}} A report from [[Jerusalem]] showed 3.53 per 100,000 people were poisoned annually from 2001 through 2006.{{cite journal|vauthors=Salameh S, Amitai Y, Antopolsky M, Rott D, Stalnicowicz R |title=Carbon monoxide poisoning in Jerusalem: epidemiology and risk factors|journal=Clinical Toxicology|volume=47|issue=2|pages=137–41|date=February 2009|pmid=18720104|doi=10.1080/15563650801986711}} In [[Hubei]], China, 218 deaths from poisoning were reported over a 10-year period with 16.5% being from carbon monoxide exposure.{{cite journal |vauthors=Liu Q, Zhou L, Zheng N, Zhuo L, Liu Y, Liu L |title=Poisoning deaths in China: type and prevalence detected at the Tongji Forensic Medical Center in Hubei |journal=Forensic Science International |volume=193 |issue=1–3 |pages=88–94 |date=December 2009 |pmid=19854011 |doi=10.1016/j.forsciint.2009.09.013}} ==History== The earliest description of carbon monoxide poisoning dates to at least 200 BC by [[Aristotle]]. Documented cases of carbon monoxide being used as a [[Suicide methods#Carbon monoxide|method of suicide]] date to at least 100 BC in [[ancient Rome]].{{cite book|last1=Penney|first1=David G.|title=Carbon Monoxide Poisoning|date=2007|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=978-0849384189|page=754|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=793KBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA754|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170910172025/https://books.google.com/books?id=793KBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA754|archivedate=2017-09-10|df=}} In the AD 350s, the Roman emperor [[Julian (emperor)|Julian]] suffered from carbon monoxide poisoning in Paris, and later described it in his work ''Misopogon'': "though the winter weather prevailed and continually increased in severity, even so I did not allow my servants to heat the house, because I was afraid of drawing out the dampness in the walls; but I ordered them to carry in fire that had burned down and to place in the room a very moderate number of hot coals. But the coals, though there were not very many of them, brought out from the walls quantities of steam and this made me fall asleep. And since my head was filled with the fumes I was almost choked. Then I was carried outside."Julian, ''Misopogon'' 341C-D This misunderstanding of the causes of carbon monoxide poisoning may have caused the death of Julian's successor, [[Jovian (emperor)|Jovian]]. [[John Scott Haldane]] identified carbon monoxide as the lethal constituent of [[afterdamp]], the gas created by [[combustion]], after examining many bodies of miners killed in pit explosions. Their skin was coloured cherry-pink from [[carboxyhaemoglobin]], the stable compound formed in the blood by reaction with the gas. As a result of his research, he was able to design respirators for rescue workers. He tested the effect of carbon monoxide on his own body in a closed chamber, describing the results of his slow poisoning. In the late 1890s, he introduced the use of small animals for miners to detect dangerous levels of carbon monoxide underground, either white mice or canaries. With a faster metabolism, they showed the effects of poisoning before gas levels became critical for the workers, and so gave an early warning of the problem. The [[canary in a coal mine|canary]] in British pits was replaced in 1986 by the electronic gas detector. As part of the [[Holocaust]] during [[World War II]], German [[Nazi]]s used [[gas van]]s at [[Chelmno extermination camp]] and elsewhere to kill an estimated over 700,000 prisoners by carbon monoxide poisoning. This method was also used in the gas chambers of several [[extermination camp|death camps]] such as [[Treblinka]], [[Sobibor]] and [[Belzec]]. Gassing with carbon monoxide started in [[action T4]], the programme developed by the Nazis in Germany to murder the mentally ill and [[disabled people]] before the war started in earnest. The gas was supplied by [[IG Farben]] in pressurized cylinders and fed by tubes into the gas chambers built at various mental hospitals, such as [[Hartheim Euthanasia Centre]]. Many key personnel were recruited from the T4 programme to murder much larger numbers of people in the gas vans and the special [[gas chamber]]s used in the [[death camp]]s such as [[Treblinka]]. [[Exhaust fumes]] from tank engines for example, were used to supply the gas to the chambers.{{cite book|title=Dictionary of Genocide|vauthors=Totten S, Bartrop P, Markusen E|year=2007|publisher=Greenwood|pages=129, 156|url=https://books.google.com/?id=rgGA91skoP4C&lpg=PA156&dq=nazi%20carbon%20monoxide%20poisoning&pg=PA156#v=onepage&q=carbon%20monoxide%20poisoning&f=false|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130526000146/http://books.google.com/books?id=rgGA91skoP4C&lpg=PA156&ots=S8jhBY6NxB&dq=nazi%20carbon%20monoxide%20poisoning&pg=PA156#v=onepage&q=carbon%20monoxide%20poisoning&f=false|archivedate=2013-05-26|df=|isbn=978-0313346422}} The use of oxygen as treatment began in 1868. The use of hyperbaric oxygen in rats following poisoning was studied by Haldane in 1895 while its use in humans began in the 1960s. ==Research== Carbon monoxide is produced naturally by the body as a byproduct of converting [[protoporphyrin]] into [[bilirubin]]. This carbon monoxide also combines with hemoglobin to make carboxyhemoglobin, but not at toxic levels. Small amounts of CO are beneficial and enzymes exist that produce it at times of oxidative stress. Drugs are being developed to introduce small amounts of CO during certain kinds of surgery, these drugs are called [[carbon monoxide-releasing molecules]].{{cite journal|last1=Foresti|first1=R|last2=Bani-Hani|first2=MG|last3=Motterlini|first3=R|title=Use of carbon monoxide as a therapeutic agent: promises and challenges.|journal=Intensive Care Medicine|date=April 2008|volume=34|issue=4|pages=649–58|pmid=18286265|doi=10.1007/s00134-008-1011-1}} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == {{Medical resources | DiseasesDB = | ICD10 = {{ICD10|T|58}} | ICD9 = {{ICD9|986}} | eMedicineSubj = article | eMedicineTopic = 819987 | MeshID = D002249 }} * [https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/co-comp/ Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) – Carbon Monoxide – NIOSH Workplace Safety and Health Topic] * International Programme on Chemical Safety (1999). [http://www.who.int/ipcs/publications/ehc/ehc_213/en/ Carbon Monoxide], Environmental Health Criteria 213, Geneva: WHO {{Poisoning and toxicity}} {{good article}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Carbon Monoxide Poisoning}} [[Category:Carbon monoxide|Poisoning]] [[Category:Accidents]] [[Category:Industrial hygiene]] [[Category:Medical emergencies]] [[Category:Natural gas safety]] [[Category:Suicide methods]] [[Category:Toxic effects of substances chiefly nonmedicinal as to source]] [[Category:RTT]] [[Category:RTTEM]]

David R. Williams, NASA Goddard Space Flight Center. Accessed on 30 November 2018.</ref> }}

'''Chang'e 5''' ({{zh|s=嫦娥五号|hp=Cháng'é wǔhào}}) is a robotic [[China|Chinese]] [[lunar exploration]] mission consisting of an orbiter and a lander. It is currently under development and it is scheduled for a launch in December 2019, after being postponed due to the failure of the [[Long March 5]] [[launch vehicle]] in 2017.<ref name="foust">{{cite web|author1=Jeff Foust|title=Long March 5 failure to postpone China's lunar exploration program|url=http://spacenews.com/long-march-5-failure-to-postpone-chinas-lunar-exploration-program/|publisher=SpaceNews|accessdate=17 December 2017|date=25 September 2017}}</ref> Chang'e 5 will be China's first [[sample return mission]], aiming to return at least 2 kilograms of lunar soil and rock samples back to the Earth.<ref name='Ch 5'/> Like its predecessors, the spacecraft is named after the Chinese moon goddess, [[Chang'e]]. This will be the first lunar sample-return mission since [[Luna 24]] in 1976.
== Overview ==
The [[Chinese Lunar Exploration Program]] is designed to be conducted in three phases of incremental technological advancement: The first is simply reaching lunar orbit, a task completed by [[Chang'e 1]] in 2007 and [[Chang'e 2]] in 2010. The second is landing and roving on the Moon, as [[Chang'e 3]] did in 2013 and [[Chang'e 4]] is now expected to achieve in 2019. The third phase is collecting lunar samples from the near-side and sending them to Earth, a task for the future Chang'e 5 and [[Chang'e 6]] missions. The program aims to facilitate a crewed lunar landing in the 2030s and possibly build an outpost near the south pole.<ref>[https://qz.com/1262581/china-lays-out-its-ambitions-to-colonize-the-moon-and-build-a-lunar-palace/ China lays out its ambitions to colonize the moon and build a "lunar palace"]. Echo Huang, ''Quartz''. 26 April 2018.</ref>
==Mission profile== The probe was planned for launch by the [[Long March 5]] rocket at the [[Wenchang Satellite Launch Center]] on [[Hainan Island]], but the failure of this vehicle in 2017 created uncertainty about its ability to carry Chang'e 5.<ref name=foust/> Targeted to the northwest region of the Moon, the specific region intended for sampling is [[Mons Rümker]] in [[Oceanus Procellarum]].<ref name='Ch 5'/><ref name="jones">{{cite web|author1=Andrew Jones|title=China confirms landing site for Chang'e-5 Moon sample return|url=https://gbtimes.com/china-confirms-landing-site-change-5-moon-sample-return|publisher=GB Times|accessdate=17 December 2017|date=7 June 2017}}</ref> After making a soft landing, the lander will dig {{convert|2|m|ft}} below the surface for a 2 kg lunar sample from [[basalt]] estimated to be 1.3 billion years old, younger than the 3–4 billion year old samples obtained by the American [[Apollo program|Apollo missions]].<ref name=jones/>
Unlike earlier Soviet missions, the mission will make [[Lunar orbit rendezvous|an automatic rendezvous]] and docking with the return module in lunar orbit before flying back to the Earth.<ref name='Ch 5'/><ref name=sf101/>
===Chang'e 5-T1=== [[Chang'e 5-T1]] is an experimental robotic lunar mission that was launched on 23 October 2014 to conduct [[Atmospheric entry|atmospheric re-entry]] tests on the capsule design planned to be used in the Chang'e 5 mission.<ref name=Launched>{{cite web|url=http://www.spaceflight101.com/change-5-test-mission-updates.html|title=Chinese Long March Rocket successfully launches Lunar Return Demonstrator|publisher=Spaceflight101|date=Oct 23, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/china/2014-10/24/c_127134592.htm| title=China launches test return orbiter for lunar mission| publisher=Xinhuanet| date=Oct 24, 2014}}</ref>
==Lander payload== The lander will carry landing cameras, optical cameras, a mineral spectrometer, a soil gas analytical instrument, a soil composition analytical instrument, a sampling sectional thermo-detector, and a [[ground-penetrating radar]].<ref name='Ch 5'/><ref name="sf101">{{cite web|title=Chang'e 5 test mission|url=http://spaceflight101.com/change/change-5-test-mission/|publisher=Spaceflight101.com|accessdate=17 December 2017|date=2017}}</ref> For acquiring samples, it will be equipped with a robotic arm, rotary-percussive drill, a scoop for sampling, and separation tubes to isolate individual samples.<ref name="sf101"/>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
{{Moon spacecraft}} {{CLEP}} {{Chinese spacecraft}} {{Future spaceflights}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Chang'e 5}} [[Category:Chinese Lunar Exploration Program]] [[Category:Missions to the Moon]] [[Category:Sample return missions]] [[Category:Chinese space probes]] [[Category:2019 in spaceflight]] [[Category:2019 in China]]

{{Infobox company | name = Commerce One, Inc. | fate = Acquired by Perfect Commerce | foundation = {{start date and age|1994}} | founder = Tom Gonzales
Tom Gonzales Jr. | defunct = {{end date and age|2006|02|07}} | location = [[Pleasanton, California]] | revenue = {{increase}} $0.401 billion (2000) | net_income = {{decrease}} -$0.344 billion (2000) | assets = {{increase}} $3.070 billion (2000) | equity = {{increase}} $2.799 billion (2000) | num_employees = 3,766 (2000) | footnotes = {{cite web | url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1069450/000091205701506507/a2041680z10-k.txt | title=Commerce One, Inc. 2000 Form 10-K Annual Report | publisher=[[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]]}} }} '''Commerce One, Inc.''' was a [[B2B e-commerce]] company{{cite news | url=https://www.cnet.com/news/commerce-one-soars-after-3-for-1-split/ | title=Commerce One soars after 3-for-1 split | work=[[CNET]]}} that used [[online auction]]s to connect business to their suppliers.{{cite book|author=John Carreyrou|title=Bad Blood: Secrets and Lies in a Silicon Valley Startup|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CcJFDwAAQBAJ|date=21 May 2018|publisher=Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group|isbn=978-1-5247-3166-3}} At the peak of [[dot-com bubble]], the company had a [[market capitalization]] of $21.5 billion.{{cite news | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2003-02-02/online-extra-from-hot-to-scorched-at-commerce-one | title=Online Extra: From Hot to Scorched at Commerce One | first=Steve | last=Hamm | work=[[Bloomberg BusinessWeek]] | date=February 3, 2003}} The company's technologies included [[Schema for Object-Oriented XML]] (SOX), an [[XML schema]] technology that influenced the development of the [[W3C]]'s [[XML Schema (W3C)|XML Schema]] language and the [[Java Architecture for XML Binding]] (JAXB). ==History== The company was founded in 1994 as DistriVision by Tom Gonzales and his son, Tom Gonzales Jr.{{cite news | url=http://www.eastbaytimes.com/2007/07/13/charity-sues-over-legacy-of-dot-com/ | title=Charity sues over legacy of dot-com | first=JOHN | last=SIMERMAN | work=[[East Bay Times]] | date=July 13, 2007}} It was renamed Commerce One in 1997 after Mark Hoffman became CEO. In January 1999, the company acquired Veo Systems from Asim Abdullah for $300 million.{{cite news | url=http://www.internetnews.com/ec-news/article.php/33571/Commerce+One+Buys+Veo+Systems.htm | title=Commerce One Buys Veo Systems | work=[[QuinStreet]] | date=January 19, 1999}} In November 1999, the company acquired CommerceBid from [[Ramesh Balwani]] for $4.5 million in cash and 785,000 shares and the company partnered with [[General Motors]] to create an [[online marketplace]].{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/11/06/business/company-news-commerce-one-buys-commercebid-for-stock-and-cash.html | title=COMMERCE ONE BUYS COMMERCEBID FOR STOCK AND CASH | agency=[[Bloomberg News]] | publisher=[[The New York Times]] | date=November 6, 1999}} In July 1999, on its first trading day after its [[initial public offering]], the company's stock price rose 190%.{{cite news | url=http://money.cnn.com/1999/07/01/technology/askjeeves/ | title=IPO a smash? Ask Jeeves | work=[[CNNMoney]] | date=July 1, 1999}} In September 2000, the company acquired AppNet for $1.6 billion in stock.{{cite news | url=http://money.cnn.com/2000/06/20/deals/commerceone/ | title=Commerce One, AppNet tie | work=[[CNNMoney]] | date=June 20, 2000}} In December 2000, the company formed [[Covisint]] with [[Ford Motor Company]], [[General Motors]], [[Daimler AG]], [[Renault]], and [[Nissan]]. Ford and General Motors each received 14.4 million shares of Commerce One and Commerce One owned 2% of Covisint. In 2001, co-founder Tom Gonzales Jr. died of a rare cancer at age 35 and left his stake in the company in a trust to help the needy. His father was later accused of mismanaging trust funds. In October 2002, the company announced that it planned to lay off 400 employees, 36% of its staff.{{cite news | url=https://www.cnet.com/news/commerce-one-cuts-deep/ | title=Commerce One cuts deep | first=Alorie | last=Gilbert | work=[[CNET]] | date=October 4, 2002}} The company filed [[bankruptcy]] on October 6, 2004 and emerged from bankruptcy 2 months later.{{cite news | url=http://www.bizjournals.com/eastbay/stories/2005/03/07/story1.html | title=Commerce One rises from dot-ashes | work=[[American City Business Journals]] | date=March 6, 2005}}{{cite news | url=https://www.law360.com/articles/3393/mystery-solved-novell-behind-acquisition-of-commerce-one-patents | title=Mystery Solved: Novell Behind Acquisition Of Commerce One Patents | first=Marius | last=Meland | work=[[Law360]] | date=May 3, 2005}} In December 2004, a portion of its [[patent portfolio]] was sold by a bankruptcy court to JGR Acquisitions, a subsidiary of [[Novell]], for $15.5 million.{{cite news | url=https://www.law360.com/ip/articles/2686/mysterious-bidder-snaps-up-commerce-one-patents-for-15-5m | title=Mysterious Bidder Snaps Up Commerce One Patents For $15.5M | first=Marius | last=Meland | work=[[Law360]] | date=December 7, 2004}} The remaining business interests, including all remaining [[intellectual property]] rights to the software, together with a patent license from JGR, were sold to new investors that continued to operate the company as Commerce One. Perfect Commerce acquired Commerce One on February 7, 2006.{{cite press release | url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/perfect-commerce-acquires-commerce-one-55231257.html | title=Perfect Commerce Acquires Commerce One | publisher=[[PR Newswire]] | date=February 7, 2006}} [[Proactis]] acquired Perfect Commerce on July 7, 2017.{{cite press release | url=https://www.crunchbase.com/acquisition/proactis-acquires-perfect-commerce--b11b00c4 | title= Perfect Commerce acquired by Proactis | publisher=[[Crunchbase]] | date=July 7, 2017}} ==References== {{Reflist|1}} [[Category:1994 establishments in California]] [[Category:1999 initial public offerings]] [[Category:2006 mergers and acquisitions]] [[Category:Companies that filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in 2004]] [[Category:Defunct online companies of the United States]] [[Category:Dot-com bubble]]

page.title: Don't Come Around Here No More

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2018}} {{Infobox song | name = Don't Come Around Here No More | cover = TP - Dont Come Around Here No More single.png | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers]] | album = [[Southern Accents]] | B-side = Trailer | released = February 28, 1985 | format = 7" | recorded = 1984 | studio = | venue = | genre = [[Psychedelic rock]]{{cite web|first=Matthew |last=Greenwald |url=https://www.allmusic.com/song/dont-come-around-here-no-more-mt0009210688 |title=Don't Come Around Here No More - Tom Petty & the Heartbreakers | Song Info |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=September 7, 2018}} | length = 5:07 | label = [[MCA Records|MCA]] | writer = [[Tom Petty]], [[David A. Stewart]] | producer = Tom Petty, David A. Stewart, [[Jimmy Iovine]] | prev_title = [[Change of Heart (Tom Petty song)|Change of Heart]] | prev_year = 1983 | next_title = [[Rebels (song)|Rebels]] | next_year = 1985 }} "'''Don't Come Around Here No More'''" is a song written by [[Tom Petty]] of [[Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers]] and [[David A. Stewart]] of [[Eurythmics]]. It was released in February 1985 as the [[lead single]] from Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers' ''[[Southern Accents]]'' album. ==Background and writing== The original inspiration was a romantic encounter that producer [[David A. Stewart]] of [[Eurythmics]] had with [[Stevie Nicks]] of [[Fleetwood Mac]].{{cite web|url=http://www.songfacts.com/detail.php?id=693 |title=Don't Come Around Here No More |publisher=Songfacts.com |date= |accessdate=September 7, 2018}} On ''[[The Howard Stern Show]]'', Stewart explained that the title's phrase was actually uttered by Nicks. She had broken up with [[Eagles (band)|Eagles]] guitarist [[Joe Walsh]] the night before,''Conversations With Tom Petty'', 2005 and invited Stewart to her place for a party after an early Eurythmics show in [[Los Angeles]]. Stewart did not know who she was at the time, but went anyway. When the partygoers all disappeared to a bathroom for a couple of hours to snort cocaine, he decided to go upstairs to bed. He woke up at 5 a.m. to find Nicks in his room trying on Victorian clothing and described the entire scenario as very much reminiscent of ''[[Alice in Wonderland]]''. Later that morning, she told Walsh, "Don't come around here no more." == Music video == The music video is themed around ''[[Alice in Wonderland]]'' and was directed by Jeff Stein. Dave Stewart appears as [[Caterpillar (Alice's Adventures in Wonderland)|the caterpillar]] at the beginning, sitting on a mushroom with a hookah water pipe while playing a sitar. Petty appears in the video dressed as [[Mad Hatter|The Mad Hatter]], and actress Louise “Wish” Foley played [[Alice (Alice's Adventures in Wonderland)|Alice]].{{cite web|author=Hanh Nguyen |url=http://www.indiewire.com/2017/10/tom-pettys-dont-come-around-here-no-more-video-alice-in-wonderland-photos-explained-1201883496/ |title=Tom Petty’s Don’t Come Around Here No More: Alice in Wonderland Guide |publisher=IndieWire |date=October 3, 2017 |accessdate=September 7, 2018}} At the climax of the video, Alice is turned into a cake and is eaten by Petty and even friends of her own. The video ends with her being swallowed whole by Petty, after which he gives a small [[burp]] and pats his mouth dry. == Personnel == '''The Heartbreakers''' *[[Tom Petty]] – lead vocals, piano *[[Mike Campbell (musician)|Mike Campbell]] – guitar, [[bass synthesizer]] *[[Benmont Tench]] – [[string synthesizer]] *[[Stan Lynch]] – drums, percussion *[[Howie Epstein]] – bass guitar, vocals '''Additional personnel''' *[[David A. Stewart]] – [[electric sitar]], synthesizer, vocals *[[Dean Garcia]] – intro bass guitar *Daniel Rothmuller – [[cello]] *[[Marilyn Martin]] – backing vocals *Stephanie Sprull – backing vocals *Sharon Celani – backing vocals *Alan "Bugs" Weidel – wild dog piano ==Chart performance== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !Chart (1985) !Peak
position |- |Australia ([[Kent Music Report]]){{Cite book|title=[[Kent Music Report|Australian Chart Book 1970–1992]]|last=Kent|first=David|authorlink=David Kent (historian)|publisher=Australian Chart Book|location=[[St Ives, New South Wales|St Ives, NSW]]|year=1993|isbn=0-646-11917-6 }} | style="text-align:center;"|61 |- |Canadian Top 100 Singles (''[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]'')[http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/rpm/028020-119.01-e.php?&file_num=nlc008388.0527&type=1&interval=20&PHPSESSID=m89iq841abagb37ld9c0fdc1f3 Top Singles - Volume 42, No. 11, May 25 1985]. collectionscanada.gc.ca. Retrieved September 2, 2013. | style="text-align:center;"|20 |- {{singlechart|New Zealand|42|artist=Tom Petty & The Heartbreakers|song=Don't Come Around Here No More|accessdate=September 2, 2013}} |- |[[UK Singles Chart]] | style="text-align:center;"|50 |- {{singlechart|Billboardhot100|13|artist=Tom Petty|accessdate=September 2, 2013}} |- |US [[Hot Mainstream Rock Tracks|Album Rock Tracks]] ([[Billboard (magazine)|''Billboard'']]) | style="text-align:center;"|2 |} ==Cover versions== Susanna of [[Susanna and the Magical Orchestra]] gives the song a low-key, piano-based cover on her 2008 album ''[[Flower of Evil (album)|Flower of Evil]]''. Indie band [[Vampire Weekend]] covers the song on a steady basis during live shows. British indie pop singer-songwriter [[Diana Vickers]] covered the song as a promotional track ahead of the release of her second album. The song was parodied by [[Bob Rivers]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bobrivers.com/#v8391 |title=Don't Bum Around Here no More |publisher=Bobrivers.com |date=March 15, 2012 |accessdate=September 7, 2018}} Showrunner [[Noah Hawley]] and composer [[Jeff Russo]] also performed a cover for a season two episode of the TV show ''[[Legion (TV series)|Legion]]''. ==References== {{reflist}} {{TPHeartbreakers}} [[Category:Tom Petty songs]] [[Category:1985 singles]] [[Category:Songs written by Tom Petty]] [[Category:Songs written by David A. Stewart]] [[Category:Song recordings produced by Jimmy Iovine]] [[Category:Songs based on actual events]] [[Category:MCA Records singles]] [[Category:1985 songs]]

revision.comment: I saw a slice of the tree during a visit to the Eisenhower Presidential Library and wanted people to know part of the tree has been preserved.
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox tree | name = Eisenhower Tree | image = Eisenhower Tree 2011 (cropped).jpg | alt = | image_caption = The Eisenhower Tree in 2011 | species = Loblolly pine | binomial = ''[[Pinus taeda]]'' | location = Augusta, Georgia | coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|type=landmark_region=XX|display=inline,title}} --> | seeded = {{Circa|1889}} | felled = {{End date|2014|02|df=y}} | custodian = [[Augusta National Golf Club]] | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> }}
The '''Eisenhower Tree''' was a [[Pinus taeda|loblolly pine]] located on the [[Augusta National Golf Club]] in [[Augusta, Georgia]].<ref name=anderson/> In the 1950s it was named after then-[[U.S. President]] [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]] who unsuccessfully lobbied to have it taken down after it interfered with his golf game. Due to its size, history, and location on a prominent golf course, it is considered iconic of the Augusta golf course<ref name="espn" /> and is one of the most famous trees in American golf.<ref name="abcnews">{{cite news|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/augusta-ice-storm-puts-end-eisenhower-tree |title=Augusta Ice Storm Puts an End to Eisenhower Tree |work=[[Associated Press]] |date=February 17, 2014 |accessdate=January 13, 2015 |last=Ferguson |first=Doug |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150114102721/http://bigstory.ap.org/article/augusta-ice-storm-puts-end-eisenhower-tree |archivedate=January 14, 2015 |df=mdy }}</ref> It was called "among the most famous landmarks in golf" by Cindy Boren in the ''[[Washington Post]]''<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/early-lead/wp/2014/02/17/augusta-nationals-eisenhower-tree-is-storm-casualty/ |title=Augusta National’s Eisenhower Tree is storm casualty |work=[[Washington Post]] |first=Cindy |last=Boren |date=February 17, 2014 |accessdate=February 18, 2014}}</ref> and "arguably the most famous tree in golf" by Martin Dempster of ''[[The Scotsman]]''.<ref name="scotsman"/> In February 2014, the tree was removed after suffering extensive damage from a major ice storm.
==Description and origins== The tree species was a native loblolly pine. It stood about {{convert|65|ft|m}} tall and was wider than is typical. It was located on the 17th hole at the Augusta National Golf Club, approximately {{convert|210|yds|m}} from the Masters tee on the left side of the [[Fairway (golf)|fairway]]. It was estimated to be 100 to 125 years old at the time it died.<ref name=anderson>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/04/08/sports/sports-of-the-times-ike-s-tree-re-enlists-as-augusta-hazard.html |title= Sports of The Times; Ike's Tree Re-enlists as Augusta Hazard |work=[[The New York Times]] |first=Dave |last=Anderson |date=April 8, 1999 |accessdate=February 18, 2014}}</ref><ref name="espn">{{cite web | url=http://espn.go.com/golf/masters14/story/_/id/10467524/augusta-national-removes-eisenhower-tree-due-storm-damage | title=Augusta removes Eisenhower Tree |work=[[ESPN]] |first=Bob |last=Harig | date=February 17, 2014 | accessdate=February 17, 2014}}</ref>
The tree was named after President Eisenhower, an Augusta National member, hit the tree while playing golf so many times that, at a 1956 club meeting, he proposed that it be cut down.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://golf.about.com/od/majorchampionships/f/eisenhower-tree.htm |title=Eisenhower Tree: Where is it, and how did it get its name? |work=Golf.About.com}}</ref><ref name="owen">{{cite book | title=The Making of the Masters: Clifford Roberts, Augusta National, and Golf's Most Prestigious Tournament | publisher=Simon & Schuster | last=Owen |first=David | year=1999 | isbn=978-0684867519}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://onpar.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/08/20/the-day-augusta-said-ike-was-out-of-order/ | title=The Day Augusta Said Ike Was Out of Order | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=August 20, 2012 | accessdate=February 17, 2014 |last=Pennington |first=Bill}}</ref> Not wanting to offend the president, the club's chairman, [[Clifford Roberts]], immediately adjourned the meeting rather than reject the request.<ref name="owen" /> Bumper stickers made during Eisenhower's second presidential campaign reading "[[Ben Hogan]] For President. If We're Going To Have A Golfer--Let's Have A Good One!" were a reference to the incident.<ref name=lederer>{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-173373660.html |title=Presidents at Play |work=[[Saturday Evening Post]] |last=Lederer |first=Richard |date=January–February 2008 |volume=280 |issue=1 |accessdate=February 18, 2014}}</ref>
==Golfing history==
The Eisenhower Tree has played a prominent role in the annual [[Masters Tournament]].<ref name="espn" /><ref name="augusta">{{cite news | url=http://chronicle.augusta.com/sports/golf/2014-02-16/masters-landmark-ikes-tree-suffers-major-damage-removed?v=1392572685 | title=Masters landmark Ike's Tree suffers major damage, removed | work=The Augusta Chronicle | date=February 16, 2014 | accessdate=February 17, 2014 | last=Boyette |first=John}}</ref> One year, the Tree came into play as [[Tommy Aaron]] hit a shot off the 17th tee which became known as the "Lost Ball Incident". The ball could not be located and a drop was given. The next day according to Aaron, while playing on the 17th again, the ball apparently fell from its perch within the tree. [[Jack Nicklaus]] stated "I'm not sure I believe it."<ref name="augusta"/>
When the course was redesigned in 1999 to be more challenging, there were concerns about the tree blocking players but it proved not to be a hindrance.<ref>{{cite news |title=Eisenhower Tree no problem |work=[[USA Today]] |first=Ron |last=Kaspriske |date=April 8, 1999}} (Database: [[NewsBank]], Retrieved February 18, 2014 )</ref>
In 2011, [[Tiger Woods]] was playing a shot from underneath the Eisenhower and damaged his left knee and [[Achilles tendon]] when he slipped on some pine straw. The injuries sidelined him until August 2011 and his world ranking dropped to 58th.<ref name="augusta"/>
==Damage and replacement==
In February 2014, the Eisenhower Tree was removed after suffering extensive damage during [[February 11–17, 2014 North American winter storm|a major ice storm]].<ref name="augusta" /> "The loss of the Eisenhower Tree is difficult news to accept", Augusta National chairman [[Billy Payne]] said. "We obtained opinions from the best [[arborist]]s available and … were advised that no recovery was possible."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/golf/2014/02/16/golf-ice-storm-destroys-eisenhower-tree-at-augusta-national/5536517/ |title=Eisenhower Tree removed |work=[[USA Today]] |first=Steve |last=DiMeglio |date=February 17, 2014 |accessdate=February 18, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2014/feb/17/augusta-eisenhower-tree-golf-woods-nicklaus |title='Eisenhower's Tree' is a high-profile victim of severe Augusta weather |work=[[The Guardian]] |location=UK |first=Ewan |last=Murray |date=February 17, 2014 |accessdate=February 18, 2014}}</ref> The storm occurred two months before the Masters Tournament. A remnant of the tree was donated to the Eisenhower Presidential Library in Abilene, KS and is on display.
The loss of the tree brought tributes. Jack Nicklaus said, "The Eisenhower Tree is such an iconic fixture and symbol of tradition at Augusta National. It was such an integral part of the game and one that will be sorely missed."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.weather.com/sports-rec/augusta-national-eisenhower-tree-ice-storm-20140217 |title=Famed 'Eisenhower Tree' at Augusta National Golf Course Felled By Ice From Winter Storm Pax |work=[[The Weather Channel]] |date=February 17, 2014 |accessdate=February 18, 2014}}</ref>
There is another tree named after Eisenhower, located at [[Dalmeny Golf Club]] in [[Scotland]], planted by the President during a visit to [[Edinburgh]] to receive the freedom of the city in 1946. On hearing of the death in Augusta, the club offered to provide an acorn to plant a new oak tree.<ref name="scotsman">{{cite web |url=http://www.scotsman.com/sport/golf/dalmeny-s-acorns-can-grow-a-new-eisenhower-s-tree-1-3309988 |title=Dalmeny’s acorns can grow a new Eisenhower’s Tree |work=[[The Scotsman]] |first=Martin |last=Dempster |date=February 18, 2014 |accessdate=February 21, 2014}}</ref>
A few yards beyond the Eisenhower Tree, another tree was planted a number of years ago.<ref name="espn"/> This tree was also removed due to the ice storm.<ref name="espn"/>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== * [[Joe Posnanski|Posnanski, Joe]] (February 17, 2014). [http://www.golfchannel.com/news/joe-posnanski/ode-eisenhower-tree/ "In Memoriam: Eisenhower's Tree"]. [[Golf Channel|The Golf Channel]]. Accessed March 2014.
==External links== *{{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140307175256/http://img.ly/y4YJ |date=March 7, 2014 |title=Picture of fallen tree }}
{{Dwight D. Eisenhower}}

{{active editnotice}} {{Infobox Song Contest | name = Eurovision Song Contest | year = 1962 | theme = | logo = ESC 1962 logo.png | semi1 = | semi2 = | final = 18 March 1962 | presenters = [[Mireille Delannoy]] | conductor = [[Jean Roderès]] | director = {{ubl|[[Jos Pauly]]|[[René Steichen]]}} | exsupervisor = | winner = {{Esc|France|y=1962}}
"[[Un premier amour]]" | vote = Ten-member juries awarded points to their three favourite songs. | host = [[Compagnie Luxembourgeoise de Télédiffusion]] (CLT) | venue = [[Villa Louvigny]]
[[Luxembourg (city)|Luxembourg City]], [[Luxembourg]] | entries = 16 | debut = None | return = None | withdraw = None | null = {{ubl|{{Esc|Austria}}|{{Esc|Belgium}}|{{Esc|Netherlands}}|{{Esc|Spain|1945}}}} | interval = [[Achille Zavatta]] | opening = | Green = Y | Green SA = | Purple = | Red = | Yellow = Y }} The '''Eurovision Song Contest 1962''' was the seventh edition of the annual [[Eurovision Song Contest]], held on Sunday 18 March 1962 at the [[Villa Louvigny]] in [[Luxembourg (city)|Luxembourg]]. The contest was won for a third time by [[France in the Eurovision Song Contest|France]] with the song "''[[Un premier amour]]''", performed by [[Isabelle Aubret]]. This marked the first time a country had won three contests. [[Austria in the Eurovision Song Contest|Austria]], [[Belgium in the Eurovision Song Contest|Belgium]], [[Netherlands in the Eurovision Song Contest|Netherlands]], and [[Spain in the Eurovision Song Contest|Spain]] all scored "nul points" for the first time.{{cite web|title=Eurovision Song Contest 1962|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=279|publisher=[[EBU]]|accessdate=12 June 2012}} == Location == {{details|topic=the host city|Luxembourg (city)}} [[File:Luxembourg, villa Louvigny.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Villa Louvigny, Luxembourg – host venue of the 1962 contest.]] The 1962 Eurovision Song Contest was hosted in [[Luxembourg City]]. The venue chosen to host the 1962 contest was the Villa Louvigny. The building served as the headquarters of [[Compagnie Luxembourgeoise de Télédiffusion]], the forerunner of [[RTL Group]]. It is located in [[Municipal Park (Luxembourg City)|Municipal Park]], in the [[Ville Haute]] [[Quarters of Luxembourg City|quarter]] of the centre of the city. == Format == After France's entry had been performed, there was a short power failure rendering the screens dark. There also seemed to be an even shorter power failure during the Netherlands entry, when viewers around Europe only saw darkness on their television screens when the Netherlands performed. The power failure seemed to affect the Netherlands score during the voting. Nevertheless, the song turned out to be popular in Europe after the contest. == Participating countries == {{Further information|List of countries in the Eurovision Song Contest}} All countries who participated in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1961]] returned for a second consecutive year, with no new countries making a début, nor any nations returning or withdrawing. === Conductors === Each performance had a [[conducted|conductor]] who [[maestro]] the orchestra.[http://www.andtheconductoris.eu http://www.andtheconductoris.eu] {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} * {{Esc|Finland}} - [[George de Godzinsky]] * {{Esc|Belgium}} - [[Henri Segers]] * {{Esc|Spain|1945}} - [[Jean Roderès]] * {{Esc|Austria}} - [[Bruno Uher]] * {{Esc|Denmark}} - [[Kai Mortensen]] * {{Esc|Sweden}} - [[Egon Kjerrman]] * {{Esc|Germany}} - [[Rolf-Hans Müller]] * {{Esc|Netherlands}} - [[Dolf van der Linden]] * {{Esc|France}} - [[Franck Pourcel]] * {{Esc|Norway}} - [[Øivind Bergh]] * {{Esc|Switzerland}} - [[Cedric Dumont]] * {{Esc|Yugoslavia}} - [[Joze Privsek]] * {{Esc|United Kingdom}} - [[Wally Stott]] * {{Esc|Luxembourg}} - '''[[Jean Roderès]]''' * {{Esc|Italy}} - [[Cinico Angelini]] * {{Esc|Monaco}} - [[Raymond Lefèvre]] {{div col end}} === Returning artists === The contest saw the return of four artists this year, with three artists having previously participated in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1960|1960]]. [[Camillo Felgen]] for [[Luxembourg in the Eurovision Song Contest|Luxembourg]]; [[François Deguelt]] for [[Monaco in the Eurovision Song Contest|Monaco]]; and [[Fud Leclerc]] making his fourth appearance for [[Belgium in the Eurovision Song Contest|Belgium]], having also been present at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1956|1956]] and [[Eurovision Song Contest 1958|1958]] contests. [[Jean Philippe]], having previous represented [[Eurovision Song Contest 1959|France in 1959]], returned to the contest as a representative for Switzerland. ==Results== {| class="sortable wikitable" |- style="background:#ccc;" ! {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2014}} {{Infobox Song Contest | name = Eurovision Song Contest | year = 1997 | logo = Eurovision Song Contest Logo 1997.svg | final = 3 May 1997 | presenters = {{unbulleted list|[[Carrie Crowley]]|[[Ronan Keating]]}} | director = Ian McGarry | exsupervisor = Marie-Claire Vionnet | exproducer = [[Noel Curran]] | conductor = [[Frank McNamara (musician)|Frank McNamara]] | host = [[Raidió Teilifís Éireann]] (RTÉ) | venue = [[Point Theatre]]
[[Dublin]], [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] | winner = {{unbulleted list|{{esc|United Kingdom|y=1997}}|"[[Love Shine a Light]]"}} | vote = Each country awarded 12, 10, 8-1 points to their 10 favourite songs | entries = 25 | debut = None | return = {{unbulleted list|{{Esc|Denmark}}|{{Esc|Germany}}|{{Esc|Hungary}}|{{Esc|Italy}}|{{Esc|Russia}}}} | withdraw = {{unbulleted list|{{Esc|Belgium}}|{{Esc|Finland}}|{{Esc|Slovakia}}}} | null = {{unbulleted list|{{Esc|Norway|y=1997}}|{{Esc|Portugal|y=1997}}}} | interval = "Let The Message Run Free" performed by [[Ronan Keating]] & [[Boyzone]] | opening = | Green = Y | Green SA = | Purple = | Red = | Yellow = Y }} The '''Eurovision Song Contest 1997''', was the 42nd edition of the annual [[Eurovision Song Contest]]. It took place in [[Dublin]], [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]], following [[Eimear Quinn]]'s win at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1996|1996 contest]] in [[Oslo]], [[Norway]] with the song "[[The Voice (Eimear Quinn song)|The Voice]]". This was a record seventh hosting of the event for Ireland, and the fourth in five years. The contest was held at the [[Point Theatre]] on 3 May 1997. [[Carrie Crowley]] and [[Boyzone]] member [[Ronan Keating]] were the presenters of the show.{{cite web|title=Eurovision Song Contest 1997|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=312|website=eurovision.tv|publisher=European Broadcasting Union|accessdate=21 October 2014|date=3 May 1997}} Twenty-five countries took part in the 1997 Contest, which saw {{Esccnty|Italy}} return after a three-year absence - the last participation being in {{Escyr|1993|three-year absence}},{{cite web|title=Italy 1993|url=http://www.esc-history.com/details.asp?key=698|website=esc-history.com|publisher=ESC History|accessdate=21 October 2014}} along with {{Esccnty|Denmark}}, {{Esccnty|Germany}}, {{Esccnty|Hungary}}, and {{Esccnty|Russia}}, who last took part in {{Escyr|1995|1995 Contest}}, despite having taken part in the non-televised [[Eurovision Song Contest 1996#Pre-qualifying round|1996 pre-qualifying round]] in which they failed to qualify and therefore were absent.{{cite web|title=Eurovision Song Contest 1996|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=311|website=eurovision.tv|publisher=European Broadcasting Union|accessdate=21 October 2014|date=18 May 1996}} {{Esccnty|Belgium}}, {{Esccnty|Finland}}, and {{Esccnty|Slovakia}} had to withdraw from the contest due to the [[Rules of the Eurovision Song Contest#Rule changes by year|relegation rule]]. The [[United Kingdom]] won the competition, thanks to [[Katrina and the Waves]], led by American-born [[Katrina Leskanich]], making it the second time that the British won the Eurovision on Irish soil (after [[Eurovision Song Contest 1981|1981]]). It also remains the last time the United Kingdom won the contest (as of 2018). == Location == {{details|topic=the host city|Dublin}} [[File:3_Arena_Front.JPG|thumb|200px|left|The Point Theatre, Dublin – host venue of the 1997 contest.]] [[Ireland]] hosted the contest for the fourth time in five years after winning the {{Escyr|1996|1996 contest}} in Oslo. Dublin was chosen to be the host city, making it the sixth time that the Eurovision Song Contest was staged in the Irish capital. The venue for the contest was the [[Point Theatre]] located on the North Wall Quay of the [[River Liffey]], amongst the [[Dublin Docklands]]. The theatre previously hosted the {{Escyr|1994}} and {{Escyr|1995}} contests. The Point Theatre is the only venue to have hosted the final three times. ==Format== After the controversy over the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1996#Pre-qualifying round|1996 pre-qualifying round]], the [[European Broadcasting Union]] introduced a new system for 1997: countries with the lowest average scores over the previous four years would be excluded from the 1997 contest, and those with the lowest averages over the previous five years would be excluded from future contests (save that every country so excluded for one year would automatically be allowed to participate the following year), with so many countries being omitted as would reduce the number of participants each year to 25. Israel declined to participate, as the Contest was held on its [[Yom HaShoah|Holocaust Remembrance Day]], granting a reprieve to Bosnia and Herzegovina, which would otherwise have been excluded owing to its low point average over the previous four years. RTÉ once again produced a highly spectacular show, with a stage that had a smaller performance space for the artists than in previous years. This was the third Eurovision set to be designed by Paula Farrell, who had previously been involved with the 1988 and 1994 contests. There was a wide array of different styles this year. Denmark brought a [[hip hop music|rap]] song, Croatia came with their version of the [[Spice Girls]] and Sweden brought a mid-1980s style [[boy band]]. The music was in general more modern than before, and for the first time since {{Escyr|1991|six years}}, an [[up-tempo]] song won. This year, [[Televoting#Televoting in the Eurovision Song Contest|televoting]] was tested in five countries: Austria, Germany, Sweden, Switzerland and the United Kingdom. The results of the televoting countries were, in some cases, different from those that used a jury. Iceland received 16 of its 18 points from these five countries. Also, for the first time in Eurovision history, there was a country where not one, but two spokespeople gave votes - France. Television reporter [[Frédéric Ferrer]] and {{Escyr|1977}} Eurovision winner [[Marie Myriam]] each took turns at giving results from that country. Long-time Irish conductor [[Noel Kelehan]] was not the host conductor this year, the duty being fulfilled by [[Frank McNamara (musician)|Frank McNamara]]. ==Returning artists== {| class="wikitable" |- ! (band)|E.N.I.]] | "[[Probudi me]]" | [[Croatian language|Croatian]] | 17 | 24 |- style="font-weight:bold; background: gold;" | 24 | {{Esc|United Kingdom|y=1997}} | [[Katrina and the Waves]] | "[[Love Shine a Light]]" | English | 1 | 227 |- | 25 | {{Esc|Iceland|y=1997}} | [[Paul Oscar]] | "[[Minn hinsti dans]]" | [[Icelandic language|Icelandic]] | 20 | 18 |} :1.{{note|a}}{{note|b}} Contained some lyrics in English. ==Scoreboard== Each country had a jury that awarded 12, 10, 8, 7, 6, 5, 4, 3, 2, 1 points for their top ten songs, or a televote, where the top ten most voted for songs were awarded the 12, 10, 8, 7, 6, 5, 4, 3, 2, 1 points. Iceland got most of its 18 points from the 5 countries that used televoting. Ireland was ostensibly the best scoring country across the televoting countries, except they were able to score points from all 5 televoting countries. The United Kingdom was only eligible to receive points from 4 of them, since they couldn't vote for themselves. In fact, the UK received 12 points from all the other televoting countries except Germany, from whom they received 10 points: in other words, the UK earned 46 of 48 possible televote points that year; Ireland earned 47 of 60 possible televote points—including their only 12 from the UK. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- | colspan=2 rowspan=2 | Voting procedure used:

Voting nation |- | 10 || '''[[United Kingdom in the Eurovision Song Contest 1997|United Kingdom]]''' || Austria, Croatia, Denmark, France, Hungary, Ireland, Netherlands, Russia, Sweden, Switzerland |- |rowspan=2| 3 | [[France in the Eurovision Song Contest 1997|France]] || Estonia, Norway, Poland |- | [[Turkey in the Eurovision Song Contest 1997|Turkey]] || Bosnia and Herzegovina, Germany, Spain |- | 2 || [[Cyprus in the Eurovision Song Contest 1997|Cyprus]] || Greece, Iceland |- |rowspan=7| 1 | [[Estonia in the Eurovision Song Contest 1997|Estonia]] || Italy |- | [[Greece in the Eurovision Song Contest 1997|Greece]] || Cyprus |- | [[Ireland in the Eurovision Song Contest 1997|Ireland]] || United Kingdom |- | [[Italy in the Eurovision Song Contest 1997|Italy]] || Portugal |- | [[Malta in the Eurovision Song Contest 1997|Malta]] || Turkey |- | [[Russia in the Eurovision Song Contest 1997|Russia]] || Slovenia |- | [[Spain in the Eurovision Song Contest 1997|Spain]] || Malta |} ==Winners== [[Katrina and the Waves]], (with lead vocalist [[Katrina Leskanich]]) representing the United Kingdom, were the winners of the contest with the song "[[Love Shine a Light]]", written by that band's lead guitarist [[Kimberley Rew]], and [[Marc Roberts (singer-songwriter)|Marc Roberts]] from Republic of Ireland came second with "[[Mysterious Woman]]". Despite being the runner-up, it remarkably received only one 12-point score, which came from the United Kingdom. The UK spokesman [[Colin Berry]] remarked: "You're going to like this one: Ireland, twelve points!" causing [[Terry Wogan]] to reply: "Well, tit for tat!" The winning song scored an unprecedented 227 points; it received points from all participating countries, including five sets of 10 points and a record-breaking ten sets of the maximum 12 points. "Love Shine a Light" is still regarded as one of the most successful Eurovision winners,As noted on a [[TOTP2]] Eurovision special, it ranks third in the rankings of points achieved as a percentage of maximum available with 227 out of 288 or 78.81%, behind [[Nicole (German singer)|Nicole]]'s "[[Ein bißchen Frieden]]" in [[Eurovision Song Contest 1982|1982]] (161 out of 204 or 78.92%) and [[Brotherhood of Man]]'s "[[Save Your Kisses for Me]]" in [[Eurovision Song Contest 1976|1976]] (164 out of 204 or 80.39%). For comparison, Elena Paparizou's 2005 win took 230 points out of a possible 456, or only 50.04%. and was the closing song in the medleys that opened the 50th anniversary show "[[Congratulations (Eurovision)|Congratulations]]" in [[Copenhagen]] in 2005, and the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2006|ESC 2006]] semi-final in [[Athens]]. With this victory, the United Kingdom has five Eurovision wins and it is to date the country's last win in the Contest. ==Barbara Dex Award== For the first time, the fansite House of Eurovision presented the [[Barbara Dex Award]], a humorous award given to the worst dressed artist each year in the contest. It is named after the Belgian artist, [[Barbara Dex]], who came last in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1993|1993 contest]], in which she wore her own self designed dress. House of Eurovision would continue to provide the Barbara Dex Award until [[Eurovision Song Contest 2016|2016]], when another Eurovision fansite, songfestival.be, took the reins of the award and will present it every year starting with the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2017|2017 Eurovision Song Contest]] in Ukraine. [[Debbie Scerri]] of Malta was the 1997 Barbara Dex Award winner. ==International broadcasts and voting== ===Voting and spokespersons=== The order in which each country announced their votes was determined by order of performance in the contest.
