[[File:Fema trailer 2 Mariel Carr Chemical Heritage Foundation Video.jpg|right|thumb|200px|A FEMA trailer]]
The term '''FEMA trailer''',<ref name=FEMAPickup>{{cite web|title=FEMA-1603-417: FEMA: Important Phone Numbers for FEMA Travel Trailer Occupants|url=http://www.fema.gov/news-release/2006/03/25/important-phone-numbers-fema-travel-trailer-occupants|website=FEMA.gov|publisher=Federal Emergency Management Agency|date=March 25, 2006}}</ref><ref name=FEMAwaveland>{{cite news|last1=Stuckey|first1=Mike|title=New life in a FEMA trailer|url=http://risingfromruin.msnbc.com/2005/10/new_life_in_a_f.html|accessdate=11 September 2015|work=MSNBC News|issue=Rising from Ruin|date=October 25, 2005}}</ref> or '''FEMA travel trailer''', is the name commonly given by the [[United States Government]]<ref name=FEMAChristmas>{{cite web|title=Safety Precautions Advised For Fema Travel Trailer Residents|url=http://www.fema.gov/news-release/2006/12/11/safety-precautions-advised-fema-travel-trailer-residents|website=FEMA.gov|publisher=Federal Emergency Management Agency|accessdate=11 September 2015|date=December 11, 2006}}</ref> to forms of temporary [[manufactured housing]] assigned to the victims of [[natural disaster]] by the [[Federal Emergency Management Agency]] (FEMA). Such trailers are intended to provide intermediate term shelter, functioning longer than [[tents]] which are often used for short-term shelter immediately following a disaster. FEMA trailers serve a similar function to the "earthquake shacks" erected to provide interim housing after the [[1906 San Francisco earthquake]].<ref name=Brown>{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Joseph Darnell|title=A Minimalistic Approach to Adaptive, Emergency Relief Structures Embodied by Promoting a Downsized Way of Life|date=August 3, 2013|publisher=Auburn University (Thesis)|location=Auburn, Alabama|url=https://etd.auburn.edu/bitstream/handle/10415/3705/Joseph%20D.%20Brown%20Final%20Thesis%20Document.pdf}}</ref>{{rp|55}}<ref name=Rafkin>{{cite news|last1=Rafkin|first1=Louise|title=Earthquake Refugee Cottages|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/05/us/cottages-from-1906-san-francisco-quake-are-preserved.html?_r=0|accessdate=11 September 2015|work=The Texas Tribune|date=February 4, 2012}}</ref><ref name=Shacks>{{cite web|title=1906 Earthquake Refugee Shacks|url=http://www.outsidelands.org/shacks.php|website=The Western Neighborhoods Project|accessdate=11 September 2015}}</ref>
FEMA trailers were used to house thousands of people in South [[Florida]] displaced by [[Hurricane Andrew]] in August 1992, some for as long as two and a half years.<ref name=FEMAandrew>{{cite news|last1=Navarro|first1=Mireya|title=New Housing for Hurricane's Last Victims|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/27/us/new-housing-for-hurricane-s-last-victims.html|accessdate=11 September 2015|work=[[The New York Times]]|page=A10|date=February 27, 1995}}</ref> After [[Hurricane Charley]] in 2004, 17,000 FEMA-issued trailers and mobile homes were successfully deployed.<ref name=LTR-06-044>{{cite web|title=Release LTR-06-044: FEMA Concludes 2004 Housing Transition Effort In Florida|url=http://www.fema.gov/news-release/2006/11/02/fema-concludes-2004-housing-transition-effort-florida|website=Federal Emergency Management Agency|date=November 2, 2006}}</ref> At least 145,000 trailers were bought by FEMA to house survivors who lost their homes during the [[2005 Atlantic hurricane season]] due to [[Hurricane Katrina]] and [[Hurricane Rita]].<ref name=Watson>{{cite news|last1=Watson|first1=Bruce|title=The Awful Odyssey of FEMA's Hurricane Katrina Trailers|url=http://www.dailyfinance.com/2010/08/28/the-awful-odyssey-of-femas-hurricane-katrina-trailers/|accessdate=11 September 2015|work=Daily Finance|agency=AOL.com|date=August 28, 2010}}</ref> FEMA trailers were also made available after extensive flooding in parts of [[New York (state)|New York]], [[Pennsylvania]], and [[New Jersey]] due to [[Superstorm Sandy]] in 2012.<ref name=Pearson>{{cite news|last1=Pearson|first1=Erica|last2=Durkin|first2=Erin|last3=Connor|first3=Tracy|title=Feds may put up FEMA trailers in New York to house tens of thousands whose homes were devastated in superstorm Sandy|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/feds-put-fema-trailers-new-york-sandy-victims-article-1.1196863|accessdate=14 September 2015|work=New York Daily News|date=November 5, 2012}}</ref><ref name=Haddon>{{cite news|last1=Haddon|first1=Heather|title=New York City Shuns Trailers Welcomed in N.J.|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324478304578173751529176608|accessdate=14 September 2015|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=December 12, 2012}}</ref>
News reports of health issues relating to Katrina-issue FEMA trailers began to appear in July 2006.<ref name=TinCan/> A federal report in July 2008 identified toxic levels of [[formaldehyde]] in 42% of the trailers examined, attributing problems to poor construction and substandard building materials.<ref name="Hsu2"/> As of 2012, two class-action lawsuits were settled, between residents of Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama and Texas, and (1) manufacturers who built mobile homes for the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) and (2) FEMA contractors who installed and maintained them.<ref name=Brunker/>
FEMA trailers are the property of the U.S. Government and are expected to be returned after use. In 1995, some Florida residents who had difficulty finding accommodation in the aftermath of [[Hurricane Andrew]] "bought their FEMA trailers for an average of $1,100 each."<ref name=FEMAandrew/> Following Hurricanes Katrina and Rita, the U.S. Government was left with large numbers of FEMA trailers. Surplus FEMA trailers were sold via online public auctions conducted by the [[General Services Administration]]. The distribution and resale of Katrina FEMA trailers has been heavily criticized given the possible health risks involved.<ref name=Cohen>{{cite news|last1=Cohen|first1=Ariella|title=Despite health fears, trailers are housing disaster victims|url=http://thelensnola.org/2011/05/19/fema-trailers-formaldehyde-katrina-rita-tuscaloosa-tornadoe/|accessdate=14 September 2015|work=The Lens|date=May 19, 2011}}</ref>
Since 2012, FEMA has modified its model for responding to storms. It provides money for temporary housing or repairs to get through the emergency, and treats FEMA trailers as a "last resort".<ref name="Schmall">{{cite news|last1=Schmall|first1=Emily|last2=Bajak|first2=Frank|title=FEMA sees trailers only as last resort after Harvey, Irma|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/fema-sees-trailers-resort-harvey-irma-49742355|accessdate=14 September 2017|work=ABC News|date=September 10, 2017}}</ref>
== Description == [[File:UptownNapoleonFEMAtrailerFlag.jpg|right|thumb|200px|A '''FEMA trailer''' ([[travel trailer]]) in front of a formerly flooded house in New Orleans.]]
Although several types and sizes of manufactured structures have been installed throughout the Gulf Coast region, most are [[Mass production|mass-produced]], one-bedroom [[travel trailer]]s. These typical FEMA trailers are designed to accommodate two adults and two children. There are larger trailers and other manufactured structures that can accommodate larger families.
A typical FEMA trailer can measure 14' by 22' (308 sq. ft.)<ref name=Brown/>{{rp|56}} or 8' by 32' (256 sq. ft.).<ref name=Browne/>{{rp|83}} It consists of a master bedroom with a standard size bed, a living area with kitchen and stove, bunk beds, and a bathroom with shower. Each trailer is equipped with electricity, air conditioning, indoor heating, running cold and hot water, a propane-operated stove and oven, a small microwave oven, a large refrigerator, and a few pieces of furniture attached to the floor; usually a sofabed, a small table, and two chairs. There are only a handful of FEMA trailer designs, so nearly all trailers have the same general layout. Furniture is attached to the trailer; it is not possible to move it, and it would be illegal to do so. It is also illegal to paint the inside or outside of the trailer.<ref name=Browne>{{cite book|last1=Browne|first1=Katherine E.|title=Standing in the Need Culture, Comfort, and Coming Home after Katrina|date=2015|publisher=University of Texas Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=18BjCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA77}}</ref>{{rp|82–86}} Trailers have little storage space, can be very cramped, and offer little or no privacy.<ref name=Browne/><ref name=Kunzelman>{{cite news|last1=Kunzelman|first1=Michael|title=A new normal' life for family sharing FEMA trailers|url=http://djournal.com/news/a-new-normal-life-for-family-sharing-fema-trailers/|accessdate=17 September 2015|work=Northeast Mississippi Daily Journal|date=March 26, 2006}}</ref><ref name=Peacock>{{cite book|editor-last1=Peacock|editor-first1=Walter Gillis|title=Hurricane Andrew : ethnicity, gender and the sociology of disasters|date=1997|publisher=Routledge|location=London|isbn=978-0415168113|pages=129–131|edition=1st|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sLw8XmpRnhoC&pg=PA129|accessdate=17 September 2015}}</ref>
Each trailer is elevated about two feet (0.6 m) above the ground, on concrete supports. There is only one door on the side of each trailer, which is accessible through a wooden or aluminum stairwell. There are also [[Inclined plane|long ramps]] for wheelchair-using occupants. [[Electric power transmission|Electrical service]] to the FEMA trailers is installed by the local power company. (For example, in most of the Gulf Coast region power is provided by the [[Entergy|Entergy Corporation]].) Each trailer has its own [[Electricity meter|power meter]]. Trailers have ports for telephone access, [[Cable television|cable]], and [[Internet access]]. However, these services are not handled by FEMA, and a trailer occupant must arrange to have these services installed by a local provider.<ref name=Brown/>
The typical FEMA trailer has two [[Propane#Uses|propane tanks]] on the front of the trailer behind the master bedroom, which provide the hot water, indoor heating, and gas for the stove and oven. Running water for the trailer is usually provided by some sort of [[Water supply network|water source on the property]], usually through a garden hose. [[Sewage]] is piped directly to an [[Waste management|underground sewage main]] on the property. Most trailers have several windows which can be opened, as well as small light fixtures in each room.<ref name=Brown/>
FEMA trailers are manufactured from plastic, aluminum, and particle board, and are therefore somewhat flimsy and require more maintenance than a permanent structure. They are also poorly insulated, offer little sound insulation, and are known to sway in high winds.<ref name=Reeder>{{cite web|last1=Reeder|first1=Linda|title=Enough Already: Katrina, FEMA Trailers, and the Road Forward|url=http://www.aia.org/akr/Resources/Documents/AIAP037883|website=The American Institute of Architects}}</ref>
While occupying FEMA travel trailers or [[mobile home]]s, residents are responsible for maintaining their trailers, such as keeping the trailers clean, changing lightbulbs and [[smoke detector|smoke-detector]] batteries, and making sure [[Propane#Uses|propane fuel tanks]] are refilled with fuel.<ref name=FEMAPickup/>
Travel trailers and mobile homes are to be inspected once a month for the occupant's safety and convenience: if a travel trailer or mobile home requires maintenance beyond basic upkeep, residents are told to call the appropriate travel trailer maintenance hotline for their [[civil parish|parish]] or county.<ref name=FEMAPickup/> In Houston, 1200 of the 4600 trailers initially issued after Hurricane Rita required serious repairs by late 2006.<ref name=Houstonian>{{cite news|title=Users damaged 1,200 FEMA trailers since Rita, agency says|url=http://houstonianonline.com/2006/11/02/users-damaged-1200-fema-trailers-since-rita-agency-says/|work=The Houstonian|date=November 2, 2006}}</ref>
== Need == [[File:FEMA - 23268 - Photograph by Marvin Nauman taken on 04-03-2006 in Louisiana.jpg|right|thumb|200px|A [[Southern University at New Orleans]] professor moves into a FEMA trailer in April 2006, more than half a year after Katrina.]]
FEMA trailers are intended to provide temporary housing for homeowners after a disaster, until they can repair or rebuild their homes.<ref name=FEMAwaveland/> Hurricanes, tornadoes, floods and other natural disasters can cause extensive damage to residential neighborhoods, as occurred in 2005 because of Hurricane Katrina.<ref name=Knabb>{{cite book|last1=Knabb|first1=Richard D.|last2=Rhome|first2=Jamie R.|last3=Brown|first3=Daniel P.|title=Tropical Cyclone Report Hurricane Katrina 23 - 30 August 2005 (updated 10 August 2006) |date=10 August 2006|publisher=National Hurricane Center|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL122005_Katrina}}|accessdate=11 September 2015}}</ref><ref name=NWSKat> [[US Department of Commerce]], "Service Assessment: Hurricane Katrina August 23–31, 2005" (June 2006), pp. 10/16, [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|NOAA]]’s National Weather Service, [[Silver Spring, Maryland|Silver Spring]], MD, webpage: [http://www.weather.gov/om/assessments/pdfs/Katrina.pdf NWS-PDF] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060723034359/http://www.weather.gov/om/assessments/pdfs/Katrina.pdf |date=2006-07-23 }}: page 7 (surge 26-28 feet, 9 m), page 50: "Appendix C: Tornado Reports Associated with Hurricane Katrina" (62 tornadoes). </ref><ref name=CNN360Tuchman29> Gary Tuchman, Transcript of "Anderson Cooper 360 Degrees" (2006-08-29) 19:00 ET, ''CNN'', CNN.com webpage: [http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0508/29/acd.01.html CNN-ACooper082906]: GARY TUCHMAN, CNN Correspondent: Responds to Anderson Cooper that it felt like it would never end, saying winds were at least 100 miles per hour in Gulfport for seven hours, between about 7:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m. For another five or six hours, on each side of that, they [Gulfport] had hurricane-force winds over 75 miles per hour; much of the city [Gulfport, Mississippi, in Harrison County] of 71,000 was then under water. </ref>
Damaged areas may take substantial periods of time to repair. Residents may be unable to return home for long periods of time while local government officials attempt to restore basic infrastructure for water and electricity.<ref name=Becker>{{cite journal|last1=Becker|first1=Christine|title=Disaster recovery: a local government responsibility|journal=PM Magazine|date=2009|volume=91|issue=2|url=http://webapps.icma.org/pm/9102/public/cover.cfm?author=christine%20becker&title=disaster%20recovery%3A%20%20a%20local%20government%20responsibility|accessdate=17 September 2015}}</ref> Flood damage to existing homes and apartments may require the complete removal and replacement of carpeting, [[Laminate flooring|flooring]], [[Building insulation|insulation]], and [[Drywall|sheetrock]].<ref name=AmericanRedCross>{{cite web|title=Repairing Your Flooded Home|url=http://www.redcross.org/images/MEDIA_CustomProductCatalog/m4540081_repairingFloodedHome.pdf|website=American Red Cross|accessdate=17 September 2015}}</ref> Flood damage beyond a few inches may also destroy furniture, appliances, and other personal belongings. Buildings that have sustained significant water damage, including apartment complexes, often require extensive rebuilding and a mold-removal process known as "[[mold remediation]]" before they can be rendered safe enough for habitation.<ref name=MoldRemediation>{{cite web|title=Mold Remediation |url=http://www.fema.gov/9500-series-policy-publications/mold-remediation |website=FEMA.gov |accessdate=17 September 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150905174615/http://www.fema.gov/9500-series-policy-publications/mold-remediation |archivedate=5 September 2015 |df= }}</ref> Roofs may also need to be replaced or repaired.
Widespread damage in an area may cause extreme housing shortages. The extent of the rebuilding effort in such an area may cause a shortage of [[General contractor|building contractors]] and materials throughout the region. This further delays the construction of new housing, and increases a need for existing apartments or motels to house incoming construction and service workers. Leasing rates for apartments may become prohibitively high for those who have lost their homes, particularly [[working class]] storm victims.<ref name=Chang>{{cite journal|last1=Chang|first1=Yan|last2=[[Suzanne Jane Wilkinson|Wilkinson]]|first2=Suzanne|last3=Potangaroa|first3=Regan|last4=Seville|first4=Erica|title=Resourcing challenges for post-disaster housing reconstruction: a comparative analysis|journal=Building Research & Information|date=June 2010|volume=38|issue=3|pages=247–264|doi=10.1080/09613211003693945|url=http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.462.1617&rep=rep1&type=pdf|accessdate=17 September 2015}}</ref><ref name=Esnard>{{cite book|last1=Esnard|first1=Ann-Margaret|last2=Sapat|first2=Alka|title=Displaced by disaster : recovery and resilience in a globalizing world|date=2014|isbn=978-0415856041|url=http://www.erica.demon.co.uk/EV/reviews/131_Esnard.pdf}}</ref> FEMA trailers, which are offered rent-free, may be the only form of [[List of house types|habitable dwellings]] available to those within a disaster area. In 2005, "the devastation of housing in [[New Orleans, Louisiana|New Orleans]] and surrounding communities was so widespread that large numbers of the displaced had few options but to take up residence in FEMA parks" following [[Flood|extreme flood damage]].<ref name=Lee>{{cite journal|last1=Lee|first1=Matthew R.|last2=Weil|first2=Frederick D.|last3=Shihadeh|first3=Edward S.|title=The FEMA Trailer Parks: Negative Perceptions and the Social Structure of Avoidance|journal=Sociological Spectrum|date=2007|volume=27|pages=741–766|doi=10.1080/02732170701534242|url=http://www.lsu.edu/fweil/LeeWeilShihadeh-FEMATrailerParks.pdf|accessdate=17 September 2015}}</ref> FEMA trailer occupants reported that they preferred the trailers to living in cars, tents, partially gutted homes, and the crowded homes of relatives.<ref name=FEMAwaveland/><ref name=Martinez>{{cite news|last1=Martinez|first1=Humberto|title=FEMA trailer Christmas keeps family's spirits bright|url=http://www.beaumontenterprise.com/entertainment/article/FEMA-trailer-Christmas-keeps-family-s-spirits-702203.php|accessdate=17 September 2015|work=Beaumont Enterprise|date=December 20, 2008}}</ref>
FEMA policy generally allows residents to live in a FEMA trailer for a period of 18 months, beginning at the time at which they receive access to the trailer. However, this period has sometimes been extended when availability of housing continued to be a serious problem for a longer time.<ref name=FEMAwaveland/> In the case of Hurricane Katrina in August 2005, deadlines were extended to allow people to live in trailers for up to 45 months.<ref name=FiveDollars/>
== Application process == People within a disaster area are eligible to apply for various forms of "Housing assistance" from the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA). These may include: (1) reimbursement for short term hotel expenses (2) money or vouchers towards rental of a place to live for up to 18 months while your home is being repaired (3) money to make repairs to your home (4) money to purchase a new home if your home cannot be repaired (5) a temporary "FEMA-owned manufactured housing unit" as a last resort if no other housing options are available.<ref name=WhatIsAssistance>{{cite web|title=What Specific Items are Covered by "Housing Assistance"? |url=http://www.fema.gov/apply-assistance/what-specific-items-are-covered-housing-assistance |website=FEMA.org |accessdate=17 September 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150906021921/https://www.fema.gov/apply-assistance/what-specific-items-are-covered-housing-assistance |archivedate=6 September 2015 |df= }}</ref>
To obtain disaster manufactured housing, someone must complete a FEMA application, after which they will be interviewed by a FEMA adjuster, who is similar to an [[Claims adjuster|insurance claims adjuster]]. The adjuster will determine if the damage to the home warrants temporary housing until the home is repaired.<ref name=Tulane>{{cite web|title=FEMA Information |url=http://www.tulane.edu/info_fema.html |website=Tulane University |accessdate=17 September 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304113301/http://www.tulane.edu/info_fema.html |archivedate=4 March 2016 |df= }}</ref> After approval, the applicant is placed on a waiting list.
== Installation == [[File:Yscloskey36.jpg|right|thumb|200px|FEMA trailer (''at left'') alongside a Katrina-damaged house in St. Bernard Parish, Louisiana]] [[File:Uptown25Jan06FEMAtrailerPark1.jpg|right|thumb|200px|FEMA trailer park, in what had been a neighborhood [[playground]].]]
FEMA requires that a property must have running water and power BEFORE a trailer can be installed. Utilities must be available at the site: FEMA will not install trailers in neighborhoods that have no access to running water or electricity.<ref name=DailyComet>{{cite news|title=How to get a FEMA trailer (be prepared to wait)|url=http://www.dailycomet.com/article/20051021/HURBLOG/51022002|accessdate=17 September 2015|work=Daily Comet|date=October 21, 2005}}</ref>
FEMA subcontracts the installation of FEMA trailers to numerous private contractors. First, a subcontractor installs the trailer itself. After this, other contractors install the access stairs or ramps, furniture, home appliances, and water. Next, the power company must be contacted to install a power line and power meter for the trailer. Finally, a FEMA inspector will inspect the trailer for safety compliance. Only after this lengthy process, will the occupant receive the keys for their trailer.<ref name=Entergy>{{cite web|title=FEMA Trailers|url=http://www.entergy-neworleans.com/your_home/storm_center/FEMA_trailers.aspx|website=Entergy News|accessdate=17 September 2015}}</ref>
Many FEMA trailers are installed on the private property of homeowners, usually on lawns and sometimes in driveways next to the house. However, there are also numerous FEMA operated [[trailer park]]s where many storm victims have been living.<ref name=McCarthy>{{cite book|last1=McCarthy|first1=Francis X.|title=FEMA Disaster Housing: From Sheltering to Permanent Housing|date=August 27, 2010|publisher=Congressional Research Service|location=Washington, D.C.|url=https://www.fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/R40810.pdf}}</ref><ref name=NoWay>{{cite book|last1=The Louisiana Justice Institute|title=NO WAY TO TREAT OUR PEOPLE: FEMA Trailer Residents 30 Months after Katrina|date=2008|url=http://www.louisianajusticeinstitute.org/files/all/docs/LJI_FEMA_Trailer_Report_Publication.pdf|accessdate=17 September 2015}}</ref>
The trailer parks operated by FEMA range from small lots, consisting of a dozen trailers in the parking lots of office buildings and supermarkets, to several massive parks occupying large plots of land with hundreds of trailers. In some cases larger parks are surrounded by a [[Chain link fencing|chain-link fence]] and [[Security lighting|brightly lit]]. FEMA has also provided police security and controlled access to the larger parks.<ref name=Adams>{{cite book|last1=Adams|first1=Vincanne|title=Markets of sorrow, labors of faith : New Orleans in the wake of Katrina|date=2013|publisher=Duke University Press|location=Durham and London|isbn=978-0822354499|page=40|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pTvGAcSEn4gC&pg=PA40|accessdate=17 September 2015}}</ref> FEMA trailer parks have developed into small communities, with both the benefits and problems that are involved.<ref name=Browne/><ref name=Peacock/><ref name=NoWay/><ref name=Adams/>
==Health problems== {{external media | width = 210px | align = right | headerimage= [[File:Fema trailer 1 Mariel Carr Chemical Heritage Foundation Video.jpg|200px]] | video1 = [https://www.sciencehistory.org/distillations/video/where-have-all-the-trailers-gone ''Where Have All the Trailers Gone?''], Video by Mariel Carr (Videographer) & Nick Shapiro (Researcher), 2015, [[Science History Institute]] | audio1 = [https://www.sciencehistory.org/distillations/podcast/where-have-all-the-fema-trailers-gone"Episode 202: Where Have All the FEMA Trailers Gone? Tracing Toxicity from Bust to Boom"], ''Distillations'', September 2, 2015, [[Science History Institute]]}}
Reports of health problems in the FEMA trailers deployed in 2005 had begun to appear by July 2006. Residents reported breathing difficulties, persistent flu-like symptoms, eye irritation, and nosebleeds. The cause was suspected to be high [[formaldehyde]] levels in the trailers.<ref name=TinCan>{{cite news|last1=Brunker|first1=Mike|title=Are FEMA trailers 'toxic tin cans'? Private testing finds high levels of formaldehyde; residents report illnesses|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/14011193/ns/us_news-katrina_the_long_road_back/t/are-fema-trailers-toxic-tin-cans/|accessdate=11 September 2015|work=MSNBC.com|date=July 25, 2006}}</ref> Formaldehyde was known to increase risk of cancer, asthma and other respiratory problems,<ref name="Hsu2"/> and children and the elderly were at greater risk.<ref name=TinCan/> As of 2008, FEMA was reported to have received 11,000 health complaints.<ref name="Hsu2"/>
Scientists suspected that the rush to produce large numbers of trailers might have caused manufacturers to cut corners—using low-cost or poorly prepared materials such as glues and pressed wood in construction of the trailers, and resulting in high levels of formaldehyde emissions.<ref name=Dilanian/><ref name=Hsu>{{cite news|last1=Hsu|first1=Spencer S.|title=Safety Lapses Raised Risks In Trailers for Katrina Victims|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/05/24/AR2008052401973.html|accessdate=11 September 2015|work=Washington Post|date=2008-05-25}}</ref> In 2007, tests on a number of FEMA trailers by the [[Sierra Club]] showed 83% had levels of formaldehyde in the indoor air at levels above the EPA recommended limit.<ref name=Dilanian>{{cite journal|last1=Dilanian|first1=Ken|title=FEMA blasted over trailer toxins|journal=USA Today|date=July 19, 2007|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/washington/2007-07-19-trailers_N.htm|accessdate=11 September 2015}}</ref><ref name=USGPO>{{cite book|last1=United States|title=Federal housing response to Hurricane Katrina : hearing before the Committee on Financial Services, U.S. House of Representatives, One Hundred Tenth Congress, first session, February 06, 2007.|date=2007|publisher=U.S. G.P.O.|location=Washington|isbn=9780160786358|url=http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/005567067}}</ref> Congressmen [[Henry Waxman]] and [[Charlie Melancon]] requested that FEMA test the trailers and address the issue.<ref name=Dying>{{cite news|last1=Spake|first1=Amanda|title=Dying for a Home: Toxic Trailers Are Making Katrina Refugees Ill|url=http://www.thenation.com/article/dying-home|accessdate=11 September 2015|work=The Nation|date=February 14, 2007}}</ref>
The United States [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|Centers For Disease Control and Prevention]] (CDC) performed indoor air quality testing for formaldehyde in some of the units. On February 14, 2008, the CDC published a preliminary report confirming that potentially hazardous levels of formaldehyde were found in many of the travel trailers and manufactured homes provided by FEMA.<ref name=CDC>[https://web.archive.org/web/20080611220238/http://www.cdc.gov/nceh/ehhe/trailerstudy/pdfs/SummaryofStudyFindings.pdf Formaldehyde Levels in FEMA-Supplied Trailers (PDF)]</ref> In July 2008, researchers conducting a federally funded analysis reported that the toxic levels of formaldehyde were found in 42% of the trailers tested, and that they were attributable to faulty construction practices and the use of substandard building materials.<ref name="Hsu2">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/07/02/AR2008070202800.html?hpid=sec-health |title=Toxicity in FEMA Trailers Blamed on Cheap Materials, Low Construction Standards |first=Spencer S. |last=Hsu |work=Washington Post |date=2008-07-03}}</ref>
As a result, FEMA modified its specifications for emergency housing, requiring that units be larger and better ventilated.<ref name=Cohen/> Construction of "manufactured homes" provided in New Jersey in 2012 was regulated by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development.<ref name=Vilensky>{{cite news|last1=Vilensky|first1=Mike|last2=Maloney|first2=Jennifer|title=What's in a Name? A Lot, for FEMA's Housing Units|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887323551004578121180557683270|accessdate=17 September 2015|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=November 16, 2012}}</ref> Researchers are also investigating possibilities for better disaster housing alternatives.<ref name=FAS>{{cite web|title=A Response to Katrina: The making of the largest, most efficient modular building order in US history...|url=https://fas.org/programs/energy/btech/about/MEMA%20AHPP%20Article.pdf|accessdate=17 September 2015|website=Federation of American Scientists|date=24 June 2014}}</ref><ref name=Clark>{{cite news|last1=Clark|first1=Steve|title=Disaster Pilot Project Seeks Better Alternative to FEMA Trailers|url=http://www.emergencymgmt.com/disaster/Disaster-Pilot-Project-Seeks-Alternative-FEMA-Trailers.html|accessdate=17 September 2015|work=The Brownsville Herald|date=June 18, 2014}}</ref>
== Distribution and resale ==
On March 25, 2006, FEMA issued a news release requesting residents to call the FEMA Trailer Hotline to schedule removal of unneeded FEMA trailers after Katrina and Rita-related use.<ref name=FEMApickup> "FEMA: Important Phone Numbers for FEMA Travel Trailer Occupants" (news), [[Federal Emergency Management Agency]] (uses term "FEMA Trailer Hotline"), March 25, 2006, FEMA.gov webpage: FEMA-24519.</ref>
In May 2009, FEMA sent eviction notices to residents in Mississippi who were living in FEMA trailers, sparking protests that the lack of available housing would result in them facing homelessness.<ref name=Fausset>{{cite news|last1=Fausset|first1=Richard|title=FEMA Calls Off Trailer Evictions|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2006/jun/21/nation/na-trailer21|accessdate=17 September 2015|work=Los Angeles Times|date=June 21, 2006}}</ref> Awareness of health concerns did not deter some residents, one of whom commented that "A dry roof over a toxic trailer beats no roof at all."<ref name=UPI/> On May 30, FEMA extended a deadline that would have evicted people from FEMA trailers. A FEMA spokesman said the organization was working with federal, state and local partners to help the residents get long-term housing.<ref name=UPI>{{cite news|title=Katrina protesters seek housing, changes|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/2009/06/02/Katrina-protesters-seek-housing-changes/88681243961771/|accessdate=11 September 2015|work=UPI.com|date=June 2, 2009}}</ref>
On June 3, 2009, FEMA announced plans to virtually give away roughly 1,800 mobile homes to 3,400 families displaced by Hurricane Katrina who were living in government-provided housing along the Gulf Coast.<ref name=FiveDollars>{{cite news|title=Katrina Trailers for Sale -- for $5 or Less: White House to sell homes to hurricane-displaced families for as little as $1|url=http://whatsnews.proboards.com/thread/1765|work=MSNBC.com|date=June 3, 2009}}</ref>
[[File:NickShapiro FEMA Trailer Sticker.jpg |right|thumb|200px| Sticker reads "NOT TO BE USED FOR HOUSING"]]
In 2010, the General Services Administration began holding mass public auctions of returned FEMA trailers. Units were marked with stickers that identified them as not suitable for housing, and buyers were required to sign a waiver agreeing that trailers would not be used as housing, and that new owners would be informed of the risks if the units were resold. The stickers are easy to remove, and Katrina FEMA trailers have been widely resold without any warning of possible health hazards. As many as 130,000 trailers are reported to have gone into the resale market, often in disaster zones and other places where there is strong demand for low-cost housing.<ref name=Cohen/>
In Alabama and other parts of the South, after tornadoes caused widespread destruction in 2011, post-Katrina trailers were being sold for between $2,000 and $4,000 each.<ref name=Cohen/> FEMA trailers have been sold to oil-field workers in areas such as North Dakota, where housing is in short supply.<ref name=Smith>{{cite news|last1=Smith|first1=Heather|title=People are still living in FEMA’s toxic Katrina trailers — and they likely have no idea|url=http://grist.org/politics/people-are-still-living-in-femas-toxic-katrina-trailers-and-they-likely-have-no-idea/|accessdate=16 September 2015|work=Grist.com|date=August 27, 2015}}</ref> Trailers were also distributed to Native American reservations,<ref name=Tribes>{{cite news|last1=Cooper|first1=Kenneth J.|title=As Housing Shortage Worsens, Tribes Forced to Use FEMA Trailers|url=http://newamericamedia.org/2011/05/as-housing-crisis-escalates-native-american-tribes-use-fema-mobile-homes.php|accessdate=17 September 2015|work=America's Wire, News Report|date=May 2, 2011}}</ref><ref name=AssociatedPress>{{cite news|title=Vacant FEMA trailers from Katrina given to Indian tribes in need of housing|url=http://blog.al.com/wire/2011/07/vacant_fema_trailers_from_katr.html|work=Associated Press|date=July 6, 2011}}</ref> including the Mescalero Apache in New Mexico, Standing Rock Sioux in North Dakota and South Dakota, the Cherokee in Oklahoma and the Oglala Sioux in South Dakota.<ref name=PoliticsReport>{{cite news|title=FEMA ships Katrina trailers to Native American reservations|url=http://politicsreport.com/news/fema-ships-katrina-trailers-native-american-reservations|accessdate=14 September 2015|work=Politics Report|date=July 13, 2011}}</ref>
It is possible to determine whether a trailer was originally one of the Hurricane Katrina trailers by checking the vehicle's VIN.<ref name=VIN>{{cite web|title=Do you own a post-Katrina FEMA trailer?|url=http://assets.grist.org/article/people-are-still-living-in-femas-toxic-katrina-trailers-and-they-likely-have-no-idea/index.html|website=Grist.com|accessdate=16 September 2015}}</ref> A number of resources have been suggested for those concerned about a FEMA trailer.<ref name=So>{{cite web|last1=Smith|first1=Heather|title=So you’re living in one of FEMA’s Katrina trailers|url=http://grist.org/article/what-do-i-do-if-i-am-living-in-a-fema-trailer/|website=Grist.com|date=August 27, 2015|accessdate=16 September 2015}}</ref>
== Class-action settlements == As of 2012, U.S. District Judge [[Kurt D. Engelhardt]] of New Orleans approved a $42.6 million class-action lawsuit settlement. Plaintiffs, who included roughly 55,000 residents of Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama and Texas, had alleged that the FEMA trailers emitted hazardous levels of the toxic chemical formaldehyde. The defendants included two dozen manufacturers who built mobile homes for the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), including Gulf Stream Coach Inc., Forest River Inc., Vanguard LLC and Monaco Coach Corp. A separate $5.1 million settlement dealt with claims against FEMA contractors including Shaw Environmental Inc., Bechtel Corp., Fluor Enterprises Inc. and CH2M Hill Constructors Inc., who were responsible for installing and maintaining the units.<ref name=Brunker>{{cite news|last1=Brunker|first1=Mike|title=Class-action suit against FEMA trailer manufacturers settled for $42.6 million|url=http://investigations.nbcnews.com/_news/2012/09/28/14140222-class-action-suit-against-fema-trailer-manufacturers-settled-for-426-million|accessdate=11 September 2015|work=NBC News|date=September 28, 2012}}</ref>

{{Infobox military person |name= Major Fred Hargesheimer |birth_date= {{birth date|1916|05|07}} |death_date= {{death date and age|2010|12|23|1916|05|07}} |birth_place= [[Rochester, Minnesota]] |death_place= [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] |image=Fred Hargesheimer, 2008, Grass Valley, California.jpg |caption=Fred Hargesheimer, 2008 |nickname= |allegiance={{flag|United States}} |branch=[[United States Army Air Corps]] |serviceyears= 1941–1945 |rank= [[Major (United States)|Major]] |unit= [[8th Photo Reconnaissance Squadron]] |battles=[[World War II]] |awards=[[Purple Heart]]
[[Silver Star]]
[[Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)|Distinguished Flying Cross]]
[[Air Medal]]
[[Asiatic-Pacific Campaign Medal]] }} Major '''Fred Hargesheimer''' (May 7, 1916 – December 23, 2010) was a former pilot of the [[United States Army Air Forces]] who was shot down during [[World War II]] over [[Papua New Guinea]] in June 1943. He later became a philanthropist who helped out the village that had hidden him from the [[Empire of Japan|Japanese]]. ==Early life== Hargesheimer was born and raised in [[Rochester, Minnesota]]. He earned a BS in Electrical Engineering from [[Iowa State College]] in 1940 before moving to [[Alpine, New Jersey]], to work for FM radio pioneer [[Edwin H. Armstrong]].{{cite web|last=Nelson|first=Ed|title=Fred Hargesheimer and ERA/Univac Story|url=http://vipclubmn.org/Documents/Fred_Hargesheimer.pdf|work=2007|publisher=Vipclubmn|accessdate=24 December 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101129210833/http://vipclubmn.org/Documents/Fred_Hargesheimer.pdf|archivedate=29 November 2010|df=}} ==World War II== Hargesheimer served with the 8th Photographic Reconnaissance Squadron of the U.S. Army Air Corps during World War II. He was flying a [[Lockheed P-38 Lightning|Lockheed P-38F-4]] on a photo reconnaissance mission on June 5, 1943, over the island of [[New Britain]], [[Papua New Guinea]], when his plane was attacked by a Japanese [[Kawasaki Ki-45|Ki-45 Nick]] fighter. Despite his injuries and jammed canopy, he was able to parachute to safety. For the next month he fought to survive in the jungle. He was found by members of the Nakanai tribe after 31 days. They sheltered him for five months in the village of Ea Ea, risking their lives to protect him from being found by Japanese soldiers. He met up with [[Coastwatchers|Australian Coastwatchers]] who moved him inland. On February 5, 1944, Fred, along with other downed airmen, was rescued by the submarine {{USS|Gato|SS-212|6}}. He was awarded the [[Purple Heart]], the [[Silver Star]], the [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)|Distinguished Flying Cross]], the [[Air Medal]], and the [[Asiatic-Pacific Campaign Medal]]. After the war, he returned to his hometown of [[Rochester, Minnesota]], where he raised a family of his own. ==Philanthropy== [[File:Fred_Hargesheimer_Visits_New_Britain.jpg|thumb|350px|left|Fred Hargesheimer visits with pupils of the Airmen's Memorial School in Ewasse on Aug. 2, 2004, during a visit to the southwest Pacific island of New Britain, Papua New Guinea. As a World War II U.S. Army pilot, he was shot down over the Japanese-occupied island and was protected by villagers for months. In gratitude, he later built this and another school, libraries and a clinic, and he and his wife taught island children in the 1970s. (Photo:Geoff Heard)]]Hargesheimer corresponded with a missionary to learn how the tribe that kept him safe had fared and in 1960 returned to the island. He was told that they needed a school. He came home and raised $15,000 over three years, "most of it $5 and $10 gifts," and then returned with son Richard in 1963 to contract for the construction of the school.[http://www.ctpost.com/default/article/WWII-pilot-who-forever-repaid-rescuers-dies-at-94-917792.php/ WWII Pilot who Forever Repaid Rescuers Dies at 94, ''The Associated Press'', December 23, 2010] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101226163440/http://www.ctpost.com/default/article/WWII-pilot-who-forever-repaid-rescuers-dies-at-94-917792.php |date=December 26, 2010 }} The simple four-room schoolhouse became known as the Airmen's Memorial School * [http://airmensmemorialfoundation.org/Airmens_Memorial_Foundation_U.S./AMFUS_Welcome.html]. Hargesheimer returned many times for the next 40 years, building a library as well as infrastructure for the village of Ea Ea, now known as Nantabu. From 1970 to 1974 he and his wife, Dorothee, lived there. He was known by the locals as '''Mastah Preddi''', a corruption of '''Master Freddie'''. In 2000, he was proclaimed "Suara Auru," or "Chief Warrior" in the native language. Hargesheimer returned in 2006 for his last visit. During the trip, he visited the site where the wreckage of his old P-38 had been recently found. Hargesheimer also attended the opening of a new library at the Noau school. ==Contact with his attacker== In 1999, aided by amateur Japanese historians of World War II, he contacted the wife of the man who had shot him down. He had always wondered why the pilot had never taken the time to finish him off when he was parachuting to the ground. By then the man, Mitsugu Hyakutomi of [[Yamaguchi, Japan]], was suffering from Alzheimer's disease. His wife said that her husband had always said that he could never shoot down such defenseless parachuting fliers.{{cite web|last=Hanley|first=Charles J. |title=‘Mastah Preddi’ fell from the sky, into hearts Islanders heal, hail WW2 pilot; man changes lives, returns to build school|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/23538741/|work=Mar 8 2008|publisher=MSNBC via AP|accessdate=24 December 2010}} ==Death== He died in [[Lincoln, Nebraska]], on December 23, 2010. ==Bibliography== *Hargesheimer, Fred. ''The School That Fell From The Sky'' {{ISBN|978-1-58909-116-0}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.pacificwrecks.com/aircraft/p-38/42-13073.html Pacific Wrecks] * [http://airmensmemorialfoundation.org/Airmens_Memorial_Foundation_U.S./AMFUS_Welcome.html Airmen's Memorial Foundation] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hargesheimer, Fred}} [[Category:American philanthropists]] [[Category:Aviators from Minnesota]] [[Category:People from Rochester, Minnesota]] [[Category:People from Grass Valley, California]] [[Category:People from Nevada County, California]] [[Category:Shot-down aviators]] [[Category:Recipients of the Air Medal]] [[Category:Recipients of the Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)]] [[Category:Recipients of the Silver Star]] [[Category:United States Army Air Forces officers]] [[Category:United States Army Air Forces pilots of World War II]] [[Category:1916 births]] [[Category:2010 deaths]]

{{Infobox museum | name = Gallo-Roman Museum | native_name = Gallo-Romeins Museum | native_name_lang = nl | image = King of the Eburones - Marble Julius Caesar.jpg | imagesize = 200 | caption = 1st century BC marble bust of [[Julius Caesar]] on display at the museum | alt = | map_type = | map_relief = | map_size = | map_caption = | map_dot_label = | coordinates = {{coord|50|46|53|N|5|27|58|E|type:landmark_region:BE-VLI|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | established = {{Start date|1954}} | dissolved = | location = Kielenstraat 16,
[[Tongeren]], [[Belgium]] | type = [[Archaeology museum]] | accreditation = | key_holdings = | collections = | collection_size = | visitors = | founder = | director = | president = | curator = | owner = | publictransit = | car_park = | parking = | network = | website = {{URL|galloromeinsmuseum.be}} }} The '''Gallo-Roman Museum''' ({{lang-nl|Gallo-Romeins Museum}}, {{lang-fr|Musée Gallo-romain}}, {{lang-de|Gallo-Römisches Museum}}) is an archeological museum in [[Tongeren]]. It is dedicated to the prehistorical times and Roman age of the region in South East [[Flanders]]. The museum was established in 1954 and received its modern building in 1994. In 2011, it was awarded as the European Museum of the Year. ==History== In the 19th century the Royal History and Antiquarian Society of Tongeren had amassed a collection of archaeological discoveries from the area. Some of this collection was then displayed in the city from 1854. In 1937 the Provincial Museum opened in Hasselt where the most important pieces of the Tongeren collection were exhibited. In 1954 the Provincial Gallo-Roman Museum was opened in Tongeren. The collection was expanded through donations and digs carried out by the museum itself and the Nationale Dienst voor Opgravingen (National Department for Excavations).[https://archief.onroerenderfgoed.be/nationale-dienst-voor-opgravingen;isaar Archive of the Real Estate Agency of Belgium] After public pressure for a new home for the collection, a new building by architect Alfredo de Gregorio was opened in 1994. This new building with new and expanded exhibition areas resulted in an increase in the number of visitors. The site was further expanded in 2006. The permanent exhibition starts with the first humanoids in the region, the Neanderthals. It presents following cultures of hunters and several waves of farmers. The third floor is dedicated to the [[Gallo-Roman culture]] located in [[Tongeren]]. The exhibition closes with the first signs of Christianity. File:Gallo-Roman Museum of Tongeren, Belgium (27541086092) (2).jpg|Gallo-Roman Museum of Tongeren File:Belgisch-limburg 452.JPG|Model of Roman Tongeren File:Belgisch-limburg 469.JPG|Roman citizens walking to a burial File:Display at Gallo-Roman Museum of Tongeren, Belgium (27029817584).jpg|Gallic recruit to Roman Legions File:Display at Gallo-Roman Museum of Tongeren, Belgium (27362902090).jpg|Roman Soldier ==Awards== In 2011, the museum was awarded the European Museum of the Year Award and was the first Belgian museum to receive this award. In 2014 the museum was awarded the Museum Prize worth 5,000 euros. The jury praised the way in which "the Gallo-Roman Museum has been true to the discipline of archaeology in all its forms for many years". In addition, according to the jury, "the museum knows how to host exhibitions that reach a lot of the public and establishes a broad pedagogy with attention to different target groups". In 2016, the museum won the Romulus Prize "for the massive efforts the museum provides to map Rome, Romans and ancient times in our country". In 2016, the museum won the Romulus Prize "for the massive efforts the museum provides to map Rome, Romans and ancient times in our country".[https://www.demorgen.be/expo/gallo-romeins-museum-tongeren-wint-romulusprijs-2016-b4833aae/ Gallo-Romeins Museum Tongeren wins Romulus Prize 2016- De Morgen Newspaper (1 Sep 2017)] == Temporary exhibitions == * In 1995 the museum created an exhibition about the Neanderthals in Europa. It was later presented also in Hamburg, Germany. * 2011: [[Ambiorix]], King of the [[Eburones]] * 2011/2012: ''[[Sagalassos]], City of Dreams'' * 2013: ''De Etrusken - Una storia particolare'' * 2015: ''Gladiators - Heroes of the Colosseum'' * 2016: Timeless Beauty (Artefacts and Photographs by Marc Lagrange).[http://www.hbvl.be/cnt/dmf20170831_03046566/stonehenge-komt-naar-tongeren Stonehenge comes to Tongeren - Het Belang Van Limburg 1 Sep 2017] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Gallo-Romeins Museum Tongeren|Gallo-Roman Museum of Tongeren}} *{{Official website|www.galloromeinsmuseum.be}} [[Category:Museums in Limburg (Belgium)]] [[Category:Museums established in 1954]] [[Category:Archaeological museums in Belgium]] [[Category:European Museum of the Year Award winners]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Tongeren]]

{{Infobox officeholder |name = Georgios Alogoskoufis
{{small|Γιώργος Αλογοσκούφης}} |image = GAlogoskoufis Nov06 (original size).JPG |office = [[Ministry of Finance (Greece)|Minister of the Economy and Finance]] |primeminister = [[Kostas Karamanlis]] |term_start = 10 March 2004 |term_end = 8 January 2009 |predecessor = [[Nikos Christodoulakis]] |successor = [[Yannis Papathanasiou]] |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1955|10|17|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Athens]], [[Greece]] |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[New Democracy (Greece)|New Democracy]] |spouse = Dika Agapitidou |alma_mater = [[National and Kapodistrian University of Athens|University of Athens]]
[[London School of Economics]] |religion = [[Greek Orthodox Church|Greek Orthodoxy]] |website = {{url|alogoskoufis.gr|Official website}} }} '''Georgios Alogoskoufis''' ({{lang-el|Γιώργος Αλογοσκούφης}}) (born 17 October 1955[http://www.parliament.gr/english/synthesh/mp.asp?MPID=361 Curriculum Vitae] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070311045012/http://www.parliament.gr/english/synthesh/mp.asp?MPID=361 |date=2007-03-11 }} at Hellenic Parliament website.) is a Professor of Economics at the Athens University of Economics and Business since 1990. He was a member of the Hellenic Parliament from September 1996 till October 2009 and served as Greece's Minister of Economy and Finance from March 2004 till January 2009. During 2004-2008 Greece's economic performance seemed extremely positive. The average growth rate was 4% per annum, unemployment fell from 10.5% in 2004 to 7.7% in 2008 just changing the way of measuring it, and public debt increased from 180 bil euro to 300 bil euro. Alogoskoufis initiated a number of policy reforms, such as the simplification of the Greek tax system such as revoking inheritance taxes for rich people, extensive privatisations, create 700 new government institutions to hire more people to the public section, export promotion, public/private partnerships etc. His supporters point out that problems for the Greek economy appeared after Alogoskoufis was replaced as minister, at the end of 2008, and especially after the change in government in October 2010. These problems appeared because of structural weaknesses in the Greek economy, such as the high public debt that was accumulated during the 1980s, the financial crisis and the partial reversal of the policies that Alogoskoufis pursued, by his successors.{{Cite web|url = http://ec.europa.eu/economy_finance/publications/european_economy/2010/index_en.htm|title = Data of the EU Parliament|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} ==Background, academic and political career== George Alogoskoufis was born in [[Athens]] on 17 October 1955. ==The economic policy mix applied under the leadership of Alogoskoufis== In the period in which Alogoskoufis served as the minister for Economy and Finance, he actuated a series of economic structural reforms and [[fiscal adjustment]] to contain budget deficits, which, although unpopular, have managed to slash Greece's budget deficit to 2.6% of the gross domestic product. In the same period of time, Greece's gross domestic product has grown with a 4%, maintaining one of the highest growth rates in the Eurozone. Although unemployment had fallen from 11% to 9% in the period between 2004 and 2007, just changing the way of measuring it, it remains one of the highest in Europe.[https://archive.is/20070625075816/http://www.europeanvoice.com/archive/article.asp?id=28016 "The Minister of Sound"] Article about G. Alogoskoufis in the Belgian newspaper European Voice, published by the Economist Group.[http://search.ft.com/ftArticle?queryText=Rising+prosperity&y=0&aje=false&x=0&id=070713000627&ct=0 "Rising prosperity brings feel-good factor"] Article in the Financial Times on the Greek economy.[https://www.forbes.com/business/forbes/2007/0723/160.html "With little fanfare, Greece has become one of Europe's best-performing economies and stock markets"] Article in Forbes on the Greek economy. During 2004–2007, corporate and personal income taxes were reduced for rich people from 45% to 40% and increased for poor people from 12% to 29% and the tax system was simplified with the tax reform such as revoking inheritance taxes for rich people.{{cite web |url=http://www.mnec.gr/en/metarithmisi/forol_metarithmisi/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-03-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080328182650/http://www.mnec.gr/en/metarithmisi/forol_metarithmisi/ |archivedate=2008-03-28 |df= }} Corporate and personal income taxes reduction He worked extensively with the private sector {{cite web |url=http://www.sdit.mnec.gr/en/projects/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-03-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080414192448/http://www.sdit.mnec.gr/en/projects/ |archivedate=2008-04-14 |df= }} List of PuPlic Private Partnership projects and sold over euro 6 billion of government holdings.{{cite web |url=http://www.mnec.gr/export/sites/mnec/en/metarithmisi/Privatisation_Programme/01_table_Privatisation_Revenues.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-03-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080414151213/http://www.mnec.gr/export/sites/mnec/en/metarithmisi/Privatisation_Programme/01_table_Privatisation_Revenues.pdf |archivedate=2008-04-14 |df= }} Table of Privatization revenues == Criticism == Alogoskoufis made a decision to revise [[GDP]] upward by 25 percent and was heavily criticized by television network [[CNN]] and EU accepted a lower revise.Greek GDP revision was part of the annual catalog of 101 Dumbest Moments in Business.[http://money.cnn.com/galleries/2007/biz2/0701/gallery.101dumbest_2007/39.html] George Alogoskoufis was pelted with eggs by Greek left wing activists at a meeting held at the [[London School of Economics]] on 14 November 2008.The activists threw the eggs as a protest to the current economic policy of the Greek government.[https://web.archive.org/web/20110717012838/http://www.thelondondailynews.com/greek-finance-minister-gets-pelted-with-eggs-p-1766.html] ==Publications==
[[File:DRAXMH.jpg|thumb|left|Alogoskoufis' book “The Drachma: From the Phoenix to the Euro”]] Alogoskoufis is the author of five books and has published widely in macroeconomics, international monetary economics and public economics. Over 40 papers have been published in some of the most prestigious international academic journals including the American Economic Review, the Journal of Political Economy, the Journal of Monetary Economics, the European Economic Review, Economica, the Journal of the Japanese and International Economies, Economic Journal and the Economic Policy. His research focuses on unemployment, inflation, exchange rates, economic growth and monetary and fiscal policy. He has given invited lectures in some of the most prestigious universities in Europe, the US and Japan and has presented papers in a number of academic conferences worldwide. ==Books== “External Constraints on Macroeconomic Policy: The European Experience” (with Lucas Papademos and Richard Portes), Centre for Economic Policy Research, 1991. “The crisis of economic policy”, Published by Kritiki Publications and the Athens Institute of Economic Policy Studies, Athens, 1994 (in Greek). “Unemployment: Choices for Europe, Monitoring European Integration 5” (with Charles Bean, Giuseppe Bertola, Daniel Cohen, Juan Dolado, Gilles Saint-Paul), Centre for Economic Policy Research, 1995. “The Drachma: From the Phoenix to the Euro” (with Sophia Lazaretou), Published by Livanis Publishing House, 2002 (in Greek). “Greece after the crisis”, Kastaniotis Publications, 2009 (in Greek). ==Publications in academic journals== The following is a selected list of journal articles by
