[http://www.peoplemagazine.co.za/celebrity-news/attie-van-wyk-spills-live-nations-acquisition-big-concerts Attie Van Wyk]
[https://www.bizjournals.com/losangeles/news/2016/02/22/live-nation-acquires-leading-south-africa-concert.html Live Nation Acquires Leading] *Founders Entertainment (2016) [https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/11/business/media/live-nation-adds-governors-ball-to-its-music-festival-lineup.html Live Nation Ads Governors Ball][https://www.bizjournals.com/newyork/news/2016/04/11/governors-ball-sells-majority-stake-to-live-nation.html Governors Ball Sells Majority] *AC Entertainment (2016) [http://www.tennessean.com/story/money/2016/10/31/live-nation-buys-ac-entertainment/93074100/ The Tennessean][http://ampthemag.com/the-real/live-nation-acquires-ac-entertainment/ Live Nation Acquires AC Entertainment] *Sweden Rock Festival (2016) [http://www.billboard.com/articles/business/7587978/live-nation-acquires-sweden-rock-festival Live Nation Acquires Sweden Rock Festival]
[http://www.businessinsider.com/r-brief-live-nation-entertainment-says-acquired-a-majority-stake-in-sweden-rock-festival-2016-11 Business Insider] *Secret Sounds Group (2016) [https://www.musicbusinessworldwide.com/aggressive-live-nation-buys-again-with-7th-major-acquisition-of-2016/ Aggressive Live Nation][http://www.billboard.com/articles/business/7597388/live-nation-acquires-more-than-half-secret-sounds Live Nation Acquires More] *BottleRock Napa Valley (2017) [http://www.sfchronicle.com/bayarea/article/Live-Nation-acquires-major-stake-in-BottleRock-10853961.php Live Nation Acquires Major Stake] *Cuffe & Taylor (2017) [http://www.musicweek.com/live/read/live-nation-acquires-controlling-stake-in-cuffe-taylor/067229 Live Nation Acquires Controlling] *Bluestone Entertainment (2017) [https://www.musicbusinessworldwide.com/live-nation-acquires-majority-stake-israels-bluestone-entertainment/ Live Nation Acquires Majority Stake] *Isle of Wight Festival (2017) [http://www.completemusicupdate.com/article/live-nation-takes-majority-stake-in-isle-of-wight-festival/ Complete Music Update] *United Concerts (2017) [https://www.billboard.com/articles/business/7989016/live-nation-acquires-united-concerts-utah-promoter Live Nation Acquires United Concerts] ==Live Nation International Music and Live Nation Artists== Live Nation is currently constructing a physical recording label,{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}} Live Nation Artists, which will be a division of Live Nation International Music. The company is expected to become a major rival against [[Sony Music Entertainment|Sony Music]], [[Universal Music Group]] and [[Warner Music Group]] with artists such as [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]], [[U2]], [[Shakira]], [[Jay-Z]] and [[Nickelback]]. As of July 30, 2008, CEO Michael Rapino is considering doing licensing deals on an artist-by-artist basis, a source inside Live Nation said. Under that scenario, [[Warner Music Group]] could end up handling the marketing, promotion, and distribution of albums by the very acts that defected from it to join Live Nation: Nickelback and Madonna. "Rapino wants to outsource everything," said a second source close to the situation. "He doesn't want to build an infrastructure or carry any overhead." The move is mirrored after the "rent-a-system" model used in Hollywood, whereby one studio produces a movie but licenses all the other functions to another studio that already has a distribution and marketing infrastructure.{{cite news| url=http://www.nypost.com/seven/07302008/business/a_different_tune_122233.htm | work=New York Post | title=A Different Tune | first1=Brian | last1=Garrity | first2=Peter | last2=Lauria | date=July 30, 2008}} Live Nation's talks represented the latest retrenchment from the strategy of former chairman [[Michael Cohl]], who sought to transform the touring giant into a multi-faceted powerhouse, including a record company. News of the potential outsourcing move followed the dismissal of industry veterans Bob Ezrin, Bob Cahill and Bill Hein, all of whom were Artist Nation employees hired by Cohl to create a label infrastructure for Live Nation's newly signed acts. Instead of banking all the upside on album sales, as was once envisioned with these so-called "360 deals," Live Nation would likely collect a less lucrative outsourcing royalty of between 25 percent and 35 percent, based on other industry licensing deals. It would then be responsible for using that money to pay the artist's royalty - a fee that, at the superstar level, can come close to equaling the licensing royalty the company is apt to get from a label. On 31 March 2008, it was confirmed that Live Nation signed a 12-year deal with U2 worth an estimated $100 million (£70 million).{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/mediatechnologyandtelecoms/2787228/U2-ties-the-knot-with-Live-Nation-deal.html|title=U2 ties the knot with Live Nation deal|first=Emma|last=Thelwell|date=31 March 2008|publisher=|via=www.telegraph.co.uk}} The deal includes Live Nation controlling the band's merchandise, sponsoring and their official website. In a contractual agreement with Live Nation signed in March 2008, the parties agreed that the band would receive $25 million for 1.6 million shares of the company; as of 17 December 2008, those shares were worth only just over $6 million. It was reported on 18 December 2008 that Live Nation, honoring their financial commitment, bought back the shares at a loss of $19 million.{{cite news|title=UPDATE 1-Live Nation takes $19 mln hit on U2 buyback deal|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/rbssConsumerGoodsAndRetailNews/idUKBNG16028420081218 | work=Reuters | first=Ajay | last=Kamalakaran | date=December 18, 2008}} The company had intended to recoup the cost of signing U2 with their most recent album, ''[[No Line on the Horizon]]''. ''No Line on the Horizon'' achieved a multi-platinum status in the international market and has sold over 5 million albums to date. ==Corporate Governance== === Executive Leadership === * Michael Rapino – Chief Executive Officer and President, Live Nation Entertainment * Joe Berchtold – President, Live Nation Entertainment * Kathy Willard – Chief Financial Officer, Live Nation Entertainment * Michael Rowles – General Counsel and Secretary, Live Nation Entertainment * Russell Wallach – Global President, Live Nation Media & Sponsorship * Arthur Fogel – Chairman, Global Music and President, Global Touring, Live Nation Entertainment * Bob Roux – President, Live Nation US Concerts * Ron Bension – President, House of Blues Entertainment * Jared Smith – President, Ticketmaster North America === Board of Directors === * Gregory B. Maffei – Chairman of the Board * Mark Carleton * Jonathan L. Dolgen * Ariel Emanuel * Robert Ted Enloe, III * Jeffrey T. Hinson * Jimmy Iovine * Peggy Johnson * James S. Kahan * Randall T Mays * Mark Shapiro * Michael Rapino – Chief Executive Officer and President [https://www.iq-mag.net/2017/12/joe-berchtold-kathy-willard-michael-rowles-reup-live-nation/#.Wnz-SmbMx- IQ Mag][https://www.billboard.com/articles/business/8096144/billboard-2018-power-100-list Billboard Power 100][https://www.reuters.com/finance/stocks/company-officers/LYV Reuters] ==Companies== ===United States=== * Live Nation owns, operates and/or exclusively books 135 live entertainment venues, including 43 in Europe, along with producing high-profile events such as [[Super Bowl]] halftime shows.{{citation needed|date=April 2013}} It also represents major music artists. * Owned [[Monster Jam]], a promoter of [[monster truck]] races and other indoor motorsports. Live Nation also owned several trucks and the rights to several trucks running at these events, including [[Grave Digger (truck)|Grave Digger]], Superman and [[Maximum Destruction (truck)|Maximum Destruction]]. Now owned by [[Feld Entertainment]], divested in September 2008. * Previously promoted [[THQ]] World [[Supercross]] GP, National Arenacross Series, IFMA Freestyle [[Motocross]], and [[International Hot Rod Association|IHRA]] [[Drag Racing]], before selling its entire motorsports division to [[Feld Entertainment]]. * Produces sporting events: [[84 Lumber Classic of Pennsylvania]]; [[Legg Mason Tennis Classic]]; [[ADT Skills Challenge]]; American Century Golf Championship. * Produces concerts and [[music festival|festivals]]: [[Great New York State Fair]], [[Ozzfest]], [[Jägermeister Music Tour]], and [[Music Midtown]] ([[Atlanta, Georgia|Atlanta]]) and in the UK Download at Donington, Hyde Park Calling and Wireless Festival. Through its LN/Gaiety subsidiary, it also manages the [[Festival Republic]] festivals at Reading and Leeds. * In July 2006 Live Nation announced it has entered into a definitive merger agreement to acquire [[House of Blues|HOB Entertainment]], Inc., the operator of the [[House of Blues]] chain of music halls and restaurants. * On October 16, 2007, Live Nation announced it signed a $120 million, 10-year global partnership contract with pop artist [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] who will become the founding artist in its new Artist Nation division. The deal consists of all future music and music-related businesses including albums, concert tours, merchandising, fan club/web site, DVDs, music-related television and film projects, and associated sponsorship agreements. * Live Nation owned the aforementioned Broadway Across America series, divested in January 2008 to Key Brand Entertainment. * On March 31, 2008, Live Nation announced it signed a 12-year partnership contract with Irish rock band [[U2]], after quitting [[Island Records]], it will expire in 2020. * On April 3, 2008, Live Nation announced it signed a 10-year, $150 million music deal with multi-platinum rap artist, [[Jay-Z]], it will expire in 2018. * In July 2008, Live Nation announced it signed a 3-album-cycle deal with multi-platinum, Canadian rock band, [[Nickelback]]. ===Worldwide=== * Acquired Italian music promoters Milano Concerti and Friends & Partners Agency. * Management of the former Olympic Venues (TOP Turin Olympic Park) in Turin, including the biggest Italian arena PalaOlimpico. * Worldwide subsidiaries include Welldone Agency & Promotion (Finland), dkbMotor (Denmark), EMA Telstar (Sweden) and Gunnar Eide Concerts (Norway). * Live Nation's subsidiary Mojo Concerts is the biggest organizer of concerts in The Netherlands with over 200 concerts and a total of a million visitors a year. Well known festivals include [[Pinkpop]], [[Lowlands (music festival)|Lowlands]], [[Arrow Rock Festival]] and [[North Sea Jazz Festival|North Sea Jazz]]. * Owns Clear Channel Entertainment do Brasil Ltda, a [[Brazil]]ian music promotion and production company * Acquires Music and Entertainment producers GAMERCO, the biggest Spanish promotion and production company. * In the United Kingdom, as [[Live Nation UK]], owns/ manages: ** A concert promotion business which promotes large outdoor concerts at the [[Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park]], as well as numerous small and medium concert venues across the country. ** [[Download Festival]], [[Wireless Festival]] and [[Hyde Park Calling]] ** A 50.1% stake in the Festival Republic, and thus interests in: *** Several [[music festivals]], including the production of [[Glastonbury Festival]], [[Reading and Leeds Festivals]], [[Latitude Festival]] *** Some medium-sized London music venues, including the [[London Astoria]]. In March 2007 Live Nation/Gaiety bought a majority share in a further 10 music venues from the [[Academy Music Group]] including the [[Brixton Academy]] and [[Shepherds Bush Empire]]. ** Management and Operations at London [[Wembley Arena]], [[Motorpoint Arena Cardiff]], [[Motorpoint Arena Sheffield]], [[O2 Apollo Manchester]] and [[Southampton Guildhall]]. ** A large majority of the UK's biggest regional theatre houses were owned/managed by Live Nation until October 2009 when the majority were sold to ATG, including the [[Sunderland Empire Theatre]], [[Palace Theatre, Manchester]], [[Grimsby Auditorium]], [[Alexandra Theatre (Birmingham)|Alexandra Theatre]] in [[Birmingham]], [[Lyceum Theatre, London]], [[Edinburgh Playhouse]], [[Liverpool Empire Theatre|Liverpool Empire]], [[New Theatre Oxford]] and [[Bristol Hippodrome]]. In addition, the [[Dominion Theatre]], London was managed by Live Nation until October 2009 when it was bought outright by the majority owner Nederlander Dominion Ltd. * In Ireland, Live Nation owns [[3Arena|3 Arena]] Dublin – formally known as The Point Depot. * In Belgium, Live Nation organizes big festivals, like [[Rock Werchter]], [[Graspop Metal Meeting]] and [[I Love Techno]] * In Canada, [[Pemberton Festival]] was launched in July 2008 by Live Nation. * In France, Live Nation organizes the [[Main Square Festival]] since 2009 as well as a few other shows like Depeche Mode in Liévin in 2010 ==Proposed merger== On February 10, 2009, Live Nation and [[Ticketmaster|Ticketmaster Entertainment]] announced that they have entered into a definitive merger agreement to create a combined entity, to be called [[Live Nation Entertainment]].{{cite web|url=http://www.pollstar.com/news_article.aspx?ID=647940 |title=Live Nation, Ticketmaster Announce Merger |work=pollstar.com |date=2009-02-10 |accessdate=April 9, 2014 |author= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140409090434/http://www.pollstar.com/news_article.aspx?ID=647940 |archivedate=April 9, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }} Ticketmaster's press release said Live Nation produces live concerts in 57 countries. The proposal has received regulatory approval in Norway and Turkey.{{cite web|url=http://files.shareholder.com/downloads/TICK/0x0x340322/ff220710-6ab4-4baf-b088-1b61758f4eea/TKTM_News_2009_12_22_General_News_Releases.pdf |title=MEDIA STATEMENT: Ticketmaster and Live Nation Welcome Competition Commission Ruling on Merger |work=files.shareholder.com |date=April 9, 2014 |accessdate=April 9, 2014 |author= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140409091622/http://files.shareholder.com/downloads/TICK/0x0x340322/ff220710-6ab4-4baf-b088-1b61758f4eea/TKTM_News_2009_12_22_General_News_Releases.pdf |archivedate=April 9, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }} In October 2009, the United Kingdom's [[Competition Commission]] provisionally ruled against the merger with Ticketmaster.{{cite news|author=Van Buskirk, Eliot|title=Live Nation/Ticketmaster Merger Faces Obstacles Here and Abroad|url=https://www.wired.com/epicenter/2009/10/live-nationticketmaster-merger-faces-obstacles-here-and-abroad/|date=October 12, 2009|publisher=Condé Nast|work=Wired|accessdate=2009-10-19}} On December 22, 2009, the Competition Commission decided to clear the proposed merger. Separate regulatory reviews of the proposal continued in the United States and Canada. The [[United States Department of Justice]] approved the merger in 2010 subject to review by a federal judge after a 60-day comment period.{{cite news|title=Ticketmaster-Live Nation merger gets Justice Department's approval|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-ct-ticketmaster26-2010jan26,0,5237319,full.story|date=January 26, 2010|author=Chmielewski, Dawn C. and Fritz, Ben and Lewis, Randy|publisher=The Los Angeles Times|accessdate=January 26, 2010}} A condition of the approval, Ticketmaster agreed to license its software to rival [[Anschutz Entertainment Group]], and to sell its subsidiary Paciolan to [[Comcast Spectacor]], Comcast's sporting events subsidiary. The company also agreed not to interfere with competition for the ten-year life of the agreement. ==Criticism== In 2009, in reaction to a merger of Live Nation and Ticketmaster, [[Bruce Springsteen]] said "the one thing that would make the current ticket situation even worse for the fan than it is now would be Ticketmaster and Live Nation coming up with a single system, thereby returning us to a near monopoly situation in music ticketing".{{cite news|title=Bruce Springsteen "Furious" At Ticketmaster, Rails Against Live Nation Merger|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/rockdaily/index.php/2009/02/04/bruce-springsteen-furious-at-ticketmaster-rails-against-live-nation-merger/|date=February 4, 2009|publisher=Rolling Stone|accessdate=2009-10-19}} In a January 25, 2010 press release, the TicketDisaster.org group—a coalition of consumer rights and anti-trust groups—also issued the following statement about the proposed Live Nation-TicketMaster merger:
"Despite its "monopoly-like dominance" controlling 70 to 80 percent of all concert ticket sales, Ticketmaster is unabashedly seeking to grow its empire - all to the detriment of the average fan. Ticketmaster is now trying to dampen competition by merging with Live Nation, the nation's largest concert promoter and second largest primary ticket seller. That merger is coming under heavy fire from consumer and industry groups and Members of Congress, particularly because of the clear anti-consumer and anti-competitive effects. As the Department of Justice reaches the final round of reviewing this merger, only one question must be answered: will the merger lead to increased prices, poorer service, or less innovation?"
==See also== {{Portal|Los Angeles|Companies}} * [[Instant Live]] * [[Live Nation Entertainment]] ==References== *[https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1335258/000095012905012209/h31387e8vk.htm Live Nation rocks the music industry] Paul Sloan, ''Fortune Magazine'', November 30, 2007. Accessed July 2008 *[http://money.cnn.com/2007/11/30/news/companies/live_nation.fortune/index.htm CNN] CCE Spinco, Inc. Common Stock Issue. At Us Government Archives. Accessed July 2008 *[http://www.4-traders.com/LIVE-NATION-ENTERTAINMENT-13449/company/ Live Nation Entertainment, Inc.] Live Nation Entertainment *[https://seekingalpha.com/article/4151469-live-nation-entertainment-lyv-q4-2017-results-earnings-call-transcript Seeking Alpha] Seeking Alpha *[https://variety.com/2018/biz/news/live-nation-reports-a-record-2017-in-year-end-results-1202712461/ Variety] Variety *[http://www.boston.com/ae/music/articles/2006/01/25/live_nation_takes_over_clear_channels_concerts/ Live Nation takes over Clear Channel's concerts] Live Nation Takes Over *[http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/sfx-entertainment-inc-history/ History of SFX Entertainment] History of SFX Entertainment {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.livenation.com/ LiveNation.com] {{Live Nation}} [[Category:Live Nation Entertainment]] [[Category:Event management companies]] [[Category:Entertainment companies based in California]] [[Category:Record label distributors]] [[Category:Sports management companies]] [[Category:Monster truck promoters and sanctioning bodies]] [[Category:Companies based in Beverly Hills, California]] [[Category:Entertainment companies established in 1996]] [[Category:Entertainment companies established in 2005]] [[Category:2005 establishments in California]] [[Category:Corporate spin-offs]]

page.title: Martin Luther King and the Montgomery Story

revision.text:
{{Infobox comic book title |image = MLK-Montgomery-comic.jpg |imagesize = |caption = Cover of ''Martin Luther King and the Montgomery Story'' |1shot = y |genre = [[non-fiction]] |publisher = [[Fellowship of Reconciliation (United States)|Fellowship of Reconciliation]] |date = |startmo = December |startyr = 1957 |main_char_team = [[Martin Luther King, Jr]].
[[Coretta Scott King]]
[[Rosa Parks]]
[[Mahatma Gandhi]] |writers = [[Alfred Hassler]] and Benton Resnik |artists = [[Sy Barry]] |pencillers = |pages = 16 |inkers = |letterers = |colorists = |editors = |creative_team_month = |creative_team_year = |creators = |TPB = |ISBN = |TPB# = |ISBN# = |subcat = |altcat = |sort = Martin Luther King and the Montgomery Story |addpubcat# = |nonUS = }} '''''Martin Luther King and the Montgomery Story''''' is a 16-page comic book about [[Martin Luther King, Jr.]], [[Rosa Parks]], and the [[Montgomery Bus Boycott]] published in 1957 by the [[Fellowship of Reconciliation (United States)|Fellowship of Reconciliation]] (FOR USA). It advocates the principles of [[nonviolence]] and provides a primer on [[nonviolent resistance]].Bello. Grace. [http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/authors/profiles/article/58354-a-comic-book-for-social-justice-john-lewis.html "A Comic Book for Social Justice: John Lewis,"] ''Publishers Weekly'' (July 19, 2012). Although ignored by the mainstream comics industry, ''The Montgomery Story'' was widely distributed among civil rights groups, churches, and schools. It helped inspire nonviolent protest movements around the [[Southern United States]], and later in [[Latin America]], [[South Africa]], the [[Middle East]], and elsewhere. Over 50 years after its initial publication, the comic inspired the best-selling, award-winning [[March (comics)|''March'' trilogy]] by [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] Congressman [[John Lewis (Georgia politician)|John Lewis]]. == Publication history == Following the success of the Montgomery Bus Boycott, which FOR USA had helped organize, executive secretary and director of publications [[Alfred Hassler]],Forest, Jim (former FoR Publication Director). Comment on Ethan Persoff's blog (2011): "The author of the text and the man who had the idea for the comic was Al Hassler, executive secretary of FOR USA. He convinced comic artist Al Capp of the value of the project. Capp's studio did the drawings gratis." and FoR member the Rev. [[Glenn E. Smiley]] came up with the idea of using a comic book to bring the story of the bus boycott to a wide audience. (Smiley had been personally active in the bus boycott, and had formed a friendship with Dr. King.)Aydin, Andrew. [http://clatl.com/atlanta/the-comic-book-that-changed-the-world/Content?oid=8807186&showFullText=true "The comic book that changed the world: Martin Luther King and the Montgomery Story's vital role in the Civil Rights Movement,"] ''Creative Loafing'' (Aug. 1, 2013). Presenting the comic idea as a way to reach wider audiences (including those with lower reading levels), the group acquired grant funding of $5,000 for the projectLove, David A. [http://thegrio.com/2011/02/02/eygptians-draw-inspiration-from-civil-rights-movement-comic-book/ "Egyptians draw inspiration from Civil Rights Movement comic book."] ''[[The Grio]]'' (February 2, 2011). from the [[Fund for the Republic]]. Dr, King himself endorsed the book and even provided a few editorial suggestions.Mark, Banaszak. [http://www.previewsworld.com/Home/1/1/71/977?articleID=144160 "THE COMIC THAT INSPIRED A MOVEMENT: Andrew Aydin on Martin Luther King and the Montgomery Story,"] ''Previews World'' (June 3, 2015). Cartoonist [[Al Capp]] was an admirer of Dr. King; his studio produced ''Martin Luther King and the Montgomery Story'' at no charge, which was co-written by Hassler and [[Benton Resnik]], and drawn by an uncredited artist. (Benton Resnick had been an editor and writer for the Al Capp-owned comics companies [[Toby Press]] and Graphic Information Services.) The artist has since been confirmed to be [[Sy Barry]]{{Cite news|url=http://www.comicsbeat.com/big-apple-con-report-finally-revealed-the-artist-of-the-martin-luther-king-jr-comic/|title=Big Apple Con report—finally revealed: the artist of the Martin Luther King Jr. comic|date=2018-04-16|work=The Beat|access-date=2018-04-22|language=en-US}} by artist [[James Romberger]]. It was published in December [[1957 in comics|1957]] in full-color with a cover price of 10 cents. 250,000 copies were printed. Instead of the typical distribution network for comics in those days, which were [[newsstands]], [[pharmacies]], and [[candy store]]s, ''The Montgomery Story'' was distributed by the [[Fellowship of Reconciliation (United States)|Fellowship of Reconciliation]]Karlin, Susan. [http://www.fastcocreate.com/3021719/the-return-of-a-comic-that-helped-inspire-the-civil-rights-movement "THE RETURN OF A COMIC THAT HELPED INSPIRE THE CIVIL RIGHTS MOVEMENT,"] ''Fast Company'' (Nov. 13, 2013).[http://comicon.com/pulse/index.php/2010/03/07/al-capps-martin-luther-king-comic/ "Al Capp's Martin Luther King Comic,"] Comicon.com's ''The Pulse'' (March 7, 2010). {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120322210437/http://comicon.com/pulse/index.php/2010/03/07/al-capps-martin-luther-king-comic/ |date=March 22, 2012 }} among civil rights groups, churches, and schools. It was also promoted in pro-Civil Rights publications such as ''[[National Guardian]]'' and ''[[Peace News]]''. FoR staff members, particularly Jim Lawson (an African American divinity student at [[Vanderbilt University]])Lewis, John, Andrew Aydin, and Nate Powell. ''March: Book One'' (Top Shelf Productions, 2013), p. 76. and Glenn Smiley, traveled through the South, giving workshops on nonviolence. They would distribute the comic to younger attendees as something to take with them and study. Some [[African Americans]] memorized and destroyed the comic to avoid being [[lynched]] for having it in their possession.{{citation needed|date=June 2015}} At some point not long after its original publication, FoR produced a Spanish version of the comic for distribution throughout [[Latin America]]. Instead of using the same art as the English edition, the Spanish version is a complete copy of the original, drawn by a different artist. 125,000 copies were printed, but only a handful of copies of the Spanish version still exist. === Revival === In 2004 comic book artist, writer and historian Tom Christopher researched the King comic and posted the article, which included art samples of both the English and Spanish versions, on his website. Christopher had previously documented the publication of ''[[All-Negro Comics]]'' (1947) and the ''Golden Legacy'' and ''Fast Willie Jackson'' series (1976), and those articles included information on other comics such as ''Negro Heroes'' and ''[[Negro Romance]]''. Christopher described ''Martin Luther King and the Montgomery Story'' not in terms of being a rare or obscure comic but as an historic document, placing it in the political context of the times and explaining non-violence as a workable tool for social change. ''Martin Luther King and the Montgomery Story'' became a major attraction on his website, and the next ''[[Overstreet Comic Book Price Guide]]'' listed the book for the first time.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} By 2006, there were only a handful of copies of ''Martin Luther King and the Montgomery Story'' left in existence. That year, cartoonist/archivist [[Ethan Persoff]] scanned an original copy of the comic and posted it on his blog for [[Martin Luther King, Jr. Day]].Persoff, Ethan. [http://www.ep.tc/mlk/ "The 1956 International Bilingual Dr Martin Luther King Jr Comic Book Message,"] Ethan Persoff's blog (early January 2006). In 2008, Persoff reported that the Cairo director of the [[American Islamic Congress]] (AIC) had translated the scanned comic into [[Arabic]] and [[Persian language|Persian]]. The AIC's HAMSA (Hands Across the Mideast Support Alliance) initiative printed 2,500 copies of the translated comic, distributing them throughout [[Algeria]], [[Bahrain]], [[Iraq]], [[Kuwait]], [[Lebanon]], [[Morocco]], [[Saudi Arabia]], [[Tunisia]], and [[Yemen]].Persoff, Ethan. [http://www.ep.tc/intro-archive021.html#hamsa "HOW EP.TC IS UNINTENTIONALLY CONTRIBUTING TO WORLD PEACE,"] Ethan Persoff's blog (March 27, 2008). Until 2012, no history of ''Martin Luther King and the Montgomery Story'' had been written, and most versions of how the comic was created listed Al Capp as the actual creator. As part of his graduate degree at Georgetown University, [[Andrew Aydin]] wrote the first long-form history of ''The Montgomery Story'' as his graduate thesis. With the help of [[Carlow University]] Professor Dr. Sylvia Rhor and comic book icon [[Eddie Campbell]], Aydin established most of what is known about the comic's creation and use. In August 2013, Aydin published a shortened version of his thesis as the feature article in ''[[Creative Loafing]]'''s award-winning "Future of Nonviolence" issue, which was guest-edited by Congressman John Lewis and Aydin.{{cite web|last1=Aydin|first1=Andrew|title=The comic book that changed the world|url=http://clatl.com/atlanta/the-comic-book-that-changed-the-world/Content?oid=8807186|date=August 1, 2013|website=Creative Loafing|accessdate=7 July 2015}}{{cite web|last1=Michaud|first1=Debbie|last2=Williams|first2=Wyatt|title=Congressman John Lewis takes over Creative Loafing|url=http://clatl.com/atlanta/congressman-john-lewis-takes-over-creative-loafing/Content?oid=8828401|date=August 1, 2013|website=Creative Loafing|accessdate=7 July 2015}} In 2013, [[Top Shelf Productions]] published an authorized re-issue of the comic, with all proceeds going to the [[Fellowship of Reconciliation (United States)|Fellowship of Reconciliation]]. == Plot == The comic opens with a one-page synopsis of [[Martin Luther King, Jr.]]'s life and education up until 1957. The narrative then shifts to [[Montgomery, Alabama]], in 1954. An [[African American]] man named Jones tells of life in Montgomery under [[Jim Crow laws]]. He describes the events of the [[Montgomery Bus Boycott]] and the important role played by [[Rosa Parks]] and Martin Luther King, Jr. In the story, King advocates nonviolence, even when his own home is bombed during the boycott. The last section of the comic discusses the "Montgomery Method" of [[nonviolence]], its roots in the activism of [[Mahatma Gandhi]], and provides practical advice on how to pursue nonviolent activism. == Legacy == ''Martin Luther King and the Montgomery Story'' influenced other civil rights activists, including the [[Greensboro Four]]. Thanks to the 2008 [[American Islamic Congress]] HAMSA initiative, thousands of copies of the Arabic and Persian version of the comic were distributed to democracy advocates throughout the Middle East. When the [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011]] broke out, U.S. Representative [[John Lewis (Georgia politician)|John Lewis]] credited the mass-distribution of the 50-year-old comic as a contributing element in the Egyptian protests.Persoff, Ethan. [http://www.ep.tc/intro-archive070.html#mlk "OUR WEBSITE'S WORK USED IN WIDE-SPREAD EGYPTIAN PEACE CAMPAIGN"] Ethan Persoff blog (February 3–15, 2011). A [[hard copy]] of the Spanish edition of the comic is housed in the [[National Museum of African American History and Culture]], part of the [[Smithsonian Institution]]. === ''March'' === [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] Congressman [[John Lewis (Georgia politician)|John Lewis]] read ''Martin Luther King and the Montgomery Story'' as a teenager. The comic book demonstrated in clear fashion to Lewis the power of the philosophy and the discipline of nonviolence. Later, as he attended weekly meetings with students from [[Fisk University]], [[Tennessee State University]], [[Vanderbilt University]], and [[American Baptist College]] to discuss nonviolent protest, ''The Montgomery Story'' served as one of their guides.Hughes, Joseph (September 16, 2013). [http://comicsalliance.com/congressman-john-lewis-interview-march-andrew-aydin-top-shelf/ "Congressman John Lewis And Andrew Aydin Talk Inspiring The ‘Children Of The Movement’ With ‘March’ (Interview)"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130918055700/http://comicsalliance.com/congressman-john-lewis-interview-march-andrew-aydin-top-shelf/ |date=2013-09-18 }}. [[Comics Alliance]]. Lewis went on to become an important activist during the [[Civil Rights Movement]]. While working on his [[United States House of Representatives elections in Georgia, 2008|2008 reelection campaign]], Lewis told his telecommunications and technology policy aide, [[Andrew Aydin]], about ''The Montgomery Story'' and its influence. Aydin tracked down a copy of the comic (which had long since fallen out of print), and thought that Lewis' own story would make strong material for comic book treatment: {{quote|Once he told me about it, and I connected those dots that a comic book had a meaningful impact on the early days of the Civil Rights Movement, and in particular on young people, it just seemed self-evident. If it had happened before, why couldn't it happen again?}} Aydin repeatedly suggested that Lewis himself write a comic book, and eventually Lewis decided to commit to the project, on the condition that Aydin write it with him.Herbowy, Greg (Fall 2014). "Q+A: Congressman John Lewis, Andrew Aydin & Nate Powell". ''Visual Arts Journal''. [[School of Visual Arts]]. pp. 48 - 51 The award-winning ''[[March (comics)|March]]'' trilogy, written by Lewis & Aydin, illustrated by [[Nate Powell]], and published beginning in 2013 by [[Top Shelf Productions]], is the result.[http://www.ala.org/emiert/coretta-scott-king-book-awards-all-recipients-1970-present "Coretta Scott King Book Awards - All Recipients, 1970-Present"]. [[American Library Association]]. Retrieved December 4, 2014.[[MacDonald, Heidi]] (May 21, 2014). [http://comicsbeat.com/march-book-one-is-first-grahpic-novel-to-win-the-rfk-book-award/ "March Book One is first graphic novel to win the RFK Book Award"]. [[Comics Beat]]. == Awards == Top Shelf's authorized re-issue of ''Martin Luther King and the Montgomery Story'' won the 2014 [[Glyph Comics Award]] for Best Reprint Publication. == See also == * ''[[Stride Toward Freedom: The Montgomery Story]]'' * [[African-American Civil Rights Movement (1954–68) in popular culture]] * [[Portrayal of black people in comics]] == References == ===General references=== *{{gcdb series|id=1231|title=Martin Luther King and the Montgomery Story}} ===Inline citations=== {{Reflist}} == External links == * (Obsolete link) [http://kingencyclopedia.stanford.edu/primarydocuments/Comic%20Book%201957.pdf digitized version of ''Martin Luther King and the Montgomery Story''], hosted on Stanford University's website *{{comicbookdb|type=title|id=21607|title=''Martin Luther King and the Montgomery Story''}} * [http://www.ep.tc/mlk/index-s.html Spanish version of ''Martin Luther King and the Montgomery Story''], hosted on Ethan Persoff's blog * [http://www.hamsaweb.org/comic/ ''Martin Luther King and the Montgomery Story'' on the HAMSA website], with Arabic and Persian translations * [http://www.tomchristopher.com/martin-luther-king-jr-and-the-montgomery-story/ ''Martin Luther King and the Montgomery Story''] — Tom Christopher's updated 2004 article. {{Martin Luther King|state=collapsed}} {{African-American Civil Rights Movement|state=collapsed}} [[Category:Cultural depictions of Martin Luther King Jr.]] [[Category:History of African-American civil rights]] [[Category:African-American civil rights movement (1954–68) in popular culture]] [[Category:1957 comics debuts]] [[Category:Political comic strips]] [[Category:Biographical comics]] [[Category:American comics]] [[Category:Comics set in the 1950s]] [[Category:Comics based on real people]] [[Category:Works about American history]] [[Category:Works about American politics]] [[Category:Works about racism]] [[Category:Comics set in the United States]] [[Category:African-Americans in comic strips]] [[Category:Books about activists]] [[Category:Montgomery bus boycott]] [[Category:Fellowship of Reconciliation]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Marilee Bruszer | image = File:Bruszer marilee.jpg | image_size = 150px | alt = | caption = Undated photograph of Bruszer | birth_name = Marilee Lee Bruszer | birth_date = November 4, 1944 | birth_place = California, United States | disappeared = August 22, 1978 | disappeared_status = Remains identified after 37 years | death_date = {{circa}} August 1978 (aged 33) | death_place = | death_cause = [[Homicide]] by strangulation | body_discovered = September 3, 1978
[[Juab County, Utah]], [[United States]] | other_names = Juab County Jane Doe | resting_place = | known_for = Unidentified victim of homicide | height = | weight = | website = }} '''Marilee Lee Bruszer''', previously known as '''Juab County Jane Doe''', was a formerly unidentified [[Americans|American]] murder victim who was found on September 3, 1978. Bruszer's body was not identified for 37 years (until August 2015) due to an inaccurate physical description generated by the original investigators and the great distance she was found from where she had resided prior to her disappearance. ==Circumstances== [[File:Juab Yuba Lake Jane Doe Reconstruction 007.jpg|left|upright|thumb|Reconstruction of the Juab County Jane Doe]] Bruszer went missing on August 22, 1978 from [[Long Beach, California]]. Few details were available about her case, although authorities did believe she had been murdered and classified her as "endangered missing." Further into the investigation, her dental records and DNA information were obtained to compare against unidentified bodies in the country.{{cite web|title=Case File 1176DFCA|url=http://doenetwork.org/cases/1176dfca.html|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=20 October 2015}}{{cite web|title=Marilee Bruszer|url=https://www.findthemissing.org/cases/9493/211|website=findthemissing.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=20 October 2015|date=16 February 2011}} On September 3, 1978, the naked remains of a woman were found near the Yuba Lake campground in [[Juab County, Utah]] by three women who were fishing near the Yuba Dam.{{cite news|title=Victim of Strangler|work=The Times News|date=1978}} She was white and believed to have been five feet two to three inches ({{convert|62|to|63|in|cm|0|disp=out}}) tall at a weight around {{convert|110|lb}}, which was reported to be inconsistent with Bruszer's height and weight at {{convert|5|ft|5|in|cm|spell=in}} and {{convert|145|to|150|lb}}, respectively. The victim was said to have light blond hair that was {{convert|11|in|cm|spell=in}} long, although some sources state that it was brown, strawberry blond or sandy blond. Her natural hair color was likely light brown, as some pubic hair was found.{{cite web|title=Utah's Unidentified Persons|url=http://publicsafety.utah.gov/bci/UTAHunidentifiedpersons.html|website=publicsafety.utah.gov|publisher=Utah Bureau of Investigation|accessdate=September 16, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140831183108/http://publicsafety.utah.gov/bci/UTAHunidentifiedpersons.html|archive-date=2014-08-31|dead-url=yes|df=}} With the body, a double-hooped earring was found along with a white barrette. She had some dental crowding, which caused one of her front teeth to be crooked. The woman was believed to be between eighteen and twenty-two when she was strangled several months to three years before her body was found.{{cite web|title=Case File 751UFUT|url=http://doenetwork.org/cases/751ufut.html|website=doenetwork.org|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=September 16, 2014}}{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 8382|url=https://identifyus.org/cases/8382|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=September 16, 2014|date=January 14, 2011}} The age and time of death of the victim are now known to have been inaccurate, as Bruszer was thirty-three at the time she disappeared a month before the remains were found. ==Identification== Early into the investigation, it was speculated that the victim was one of four missing women from the area, Nancy Wilcox, Susan Curtis, Debra Kent and Nancy Baird. Later, these were eventually eliminated as potential identities after [[x-ray]]s of Juab County Jane Doe's teeth were compared to their dental records.{{cite news|title=Girl's Identity Remains Unknown|work=The Times News|date=1978}}{{cite news|title=State Seeks Help in Identifying Girl|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=336&dat=19780908&id=diVVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=-X8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6096,1853286|accessdate=20 October 2015|work=The Deseret News|date=8 September 1978|pages=10}} Currently, all four subjects still remain missing and have never been recovered.{{cite web|title=Susan Curtis|url=http://www.charleyproject.org/cases/c/curtis_susan.html|website=The Charley Project|date=12 December 2014|accessdate=20 October 2015}}{{cite web|title=Nancy Wilcox|url=http://www.charleyproject.org/cases/w/wilcox_nancy.html|website=The Charley Project|accessdate=20 October 2015|date=12 December 2014}}{{cite web|title=Debra Jean Kent|url=http://www.charleyproject.org/cases/k/kent_debra.html|website=The Charley Project|accessdate=20 October 2015|date=17 February 2015}}{{cite web|title=Nancy Perry Baird|url=http://www.charleyproject.org/cases/b/baird_nancy.html|website=The Charley Project|accessdate=20 October 2015|date=30 September 2013}} A detective was looking through the evidence locker at the [[Davis County Sheriff's Office (Utah)|Davis County Sheriff's Office]] in 2013 when he came across some hair marked "Hair from Yuba Lake body." This was attributed to retired Davis County Sheriff's Captain Kenny Payne formerly working there as well as the state medical examiner's office at the same time and misplacing the evidence. The detective sent it off to Juab County soon after.{{cite web|title=2 cold case victims identified in Juab Co. thanks to DNA|url=http://www.ksl.com/?sid=36762352&nid=148|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=September 16, 2014|date=September 30, 2015}} The [[Juab County Sheriff's Office]] secured a sample of this evidence and had it sent to Texas for testing in 2014. There, a DNA profile was generated and entered into the national database of missing people resulting in a familial match with two of Bruszer's family members who had submitted their DNA in the hopes of locating her. On August 22, 2015, the Long Beach Police informed the relatives that Bruszer had formally been identified. ==See also== * [[List of people who disappeared mysteriously]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{commons category|unidentified murder victims}} {{Unidentified decedent}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bruszer, Marilee}} [[Category:1944 births]] [[Category:1978 deaths]] [[Category:1978 murders in the United States]] [[Category:American murder victims]] [[Category:Deaths by person in the United States]] [[Category:Deaths by strangulation in the United States]] [[Category:Formerly missing people found dead]] [[Category:Incidents of violence against women]] [[Category:People from Juab County, Utah]] [[Category:People from Long Beach, California]] [[Category:People murdered in Utah]] [[Category:People who were forensically reconstructed]] [[Category:Unsolved murders in the United States]] [[Category:Female murder victims]]
