revision.text:
{{infobox play | image = Aaron Sorkin at the Music Box Theatre in 2007.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = Aaron Sorkin discussing ''The Farnsworth Invention'' with an audience at the [[Music Box Theatre]] on November 8, 2007 | writer = [[Aaron Sorkin]] | chorus = | characters = | mute = | setting = | premiere = | place = | orig_lang = English | series = | subject = | genre = | web = }} '''''The Farnsworth Invention''''' is a [[stage play]] by [[Aaron Sorkin]] adapted from an unproduced [[screenplay]] about [[Philo Farnsworth]]'s first fully functional and completely all-electronic [[television]] system and [[David Sarnoff]], the [[RCA]] president who stole the design. == Screenplay == On April 29, 2004, [[New Line Cinema]] announced they had acquired the drama script ''The Farnsworth Invention'' from award-winning writer Aaron Sorkin. [[Thomas Schlamme]] was set to direct. The release read in part: "''The Farnsworth Invention'' tells the story of [[Philo Farnsworth]], a boy genius born in Beaver, Utah, who later moved to Rigby, Idaho, where he began experimenting with electricity. In 1920, when Farnsworth was 14, he showed his high school chemistry teacher a design he had made for an electronic television only to become involved in an all or nothing battle with [[David Sarnoff]], the young president of [[RCA]] and [[United States|America]]'s first communications mogul." Schlamme described the movie as "a classic American tale driven by the conflict between a [[Mormon]] farmer and a [[Russia]]n immigrant over the ownership of the most influential invention of the 20th Century." Following its initial press release, New Line did not disclose any additional information about the film. As a result, [[website]]s such as the [[The Internet Movie Database|Internet Movie Database]] incorrectly anticipated a film in 2005. IMDb eventually removed the entry. == Stage play == In 2005 it was announced that Sorkin was adapting the screenplay for the stage and the play would debut in the [[Abbey Theatre]] in [[Dublin]], [[Ireland]]. It was staged at the [[La Jolla Playhouse]] from February 20 - March 25, 2007 as "a page-to-stage production" with [[Jimmi Simpson]] (''[[Zodiac (2007 film)|Zodiac]]'') playing Farnsworth and [[Stephen Lang (actor)|Stephen Lang]] (''[[Gods and Generals (film)|Gods and Generals]]'', ''[[Avatar (2009 film)|Avatar]]'') as Sarnoff. Award-winning composer [[Andrew Lippa]] penned 45 minutes of music to underscore the drama. It was scheduled to open on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] on November 14, 2007, but this was delayed due to the [[2007 Broadway stagehand strike]].[http://www.playbill.com/news/article/109037.html Aaron Sorkin's Farnsworth Invention to Open on Broadway in November] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070626121651/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/109037.html |date=2007-06-26 }} – ''[[Playbill]]'' Article, June 21, 2007 It opened at the [[Music Box Theatre]] on December 3, 2007, with [[Hank Azaria]] in the Sarnoff role due to Lang's commitment to [[James Cameron]]'s 2009 film ''[[Avatar (2009 film)|Avatar]]''. The show closed on March 2, 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.farnsworthonbroadway.com/ |title=Official Show Website |publisher=Farnsworthonbroadway.com |date= |accessdate=2009-09-15}} An Australian production directed by Louise Fischer officially opened on July 13, 2011 at the [[New Theatre (Newtown)|New Theatre]] in [[Newtown, New South Wales|Newtown]]. == Historical accuracy == The play is not historically accurate, and is an intentional alteration of the story. It shows Farnsworth as being defeated legally by Sarnoff, and then spending his life in obscurity. In reality, Farnsworth won the lawsuit, later received a $1 million payment from RCA for the purchase of his TV patents, and went on to have an illustrious career in technological research. There is a statue of Farnsworth in [[Statuary Hall]] in the [[U.S. Capitol]]. This issue was later addressed on a Facebook question where Sorkin wrote: {{cquote|There were many lawsuits, appeals and counter-suits that covered years. Farnsworth won some of them and lost some of them. The final result—certainly in the context of the play I'd written—was a loss. Farnsworth died, as Sarnoff says at the end, "drunk, broke and in obscurity" and whether or not it was the result of corporate espionage or theft was the subject of the play. That's a long of way of saying I conflated many lawsuits into one.Sorkin, Aaron. "Questions for me?" Message Board on Sorkin's [[Facebook]] page
—Aaron Sorkin}} == Critical reception == In ''[[The New York Times]]'', [[Ben Brantley]] [[Damn with faint praise|panned the play with faint praise]]: {{cquote|The show certainly deserves high marks for all those traits that exacting schoolteachers hold dear: conciseness, legibility, correct use of [[topic sentence]]s, evidence in defense of two sides of an argument and colorful examples to support the main thesis .... And yet you’re likely to leave “The Farnsworth Invention” feeling that you have just watched an animated Wikipedia entry, fleshed out with the sort of anecdotal scenes that figure in “re-enactments” on E! channel documentaries and true-crime shows.[http://theater2.nytimes.com/2007/12/04/theater/reviews/04farn.html?pagewanted=1&sq=david%20sarnoff&st=nyt&scp=2 Brantley, Ben. "A Farm Boy and a Mogul, and How They Changed the World,"] ''New York Times.'' December 4, 2007.}} In the ''[[New York Post]]'', [[Clive Barnes (critic)|Clive Barnes]] awarded it 2½ out of 4 stars and stated, "Sorkin's take on the Farnsworth/Sarnoff standoff would be better suited to a screen, either big or small. Even now, while crackling with crisp dialogue, ''The Farnsworth Invention'' often has the air of a clumsy stage adaptation of, say, ''[[Citizen Kane]]''." {{cite news|last=Barnes |first=Clive |url=http://www.nypost.com/seven/12042007/entertainment/theater/back_to_bway_with_made_for_tv_tale_502570.htm |title=''New York Post'' review |publisher=Nypost.com |date=2007-12-04 |accessdate=2009-09-15}} Joe Dziemianowicz of the ''[[New York Daily News]]'' described it as "disappointing and ho-hum" and "seldom deeply involving . . . Scenes play out like brief [[vignette (literature)|vignette]]s from a [[History (U.S. TV channel)|History Channel]] biopic . . . without stirring emotions." {{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/arts/2007/12/04/2007-12-04_tale_of_tv_in_farnsworth_invention_goes_.html |title=''New York Daily News'' review |publisher=Nydailynews.com |date=2007-12-04 |accessdate=2009-09-15}} In ''[[Newsday]]'', Linda Winer called it "vintage Sorkin and crackling prime-time theater . . . breezy and shrewd, smart-alecky and idealistic." {{cite news|first=Linda|last=Winer|title=Review: Aaron Sorkin's "The Farnsworth Invention|url=http://www.newsday.com/entertainment/stage/ny-secsingdec04,0,3986500.story|publisher=[[Newsday]]|date=December 4, 2007|accessdate=2007-12-12 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071207175542/http://www.newsday.com/entertainment/stage/ny-secsingdec04,0,3986500.story |archivedate = 2007-12-07}} In ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', David Rooney said, "The plot-heavy drama is light on fully fleshed-out characters or subtext, making it likely to play more satisfyingly when it inevitably reverts to being a film or [[cable television|cable]] project . . . [it] never fully moves beyond its stream of over-explained factoids." {{cite news|url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117935557.html?categoryid=33&cs=1 |title=''Variety'' review |publisher=Variety.com |date= December 3, 2007|accessdate=2009-09-15 |first=David |last=Rooney}} In the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'', Hedy Weiss described it as "a firecracker of a play in a fittingly snap, crackle and pop production under the direction of Des McAnuff, the drama has among its many virtues the ability to make you think at the same time that it breaks your heart." {{cite news|first=Hedy|last=Weiss|title=Moguls, Scientists, and 'Farnsworth'|url=http://www.suntimes.com/entertainment/weiss/679274,CST-FTR-farn04web.article|publisher=[[The Chicago Sun-Times]]|date=December 4, 2007|accessdate=2007-12-12}} Chris Jones of the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' called it "slick yet deeply conflicted" and "restless" and added, "this is one of those Boomer-friendly, media-savvy, self-aware pieces of effective theater that feel like they owe a lot to TV writing and our celebrity-obsessed culture . . . this is a jumpy piece of writing. It feels like the writer is worried the audience might change the channel. That's not entirely a bad thing. As fans of Sorkin's TV shows know well, the internal psyche of Sorkin is a very stimulating place in which to dwell for a couple of hours. His characters are uncommonly articulate and witty—albeit without much differentiation. He has mastered all the dramatic rules so well, he can titillate you by deconstructing and then reassembling them. And in this case he certainly knows how to make a dry scientific quest into a provocative piece of theater." {{cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/chi-sorkin_onlinedec06,1,6902398.story |title=''Chicago Tribune'' review |publisher=Chicagotribune.com |date=2007-12-06 |accessdate=2009-09-15 | first=Chris | last=Jones}} == Further reading == * {{cite book |title=The Last Lone Inventor: A Tale of Genius, Deceit & the Birth of Television |author=Evan I. Schwartz |date=2003-05-13 |publisher=Harper Paperbacks |isbn=978-0-06-093559-7}} == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * {{IBDB show|465453}} * [http://www.farnsworthonbroadway.com/trailer See the official trailer for "The Farnsworth Invention"] * [http://www.thefarnsworthinvention.com The Farnsworth Invention: Fact -v- Fiction] * {{Official website|http://www.farnsworthonbroadway.com|''The Farnsworth Invention'' official website}} * [http://www.philotfarnsworth.com Farnsworth Archives] * [https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/technology/bigdream/abprogram.html PBS American Experience Documentary : ''Big Dream, Small Screen''] * [http://www.bairdtelevision.com/Farnoff.html The Saga of ''The Farnsworth Invention''] {{Aaron Sorkin}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Farnsworth Invention, The}} [[Category:2007 plays]] [[Category:Broadway plays]] [[Category:American plays]] [[Category:Plays based on actual events]] [[Category:Plays set in the United States]] [[Category:Idaho in fiction]]

{{coord|53.477|-2.231|display=title|region:GB_scale:5000}} {{Infobox venue | name = The Warehouse Project | location = Store St., Manchester (present)
Victoria Warehouse, Trafford (2012-2013)
Store St., Manchester (2007-11)
[[Strangeways Brewery]], Manchester (2006) | type = [[Nightclub]] | genre= [[House music|House]], [[techno]], [[Trance music|Trance]], [[Electro music|electro]], [[Concert|live concerts]] | coordinates = | opened = 2006 | seating_capacity= 2000{{cite web|url=http://www.skiddle.com/whats-on/Manchester/The-Warehouse-Project/ |title=The Warehouse Project Manchester | Events and tickets for The Warehouse Project in Manchester |publisher=Skiddle.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-07}} | website = [http://www.thewarehouseproject.com/ www.thewarehouseproject.com] }} [[File:Piccadilly Station Manchester - geograph.org.uk - 692981.jpg|thumb|Warehouse Project events have been held underneath Piccadilly station (Store Street) since 2014, and were also previously held here from 2007 to 2011.]] '''The Warehouse Project''' is a series of club nights organised in [[Greater Manchester]], England, since 2006. Unlike most other clubs, it has a limited seasonal approach rather than running all year. Each year's season runs from September through to New Years Day, plus occasional one off dates such as Bank Holiday weekends. This period corresponds with the busiest time of the year and the student calendar.{{cite web|url=http://www.enforbusiness.com/interview/five-minutes-sacha-lord-marchionne-and-sam-kandel-founders-warehouse-project |title=Five minutes with... Sacha Lord-Marchionne and Sam Kandel, founders of the Warehouse Project | Interview |publisher=EN for Business |date= |accessdate=2014-06-07}} ==History== The Warehouse Project was initially started as a joint venture by Sacha Lord-Marchionne and Sam Kandel, who both had previous involvement with the [[Sankeys (nightclub)|Sankeys]] nightclub in Manchester. It began operations in the disused [[Strangeways Brewery|Boddingtons Brewery]] in [[Strangeways]], and then moved into a space under [[Manchester Piccadilly railway station|Manchester Piccadilly station]], on Store Street, which previously served as an air raid shelter.{{cite web|url=http://www.djmag.com/news/detail/921 |title=The Warehouse Project |publisher=djmag.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-07}} On 14 July 2011, The Warehouse Project announced that the 2011 season would be the last ever WHP event at Store Street.{{cite web|url=http://www.skiddle.com/groups/whp/news/9668.html |title=Latest News: Composit Music |publisher=Skiddle.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-07}} This was followed by a later announcement on 22 March 2012 that the 2012 season would be based at the Victoria Warehouse Hotel, to the west of [[Manchester city centre]] in [[Trafford Park]], near [[Old Trafford]] football stadium. The club remained at this location for the 2013 season as well. In late 2013, rumours started that The Warehouse Project was due to move to the disused [[Manchester Mayfield railway station|Mayfield Depot]] next to Manchester Piccadilly station from 2014 but a planning application was subsequently withdrawn in September 2013. The Warehouse Project's 2013 season drew to a close at the end of the year, with a final closing party on 1 January 2014 at the Victoria Warehouse Hotel venue.{{cite web |title=Manchester Mayfield railway station |url=http://www.manchesterconfidential.co.uk/News/Warehouse-Project-Coming-Back-To-City-Centre-Manchester-Mayfield-Depot |work=Manchester Confidential |date=28 August 2013 |accessdate=2013-10-06}} Despite the announcement made in 2011, the 2014 season returned to Store Street, in a move being described by the organisers as returning to their "spiritual home" for one last year.{{cite web|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/whats-on/music-nightlife-news/warehouse-project-announces-2014-season-7250904 |title=Warehouse Project announces 2014 season launch party |publisher=manchestereveningnews.co.uk |date=2014-06-11 |accessdate=2014-07-14}} During this time, the owners of Mayfield Depot decided to redevelop their site rather than retaining it as a cultural venue.,{{Cite web |title=Warehouse Project plans to move into Mayfield Depot scrapped after owners pull out |url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/whats-on/whats-on-news/warehouse-project-mayfield-depot-nightclub-7561930 |work=Manchester Evening News |date=6 August 2014 |accessdate=2014-08-06}} so the 2015 season will again be located at the Store Street location. The 2017 season was announced in July 2017, with 31 shows returning to Store Street once again from September.{{cite web|url=https://www.skiddle.com/news/all/The-Warehouse-Project-2017-line-up-announced/31913/ |title=The Warehouse Project 2017 Lineups Announced}} ==Music and artists== Since its foundation the club has played host to numerous internationally acclaimed DJs such as [[Carl Cox]], [[Sven Väth]], [[Aphex Twin]], [[Richie Hawtin]], [[Deadmau5]], [[Annie Mac]], [[Pete Tong]], [[Armand Van Helden]] and [[Erick Morillo]], and musicians such as [[De La Soul]], [[Happy Mondays]], [[Chic (band)|Chic]], [[The Prodigy]], [[Disclosure (band)|Disclosure]], [[Basement Jaxx]] and [[Foals (band)|Foals]].{{cite web|url=http://www.4clubbers.net/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=1436 |title=Topic: News In Efficient Options For Garcinia Extract |publisher=4clubbers |date=2012-11-12 |accessdate=2014-06-07}} In 2007, The Warehouse Project was voted by dance music magazine ''[[Mixmag]]'' as the best club in the [[United Kingdom]].{{cite web|url=http://vivalifestyle.co.uk/148/ |title=Manchester's most influential club in the last five years: The Warehouse Project |publisher=Viva Lifestyle |date=2012 |accessdate=2015-03-04}} In 2013 The Warehouse Project was voted by ''DJ mag'' as the ''Best Club Series'' in the magazines ''Best of British Awards''.{{cite web|url=http://www.djmag.com/content/best-club-series-warehouse-project |title=Best club series: The Warehouse Project |date=2013 |accessdate=2015-03-04}} The Warehouse Project is noted for placing international DJs alongside less established artists. ==Fatalities== Two high-profile deaths have occurred at The Warehouse Project, those of Nick Bonnie and Souvik Pal, alongside several reports in the media of near-misses.{{cite web|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/suspected-drug-dealer-critically-ill-6110301 |title=Suspected drug dealer critically ill after swallowing drugs at Warehouse Project |publisher=Manchester Evening News |date=2013-09-29}}{{cite web|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/warehouse-project-clubber-hospitalised-after-6150668 |title=Woman hospitalised after taking drugs at Warehouse Project comes out of coma |publisher=Manchester Evening News |date=2013-10-07}} These incidents resulted in calls from local councillors such as David Acton and Mike Cordingley for the licence to be revoked or reviewed.{{cite web|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/revealed-shocking-full-toll-drug-6118379 |title=Warehouse Project: Revealed, shocking full toll of drug horror at death club |publisher=Manchester Evening News |date=2013-10-01}} However, police statements have countered this, with high-ranking officers supporting the club and is management.{{cite web|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/warehouse-project-tragedy-man-gloucestershire-6108246 |title=Warehouse Project tragedy: Man from Gloucestershire dies and five others hospitalised after taking ecstasy |publisher=Manchester Evening News |date=2013-09-28}} Sixteen individuals were hospitalised during the first weekend of the 2013 season from taking drugs at the venue, and also include drug dealers at the club who have attempted to avoid arrest by swallowing all their stash. ===Souvik Pal=== At the end of the 2012 season, on New Year's Eve, Souvik Pal was escorted out of the club.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2013/jan/08/missing-manchester-student-father |title=Missing Manchester students father arrives in UK from India to help search |publisher=The Guardian |date=2013-01-08}} He was subsequently found dead in the adjacent canal later that month.{{cite web|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/mystery-man-bridge-hold-clue-6257710 |title=Mystery man on bridge may hold clue over death of Warehouse Project clubber |publisher=Manchester Evening News |date=2013-10-31}}{{cite web|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/indian-student-souvik-pals-body-1235671 |title=Souvik Pals body found in canal near spot where he disappeared |publisher=Manchester Evening News |date=2013-01-23}} The unexplained death was later reclassified as a murder investigation after reports of Souvik being seen leaving the area with an unknown individual after being thrown out of the club. Although the death did not occur on the premises of the club, local councilors questioned whether the security at the club was sufficient. ===Nick Bonnie=== On the very first night of the 2013 season, a group of friends from [[Gloucestershire]] attended the opening event at The Warehouse Project. During the course of the night, one of their party fell ill and had to be taken to hospital, where he later died due to an overdose of an illegal drug he had consumed at The Warehouse Project. Initially, it was believed that Nick had purchased the drug inside club from a dealer, largely due to testimony of his friends, and this led to police and media fears of a "bad" batch of [[MDMA|ecstasy]], possibly laced with [[Para-Methoxyamphetamine|PMA]]. However, in subsequent court proceedings, the friends admitted to having invented this story to cover that they had brought the drug into the club themselves.{{cite web|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/pals-warehouse-project-drug-death-clubber-7968116 |title=Pals of Warehouse Project drug-death clubber Nick Bonnie walk free after admitting lies over tragedy |publisher=Manchester Evening News |date=2014-10-20}} The fall out from the death led to further calls for the club's license to be reviewed, and in the following days further hospital statements contributed to media reporting that the club itself had become an unacceptable risk.{{cite web|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/revealed-shocking-full-toll-drug-6118379 |title=Hospital staff left in tears by spate of bad ecstasy victims |publisher=Manchester Evening News |date=2013-10-01}} The club responded to this by increasing in the number of medical and security staff at the venue. Various national politicians, including the Prime Minister [[David Cameron]], commented on the incident and the dangers posed by people taking illegal drugs at clubs such as The Warehouse Project, calling it a tragic death.{{cite web|url=http://www.itv.com/news/update/2013-09-30/david-cameron-charity-workers-death-is-tragic/ |title=Charity workers drugs death |publisher=ITV |date=2013-09-30}} ==References== {{reflist}} Detail Report * [http://www.thewarehouseproject.com/ The Warehouse Project official website] * [https://www.skiddle.com/whats-on/Manchester/The-Warehouse-Project/ The Warehouse Project Official Ticket Outlet 2017] {{DEFAULTSORT:Warehouse Project, The}} [[Category:Music venues in Manchester]] [[Category:Music venues in Greater Manchester]] [[Category:Club nights]] [[Category:Electronic dance music venues]]

page.title: U.S. raid on the Iranian Liaison Office in Erbil

revision.comment: Rescuing 0 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9)
revision.text:
The '''US raid on the Iranian Liaison Office in Erbil''' refers to the events of 11 January 2007 when the [[Military of the United States|US military]] raided the [[Iran]]ian Liaison Office (which was in the process of becoming accredited as an officially recognized [[consulate]])<ref name=iran-20070119>{{citation |url=http://www.securitycouncilreport.org/atf/cf/%7B65BFCF9B-6D27-4E9C-8CD3-CF6E4FF96FF9%7D/Iran%20S200728.pdf|title=Letter dated 19 January 2007 from the Chargé d’affaires a.i. of the Permanent Mission of the Islamic Republic of Iran to the United Nations addressed to the Secretary-General|date=22 January 2007|publisher=[[United Nations]]|id=A/61/706–S/2007/28|accessdate=2008-05-05}}</ref> in [[Erbil]], [[Iraq]], ostensibly to detain two senior Iranian officials but capturing five mid-level diplomats instead.<ref name=WP-20070621>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/06/20/AR2007062001456.html|title=U.S. Refuses to Free 5 Captured Iranians Until at Least October|author=Robin Wright|work=[[Washington Post]]|date=June 21, 2007|accessdate=2008-05-05}}</ref><ref name=Independent-20070403 /> The [[US government]]'s position is that the office was used by the Iranian [[Revolutionary Guards]] as a local headquarters. However, both Iranian and [[Kurdish Autonomous Region]] officials state that it was a diplomatic mission in the city of Arbil (Irbil) in [[Iraqi Kurdistan]].<ref name=IHT-20070406>{{cite news|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/04/07/africa/ME-GEN-Iraq-US-Iran-Prisoners.php|title=Kurdish leader: US sought to capture Iranian Revolutionary Guard officials in Irbil raid|publisher=[[International Herald Tribune]]|date=2007-04-06|accessdate=2007-04-07}}</ref><ref name=WP-20070112>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/01/11/AR2007011100427.html|title=U.S. Troops Raid 2 Iranian Targets in Iraq, Detain 5 People|author=Robin Wright and Nancy Trejos|work=[[Washington Post]]|date=2007-01-12|accessdate=2007-04-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2007/0111/breaking17.htm|title=US raids Iranian consulate in Iraq|date=2007-01-11|publisher=ireland.com|accessdate=2008-05-05}}</ref>
On July 9, 2009, US authorities released the five diplomats (Mohsen Bagheri, Mahmoud Farhadi, Majid Ghaemi, Majid Dagheri and Abbas Jami), after more than two and a half years imprisonment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/07/09/iraq.iranians.released/index.html|title=Iranians held in Iraq since 2007 released |publisher=CNN |accessdate=15 July 2017}}</ref> The US said this action was required under the [[U.S.–Iraq Status of Forces Agreement]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/2009-07-09-voa52.cfm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090717220255/http://www.voanews.com/english/2009-07-09-voa52.cfm|dead-url=yes|archive-date=17 July 2009|title=US: Iranian Prisoner Release Not a Gesture to Tehran|publisher=Voice of America|accessdate=15 July 2017}}</ref>
==The raid== According to [[Iran]]ian officials, five U.S. helicopters landed on the roof of the liaison office in Arbil. U.S. soldiers entered the building, detained five people and took away materials.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newswire.co.nz/main/viewstory.aspx?storyid=354288&catid=0|title=Page not found - NewsWire.co.nz|publisher=|accessdate=15 July 2017}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The raid occurred between 3 and 5 a.m., when the U.S. troops entered the liaison office after disarming the guards.<ref name=WP-20070112 /> Two senior local Kurdish officials said the forces confiscated computers and documents.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yorkdispatch.com/nationworld/ci_4992823|title=Iraqi officials say multinational forces detained Iranian staffers from Tehran's consulate|work=York Dispatch|accessdate=15 July 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120205103252/http://www.yorkdispatch.com/nationworld/ci_4992823|archivedate=5 February 2012|df=}}</ref>
In a report which was later confirmed by [[Massoud Barzani]], the President of the [[Kurdistan Regional Government]],<ref name="w3123">[https://www.theguardian.com/worldlatest/story/0,,-6538988,00.html Kurd: U.S. Sought Other Iranians in Raid], ''[[The Guardian]]'', April 7, 2007</ref> ''[[The Independent]]'' noted that instead of the current captives, the U.S. had hoped to capture the deputy head of the Iranian [[Supreme National Security Council]], Mohammed Jafari, and chief of intelligence of the IRGC, General Manuchehr Frouzandeh, who were on an official visit to Iraq ostensibly to improve co-operation in the area of bilateral security, during which they met the [[Iraqi President]] [[Jalal Talabani]]. Barzani stated: "They (the commanders) came here and they came openly. Their meetings with the president and myself were reported on television. The Americans came to detain this delegation, not the people in the office. They came to the wrong place at the wrong time."<ref name=Independent-20070403 /><ref name=IHT-20070406 /> It was also reported that U.S. troops attempted to detain people at the [[Arbil International Airport|Arbil airport]] that same day, but Kurdish forces intervened. Iraqi Foreign Minister [[Hoshyar Zebari]] said that there was almost a confrontation between U.S. and Kurdish troops at the airport but that "a massacre was avoided at the last minute."<ref name=WP-20070112 />
The raid took place within hours of [[U.S. President]] [[George W. Bush]] claiming "Iran is providing material support for attacks on American troops" in an address to the nation.<ref name=Independent-20070403>{{cite news|url=http://news.independent.co.uk/world/middle_east/article2414760.ece |title=The botched US raid that led to the hostage crisis |author=[[Patrick Cockburn]] |work=[[The Independent]] |date=2007-04-03 |accessdate=2007-04-03 |location=London |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070406172103/http://news.independent.co.uk/world/middle_east/article2414760.ece |archivedate=2007-04-06 |df= }}</ref>
This was not the first time the United States had arrested alleged [[Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps|IRGC]] members in Iraq. A few weeks before, on 29 December, U.S. forces in Iraq released alleged Iranian IRGC members who were detained for alleged weapons smuggling after a raid conducted 21 December in [[Baghdad]].<ref>[http://www.indiadaily.com/breaking_news/84145.asp IndiaDaily<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110518203655/http://www.indiadaily.com/breaking_news/84145.asp |date=2011-05-18 }}</ref><ref name=bbc-20061229>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/6216455.stm|title=US frees detained Iran diplomats|date=29 December 2006|publisher=[[BBC]]|accessdate=2008-05-05}}</ref>
==Status of office== The Iranian liaison office in Arbil has been active and operating since 1992. The various governments dispute the exact status of the office.
According to Iraqi Foreign Minister [[Hoshyar Zebari]], the detained Iranians had been working in Arbil with official sanction, and the liaison office was in the process of becoming a full consulate; however the office was yet to be classified as a consulate with diplomatic protection.<ref name=khaleej-20070125>{{cite news|url=http://www.khaleejtimes.com/DisplayArticleNew.asp?xfile=data/middleeast/2007/January/middleeast_January262.xml&section=middleeast&col=|work=Khaleej Times Online|agency=AFP|title=US says its has proof Iran is interfering in Iraq|date=25 January 2007|accessdate=2008-05-05|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071201130210/http://khaleejtimes.com/DisplayArticleNew.asp?xfile=data%2Fmiddleeast%2F2007%2FJanuary%2Fmiddleeast_January262.xml&section=middleeast&col=|archivedate=1 December 2007|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/article/0,,30200-1247222,00.html|title=Arrests 'Violated Law'|date=January 12, 2007|publisher=[[Sky News]]|accessdate=2008-05-05}}</ref>
Iran states that based on an agreement between the Governments of Iran and Iraq its status was officially changed to a [[Consulate General]], and official ''note verbale'' (diplomatic notes) were exchanged between the two countries accordingly.<ref name=iran-20070119 /> According to the [[Vienna Convention on Consular Relations]] consulates enjoy immunity and all members of the U.N. have to respect such immunity.
Officials of the [[Kurdistan Regional Government]] said that consular activities, such as the issuance of visas, had been carried out by the office staff since 1992, and they were treated as if they were accredited diplomats.<ref name=AsiaTimes-20070331>[http://www.atimes.com/atimes/Middle_East/IC31Ak04.html US silent on detained Iranians], [[Asia Times]], 31 March 2007</ref>
The [[U.S. State Department]] spokesman [[Sean McCormack]] said the detainees were not diplomats.<ref name=khaleej-20070125 />
==Reactions== [[Masoud Barzani]] condemned the capture and demanded the quick release of Iranians.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baztab.ir/news/57601.php|title=بارزاني و دستور محاصره نظاميان آمريكا براي آزادي سريع ديپلمات‌هاي ايران<!-- Bot generated title -->|publisher=|accessdate=15 July 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071029171037/http://www.baztab.ir/news/57601.php|archivedate=29 October 2007|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/worldlatest/story/0,,-6338889,00.html | location=London}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref> [[Kurdistan]]i government was reportedly unaware of the US plans to raid the Iranian liaison office and did not know the purpose of the operation. After raiding the office, the US forces headed for Eikawa district, which hosts foreign companies and countries' representatives. Security forces of the [[Kurdistan Democratic Party|Democratic Party of Kurdistan]] (KDP) reportedly surrounded three US military vehicles to prevent them from further action.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web|url=http://www.teluguportal.net/modules/news/article.php?storyid=28059|title=WordPress › Error<!-- Bot generated title -->|publisher=|accessdate=15 July 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121208032210/http://www.teluguportal.net/modules/news/article.php?storyid=28059|archivedate=8 December 2012|df=}}</ref>
Iran's Foreign Ministry spokesman Mohammad Ali Hosseini told state-run radio the raid was against a diplomatic mission since the presence of Iranian staffers in Arbil was legal. Hosseini said the action by coalition forces reflected a continuation of pressure on Iran, aiming to "create tension" between Iraq and its neighbors.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.forbes.com/feeds/ap/2007/01/11/ap3322132.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070117015100/http://www.forbes.com/feeds/ap/2007/01/11/ap3322132.html|archivedate=2007-01-17 }} </ref>
In [[Tehran]], Iran summoned the ambassadors of [[Iraq]] and [[Switzerland]] (which represents US interests in Iran) over the consulate raid.<ref name=autogenerated1 />
The [[UN Secretary General]]'s described the incident as "disputes between individual states". A UN spokesman said "We've left it to the respective countries to work it out among themselves ... Ultimately it's up to Security Council members themselves to determine how its resolutions get implemented."<ref name=AsiaTimes-20070331 />
On March 10 at a meeting of envoys in [[Baghdad]] the Iranian delegation raised the issue of the five detained Iranians. A US spokesman said that Iraq had asked the US side to investigate the circumstances involving the detention. Iran says it was assured by Iraq that the five would be released by March 21, the [[Iranian new year]].<ref>[http://www.ft.com/cms/s/b9422276-dd47-11db-8d42-000b5df10621.html Mideast security talks face delay], [[Financial Times]], 28 March 2007</ref>
Some claim that the increased diplomatic tension created by this incident lead to the [[2007 Iranian seizure of Royal Navy personnel|Iranian seizure of 15 Royal Navy personnel]] in a border dispute two months later.<ref name=Independent-20070403 />
===Alleged retaliation=== According to American journalist [[Robin Wright (author)|Robin Wright]], the [[2007 Iranian seizure of Royal Navy personnel|2007 seizure of fifteen British sailors]] in the Persian Gulf was likely connected to the holding of the five Iranian officials. The seizure of the British came three days after [[Nowruz]], a date that the Iranian government had announced that it expected the five officials to be freed by, and which passed without their release. "The common denominator was the Revolutionary Guards." Iranians being held by the US were "[[Quds Force]] operatives" (the foreign operation branch of the [[Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps|Revolutionary Guards]]), while the Iranian naval unit that had taken the British hostage were also Revolutionary Guards.<ref>Wright, Robin, ''Dreams and Shadows : the Future of the Middle East'', Penguin Press, 2008 p.335</ref> When the Sailors were released twelve days later and the five Iranians remained in detained, "Tehran shifted its focus", according to Wright. One month later four Iranian Americans with dual nationalities—[[Ali Shakeri]], [[Haleh Esfandiari]], [[Kian Tajbakhsh]], [[Parnaz Azima]]—were detained for unspecified `crimes against national security.`<ref>Wright, Robin, ''Dreams and Shadows : the Future of the Middle East'', Penguin Press, 2008 p.335-6</ref>
==In custody== The Iranian consular officers were: Naser Bagheri, [[Mousa Chegini]], Abbas Hatami Kakavand, Hamid Askari Shokouh and Majid Ghaemi.<ref name=iran-20070119 />
Under [[Law enforcement in Iraq|Iraqi law]], detainees identified as insurgents should be charged in civilian courts. They may be held up to 14 days before being brought before a magistrate. These requirements appear to be systematically ignored in practice.<ref name=AsiaTimes-20070331 /> In this incident, the Iraqi government denies that the detainees were helping insurgents.<ref name="w3123" />
In 2008<ref name="first">{{cite web|url=http://www.albawaba.com/en/countries/Iraq/214878|title=albawaba.com middle east news information::Iran complains about detention conditions of diplomats in US custody<!-- Bot generated title -->|publisher=|accessdate=15 July 2017}}</ref> three of the five Iranian detainees were being held at a U.S. prison camp in Iraq. According to the United States Defense Department they were under interrogation and the U.S. had "no plans to free them while they are seen as a security risk in Iraq".<ref name=Times-20070327>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/article1572776.ece|title=Kidnapping could be traced back to arrests by US forces|author=Richard Beeston|work=[[The Times]]|date=2007-03-27|accessdate=2007-04-03 | location=London}}</ref> An [[International Committee of the Red Cross]] representative met the five Iranian employees in March 2008 and reported "they were in good health."<ref name=Alalam-20070404>{{cite news|url=http://www.alalam.ir/english/en-newspage.asp?newsid=009030120070404162240 |title=Abducted Iranians to Meet Iran Envoy |publisher=[[Alalam News]] |date=2007-04-04 |accessdate=2007-04-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927040934/http://www.alalam.ir/english/en-newspage.asp?newsid=009030120070404162240 |archivedate=2007-09-27 |df= }}</ref> However, this claim has been doubted by the families of the captured workers, stating they worry about the circumstances they were in, and whether they might be under prolonged torture by Americans to acquire false confessions.<ref>mms://217.218.67.244/presstv/070517/diplomats.wmv{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> After its first consular meeting with the captives, Iran announced that the "[detainees] have complained about their kidnapping, the US attitude and non-observance of international regulations."<ref name="first" />
===Release of some Iranians=== On November 9, 2007, United States released two of the detainees (after 305 days) as well as 7 other Iranian citizens. The other seven Iranians being freed had been picked up in different parts of the country and held for periods ranging between three months and three years.<ref name=bbc-20071109>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/7086402.stm|title=US releases nine Iranians in Iraq|date=9 November 2007|publisher=[[BBC]]|accessdate=2008-05-05}}</ref> Here is the list of those who were released:<ref name=autogenerated2>[http://www.radiozamaneh.info/news/2007/11/_9_1.html رادیو زمانه | خبر اول | ايران و آمريکا | 9 ایرانی از زندان آمریکا در عراق آزاد شدند<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * [[Mousa Chegini]] * Hamid Reza Askari * Adel Moradi * Mohammad Ali Ahmadi * Ebrahim Mowlaei * Raed Saeedi * Azam Karami * Habib Ghorbani * Mohammad Jafar Makki Mohammad
"The release followed a careful review of individual records to determine if they posed a security threat to Iraq, and if their detention was of continued intelligence value," the American officials said in a statement.<ref name=bbc-20071109 />
==See also== * [[Iran–United States relations]] * [[2007 Iranian seizure of Royal Navy personnel]] * [[Karbala provincial headquarters raid]] * [[Baghdad kidnapping of Iranian diplomat (February 2007)]] * [[Iran hostage crisis]] * [[Iranian diplomats kidnapping (1982)]] * [[USA kill or capture strategy in Iraq]]

==External links== * [http://www.bbc.co.uk/persian/news/story/2007/01/070111_he-iran-arbil.shtml United states troops raided an Iranian consular office] ([[BBC]] Persian) * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071029171037/http://www.baztab.ir/news/57601.php Kidnapping of Iranian diplomats] (in Persian) * [http://www.alalam.ir/english/en-newspage.asp?newsid=018030120070111111524 Iran Slams US Abduction of Consulate Staff] * [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/01/11/AR2007011100248.html U.S. forces raid Iranian consulate in Iraq] (''Washington Post'') * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070927000833/http://www.muslimnews.co.uk/news/news.php?sub=1790 Iran confirms U.S. kidnap of 5 Iranian consulate staff in Iraq] * [http://www.newswire.co.nz/main/viewstory.aspx?storyid=354288&catid=0 Iran Protests Consulate Raid In Iraq]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070113045122/http://www.allheadlinenews.com/articles/7006110035 Iran Demands Release Of Embassy Staff Detained In Iraq] * [https://archive.is/20070129030843/http://mwcnews.net/content/view/11727/195/ US storms 'Iran consulate' in Arbil] * [https://www.theguardian.com/worldlatest/story/0,,-6338889,00.html U.S. Detains 6 Iranians in Irbil Raid] – ''The Guardian'' * [https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601103&sid=a90DLQrWr.YY&refer=us U.S. Forces Raid Iranian Consulate in Iraq, Detain 5 (Update2)] – Bloomberg News * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070707063105/http://news.monstersandcritics.com/middleeast/news/article_1242138.php US forces storm Iranian consulate in Arbil, arrest five]

{{Infobox organization |name = Universal Hip Hop Parade |image = Universal Hip Hop Parade (logo).jpg |caption = Universal Hip Hop Parade logo |formation = 1999 |website = {{URL|https://web.archive.org/web/20090612100050/http://www.universalhiphopparade.com:80/}} }} The '''Universal Hip Hop Parade''' '''(UHHP)''' is an annual family-friendly [[non-profit]] [[educational]] and [[cultural]] event held in the historically [[Black people|Black]] [[neighbourhood]] of [[Bedford Stuyvesant]] [[Brooklyn]] on the Saturday before the anniversary of [[Marcus Garvey|Marcus Garvey's]] August 17 birthday to bring to mind that Marcus Garvey himself also used [[popular culture]] as a tool to empower people and encouraged the growth of [[African American culture|Black institutions]].
[[Image:ManWithBanner.jpg|left|thumb|Parade]] The [[parade]] holds the distinction of being the world's longest celebration of [[Hip-hop culture]]. It covers all the traditional elements of [[Hip hop]] including [[rappers]], [[Breakdance|break dancers]], [[singers]] and [[actors]] performing both on floats and on foot. Additionally, [[Graffiti|graffiti artists]] and [[Disc jockey|deejay’s]] perform at different locations along the parade route.
The parade also presents other examples of the vibrant artistic and cultural life of the community including [[stilt walker]]s, [[motorcycle club|motorcycle]] & [[car club|van]] clubs, [[graffiti|graffiti banner displays]], [[marching band]]s, sound trucks, [[dancers]] and more. Additionally Hip-hop legends, [[elected official]]s, [[activist|community activists]] and legendary [[Master of Ceremonies|MC’s]] have participated. The parade also serves to display the emerging [[neighborhood]] of [[Bedford Stuyvesant]], including its [[art]]s, [[culture]] and growing [[commercial district]] to the residents from other neighborhoods of [[New York City]] as well as other [[tourists|visitors]] to the area. Local organizations showcase their artistic creativity, membership and colors while promoting their services, events and products. Neighborhood businesses and institutions along the route play music and distribute giveaways to help create a festive environment. Residents and visitors alike are urged to participate and join the parade procession..
==History== The Universal Hip Hop Parade was founded by Jeffery Kazembe Batts, Charles Barron, Freedom Williams and a host of activists in the fall of 1999 to celebrate the [[African American]] [[cultural]] [[activist|social activist]] roots of [[hip-hop culture]]. It is an outgrowth of the work of an earlier group, the Universal Nubian Association (UNA). Organizers come from across the [[New York City|NYC metropolitan area]] and have agreed to organize the UHHP in Bed-Stuy, Brooklyn.
In 2007 The Parade Made a Major Transition with Making the Mover and Shaker Out of Bed Stuy Brooklyn Mike Hollywood Christie aka Dj Dr Hollywood at the Helm and He took the Organization to New Heights with Monthly Open Mic's and Helping the Parade Reach its highest viewing numbers to date. Mike Hollywood Christie was the Parade Chairman from 2007 - 2011 and August 2013 - March 2014.
In addition to running the parade itself the [[nonprofit]] group Universal Hip-Hop Parade Foundation, Inc. also organizes forums, concerts, open-mike's, rallies, teach-ins and parties throughout the year.<ref>[http://www.ourtimepress.com/NewsDescribe.asp?NewsID=190&News_Type=Loca 10th Congressional District Candidates,Two Sides of the Same Coin] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061028071402/http://www.ourtimepress.com/NewsDescribe.asp?NewsID=190&News_Type=Loca |date=October 28, 2006 }}</ref>
The foundation is funded through private donations and grants including the Greater New York Development Fund of the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs, administrated by the Brooklyn Arts Council (BAC).
